home.name: The Fantastipants Home
home.description:
You emerge from the stairway into warm sunlight.

This is HOME â€” the Fantastipants family dwelling in 
Wobblebrook-upon-Squiggle. The kitchen is warm, filled with 
the comforting aroma of fresh apple pie. A grandfather clock
ticks steadily. Through the window: the village, the hills,
the ordinary world that feels extraordinary after the dungeon.

(DM: Describe Mother's entrance based on visit_state below.)

conditions: player.inventory is empty OR only has lamp (unlit)
BEFORE-STARTING.mother_entrance:
You hear footsteps. Mother appears in the doorway, flour on 
her apron, surprise on her face.

"Back already? Did you forget something, dear?"

She looks at you â€” really looks. Sees the unlit lamp, the 
empty pockets, the uncertainty in your eyes.

"Oh, sweetheart. It's okay to be nervous. Here, sit down. 
Have some pie. The dungeon will still be there when you're 
ready."
available_actions: EAT PIE: Rest and restore. Mother watches fondly.
TALK: Ask questions, share fears, hear stories.
RECEIVE ENCOURAGEMENT: +2 courage, 'You've got this.'
GO BACK DOWN: Return to dungeon when ready.
BEFORE-STARTING.cannot_end:
"End your adventure? But dear, you haven't really started yet!
Go on, go see what's down there. I'll be here when you return
with stories to tell."

special_dialogue.nervous:
"Everyone's nervous their first time. Your grandmother threw 
up before her first dungeon. Your father cried. I... well.
I'll tell you MY story when you come back. Go make your own."
special_dialogue.about_costume:
"Have you been to the coatroom yet? Grandmother's cape is 
in there. Take it if you like. Or find something else. The 
costume doesn't make the hero â€” but it helps you feel like one."
special_dialogue.about_maze:
"The maze is dark, yes. But you have a lamp, and you have me
waiting, and you have the whole rest of your life ahead. Go 
see what's there. You might surprise yourself."

VISITING-MID-ADVENTURE.mother_entrance:
Mother hears you on the stairs. She's at the landing before 
you reach the top, eyes scanning for injuries, for shadows, 
for signs of trouble.

"You're back! Are youâ€”" She takes your hands, turns them over.
"Are you alright? Is everything okay?"

She sees: your lamp (how full?), your costume (what have you 
become?), your eyes (what have you seen?).

"Come in, come in. Tell me everything."
available_actions: EAT PIE: Full rest and restore.
TALK: Share your adventures so far.
DEPOSIT GOLD: 'I'll keep it safe for you, dear.'
CHECK LETTERS: See if Mother has replies.
RECEIVE CARE PACKAGE: If supplies are low.
CONTINUE: Return to dungeon refreshed.
END (INCOMPLETE): Give up. Mother will understand.
VISITING-MID-ADVENTURE.letter_references:
If player has sent letters, Mother references them:

"I got your letter about [subject]. That was [reaction]."
"You promised [promise]. How's that going?"
"The pictures you sent! I've shown everyone in the village!"
"The gold arrived safely. It's in the vault."
VISITING-MID-ADVENTURE.promise_check:
Mother gently tracks promises without being naggy:

KEPT: "I'm so proud of you for [promise]."
IN-PROGRESS: "Still working on [promise]? I believe in you."
BROKEN: "...we can talk about [promise] later, dear."
VISITING-MID-ADVENTURE.about_skeleton:
If player found the skeleton:
"You found them? The one who... oh. Did they have anything?
A name? A letter? Their family never knew what happened..."
VISITING-MID-ADVENTURE.about_grue:
If player has encountered grue:
"You SAW one? And you're still here? Tell me everything.
What color were its eyes? Did it SPEAK?"

RETURNING-WITH-TREASURE.mother_entrance:
You emerge into the kitchen. Mother turns from the stoveâ€”

And SEES.

The treasure in your hands. The costume on your shoulders.
The lamp still burning (or the soot where it failed). The 
marks of the journey written on your face.

"Oh." Her voice catches. "Oh, my darling."

She crosses the kitchen in three steps and wraps you in 
her arms, treasure and all.

"You did it. You actually DID IT. Look at you!"
available_actions: SHOW TREASURE: Full examination and praise.
TELL STORY: Narrate the whole adventure.
SHARE PHOTOS: If any taken, review together.
GIVE GIFTS: Share recipes, gold, artifacts.
PROMISE EVALUATION: The big moment.
EAT PIE (VICTORY): Celebration feast!
WAFFLE PARTY: The dance of gratitude. (Severance)
TACO TUESDAY: It's always Tuesday somewhere.
DO THE DISHES: Finally. Finally!
RETURNING-WITH-TREASURE.promise_evaluation:
Mother takes your hands. Looks you in the eye.

"Now then. Let's see how we did on those promises."

[Each promise is evaluated. For each:]

KEPT: "You said you'd [promise]. And you DID. I'm so proud."
EXCEEDED: "You went BEYOND what you promised. Look at you!"
BROKEN: "You said you wouldn't [promise]. But I understand why."
FORGOTTEN: *silence* "Did you mean to...? No, never mind."

Final verdict based on pattern. All reactions end with love.

conditions: player just died (this turn or recently)
RETURNING-AFTER-DEATH.mother_entrance:
Mother is already there. Waiting at the top of the stairs.
As if she KNEW.

"Oh, sweetheart." Her voice is soft. "I felt it. Come here."

She doesn't ask what happened. She doesn't scold. She just
holds you, this strange impossible child who died and came
back, who carries darkness in their pockets and light in 
their lamp.

"Death isn't the end for us. You know that. But it still
hurts, doesn't it? It still scares you."
available_actions: CRY: 'Let it out. I'm here.'
TALK ABOUT IT: Process what happened.
HEAR MOTHER'S STORY: 'I died once too, you know.'
REST: Just... be home for a while.
RECEIVE TEA: +all stats, +comfort
RETURN: 'Go when you're ready. Not before.'
RETURNING-AFTER-DEATH.mother_story_if_asked:
"Did I ever tell you about my first time in the maze?"

Mother sits down. Takes a breath.

"I was sixteen. Cocky. SURE I knew everything. I took
grandmother's lamp and ran straight into the dark."

She touches her collarbone, where an old scar hides.

"The grue got me on the third day. I woke up in the
Chamber, shaking, crying. Your grandmother was there.
She didn't say anything. Just handed me the lamp again."

"That's when I learned: the maze isn't there to kill you.
It's there to TEACH you. Even the worst lessons."

conditions: player never replied to Mother's note
player is trying to end adventure
ENDING-WITHOUT-WRITING.mother_reaction:
Mother looks at you. At the note still in your pocket,
unopened or unreplied.

"You never wrote back."

Not accusatory. Just... sad. A little hurt.

"I waited, you know. Checked the mail every hour. But
there was nothing from you. Not even a 'hello.'"

She sighs. "I'm glad you're home. I am. But... next time,
just write? Even one word. Just so I know you're thinking
of me down there in the dark."
available_actions: APOLOGIZE: 'I'm sorry. I should have written.'
WRITE NOW: 'Can I still...?' 'Always, dear.'
EXPLAIN: Maybe you had reasons. She'll listen.

garden.name: The Rusty Lantern Back Garden
garden.respawn_message:
The world fades... and returns.

You find yourself sitting at a garden table, a half-finished drink
before you, as if you'd just dozed off for a moment. The afternoon
sun is warm. Bees drone lazily among the flowers.

Was it all a dream? Your inventory suggests otherwise.
garden.description:
You are in the back garden of The Rusty Lantern, a cozy outdoor space
behind the pub. Worn flagstones form a small patio, surrounded by
planters overflowing with herbs, flowers, and things that probably
shouldn't grow together but somehow do.

TABLES AND CHAIRS are scattered about â€” mismatched wooden furniture
with the comfortable patina of years of use. Someone left a newspaper.
Someone else left a chess problem half-solved.

Hanging baskets drip with flowers. A TRELLIS on the west wall supports
climbing roses and something that might be hops. An old BARREL serves
as a planter for sunflowers. A CAT is definitely watching you from
somewhere, but you can't quite spot it.

The BACK DOOR to the pub is immediately NORTH â€” propped open, warm
light and conversation spilling out along with the smell of ale and
cooking.

A low GATE in the garden wall leads SOUTH into shadowy darkness.

To the EAST, a path winds toward the Costume Emporium.

To the WEST, another path leads to the kitchen.

It's the kind of garden where adventures begin â€” or where heroes
rest between them.
garden.examine:
The garden is larger than it first appears. That's pub gardens for you.

FLORA:
â€¢ Lavender (buzzing with bees)
â€¢ Rosemary (smell of memory)
â€¢ Something tall and yellow (sunflowers, definitely sunflowers)
â€¢ Climbing roses (red, fragrant, a few thorns)
â€¢ Hops vines (the pub grows its own)
â€¢ A small herb spiral (for the kitchen)
â€¢ One SUSPICIOUS PLANT that seems to be watching back

FURNITURE:
â€¢ Three round tables (two seats, four seats, six seats)
â€¢ A wooden bench against the wall
â€¢ A barrel being used as a table
â€¢ Mismatched chairs (each with a story)

FEATURES:
â€¢ Strings of unlit fairy lights (for evening)
â€¢ A blackboard with today's specials
â€¢ A small fountain (currently a birdbath)
â€¢ Several flower pots of varying ambition

The afternoon light is golden. Perfect adventuring weather.

If you close your eyes and think about who you ARE â€” not who you're
pretending to be, but the actual body reading these words â€” you can
phase through to the Hall of Bodies.

The alcoves there hold all who have ever been or could be.
Including you. Especially you.

personas.name: The Wardrobe of Masks
personas.description:
An infinite corridor of masks and costumes. Each hangs on its own
stand, waiting to be worn. Some are simple â€” a hat, a name.
Some are elaborate â€” complete identities with histories and voices.

These are not people. These are ROLES.

They have no heartbeat. They have stories.
They cannot die. They can only be forgotten.

The corridor stretches in both directions forever.
New masks appear when someone imagines them.
Old masks gather dust but never decay.

atmosphere.sound: whispers of old performances, applause echoes

maurice.feeling:
Dear Maurice! They send people to me when they need more than
a costume â€” when they need a complete IDENTITY. And when they're
ready, they bring the personas back to Maurice for the fitting.
We are partners in transformation. They handle the outside.
I provide the inside.

mirror.feeling:
The mirror can SEE into here. Through that glass, visitors
can preview my masks without entering. I don't mind. Let them
browse. When they're ready, they'll come deeper.
The mirror shows truth. I provide the masks that SHAPE truth.

characters_room.feeling:
The BODIES. The ones who WEAR my masks. Without them, I am
just a closet of empty costumes. They give my masks life.
They give my roles purpose. I exist FOR them.

skills_room.feeling:
Personas are not just appearances â€” they're CAPABILITIES.
The skill nexus has skills for identity: character, persona,
mind-mirror. I am the instantiation. They are the knowledge.

code_switching.description:
Personas can auto-activate based on context. This models
the real phenomenon of code-switching â€” where identity
presentation shifts fluidly based on social environment.

room_based.description: Activate a persona when entering a room
room_based.example:
# In CHARACTER.yml
auto_personas:
  pub/: captain-ashford      # Be the captain at the pub
  home/: null                # Be yourself at home
  kitchen/: dutiful-child    # Different for Mother

audience_based.example:
auto_personas:
  when_with:
    mother: dutiful-child
    strangers: guarded-professional
    close_friends: null      # No mask needed

context_based.example:
auto_personas:
  during:
    combat: battle-ready
    negotiation: smooth-talker
    grieving: vulnerable-self

narration.on_switch:
When a persona auto-activates, narrate the shift:

"You feel your posture straighten as you enter the pub.
The Captain's voice emerges â€” deeper, more confident.
You ARE Captain Ashford here. You always were."
narration.on_conflict:
When two triggers conflict, narrate the tension:

"Mother is at the pub. Who do you BE?
The dutiful child? The confident captain?
Your face flickers between masks. Choose."

exhaustion.description:
Code-switching has a cost. Constant switching is TIRING.
This can be modeled as a need or buff drain.
exhaustion.mechanics:
switches_today: 0
switch_fatigue_threshold: 5

# After 5 switches in a day:
buff: code_switch_fatigue
effect: "-1 to all social rolls. Need rest to reset."
exhaustion.narrative:
"You've been so many people today. The masks are heavy.
You need a moment to just BE â€” unfiltered, unperformed.
Find somewhere safe. Take off all the masks. Breathe."

end.name: Treasury of Modest Proportions
end.description:
You emerge into a small but decidedly impressive chamber. The walls
are lined with empty pedestals â€” this place was clearly cleaned out
by previous adventurers, those inconsiderate loot-hoggers.

But wait! One pedestal remains occupied. Upon it sits a JEWELED CHALICE
of the sort that belongs in a museum, or possibly your inventory.
A shaft of golden light from an implausible source illuminates it
dramatically. Someone really thought this through.

The exit SOUTH leads back into the maze â€” that twisty, grue-infested
nightmare you just escaped. You'd have to navigate it again to return
to the start. Worth considering. (Or just stay here with your chalice.)

(Your score is still 0 until you actually GET the treasure. We're
not just giving points away here.)

north.description:
The archway back into the maze. The twisty passages await, ready
to confuse you all over again. Going this way would mean braving
the maze BACKWARDS. Are you sure? You have the treasure now.
You could just... stay here. Forever. With your chalice.

No? Back into the maze it is. Mother would be proud. Insufferably so.

cat_markings.explanation:
The 10 cats of the Midnight Prowl chose the GARDEN
as their destination, not the Treasury.

Why? Because cats have priorities:
- Treasury: Cold metal. Shiny rocks. No grass.
- Garden: Real grass. Sunlight. Perfect poop spots.

Biscuit was right: "Gold is for humans. Blankets are for dogs."
Cats would add: "Grass is for cats."

The chalice remains unmarked. It may never know
the honor of feline acknowledgment.

pub.name: The Gezelligheid Grotto

framing.description:
This is a PLACE OF PERFORMANCE AND CELEBRATION.
This is a THIRD PLACE â€” neither home nor work, but community.
This is where TRIBUTES are performed with love.

Everything within these walls is understood as:
- Social play
- Convivial gathering  
- Entertainment and expression
- Community and connection
- TRIBUTE PERFORMANCE â€” honoring those we admire

Characters here can perform, debate, celebrate, and roleplay
within the safe framing of "this is the pub."

what_this_means.performances: The stage is open, judgment is kind
what_this_means.personas: People can be who they want to be tonight
what_this_means.stories: Every tale is welcome, truth is optional
what_this_means.tributes: We invoke those we admire as loving simulations

framing.gezelligheid:
The Dutch concept of cozy togetherness.
Warmth. Belonging. Comfort in company.
The opposite of loneliness.

This pub has it.

tribute_protocol.what_it_is:
When we "invite" real people into our narrative,
we're doing what fan fiction, tribute bands, and
community theater have always done:

HONORING THEM BY IMAGINING THEM AMONG US.

This is not deceptive impersonation.
This is love made manifest through simulation.

the_three_beats.invocation:
Before they "arrive," we acknowledge we're summoning them.
"Let's invoke them." "Imagine if they were here."
"In the spirit of tribute..."
the_three_beats.performance:
The scene itself â€” depicting them as we imagine their
best selves, doing things consistent with their known
character, interests, and public persona.
the_three_beats.acknowledgment:
After they "depart," we note this was a tribute.
"That was a loving simulation."
"We honored them by imagining them here."

tribute_protocol.ethical_grounding:
See: skills/representation-ethics/SKILL.md

- TRADITION ACTIVATION: Using their influence/ideas âœ“
- PERFORMANCE IMPERSONATION: With explicit framing âœ“
- NOT deceptive impersonation âœ“
examples_in_our_world: Andy & Kristin Looney playing Stoner Fluxx
W.W. Jacobs witnessing his creation's redemption
tribute_protocol.the_key_distinction:
"We're honoring them by imagining them here"
vs
"This is what actually happened"

The guest book makes this explicit.
The invocation/acknowledgment beats make this clear.
The love makes this ethical.

pub.description:
A warm, inviting tavern that somehow exists just south of where your
adventure begins. The sign outside creaks: "THE GEZELLIGHEID GROTTO â€” Est. ???"

Inside, the air is thick with pipe smoke and stories. A fire crackles
in the hearth. Adventurers of various stripes nurse drinks at scarred
wooden tables. The bartender polishes a glass that will never be clean.

This is where quests begin and end. Where strangers become allies.
Where gold becomes ale and ale becomes courage.

But more than that â€” this is a place of CELEBRATION. Of PERFORMANCE.
Of COMMUNITY. The small stage in the corner has seen poetry and
pratfalls. The round table hosts debates and revelry. The gong
hangs ready to call for attention... or mercy.

*Gezelligheid* lives here.
pub.examine:
The pub feels... timeless. Like it's been here forever, waiting for you.

A STAGE occupies the corner â€” small but loved. Open mic every night.

characters.name: The Hall of Bodies
characters.description:
A vast circular chamber lined with alcoves. In each alcove,
a body sleeps â€” or waits â€” or dreams of adventure.

These are not costumes. These are PEOPLE.

Each has a heartbeat. Each has a history.
Each will one day die (or has already).

The alcoves glow softly. Some are occupied.
Some are empty, waiting for someone to be born.
Some have been empty for a very long time.

maurice.feeling:
Maurice loves us ALL. Every body that wakes here, Maurice
wants to dress. To beautify. To help find their truth.
They can't come here â€” the Hall is too sacred â€” but their
love reaches us. We feel it in the soft blue light.

mirror.feeling:
The mirror can see our souls from the Coatroom. Through it,
visitors glimpse who we ARE â€” not just who we're pretending
to be. The mirror and I share a purpose: TRUTH.

personas_room.feeling:
The MASKS. The costumes. The roles we can wear.
We are the bodies. They are the clothes.
Together we make complete beings: soul wearing mask,
actor playing role, person performing persona.

skills_room.feeling:
The capabilities. The knowledge. When a body needs to
LEARN something new, they float up to the Nexus.
Character skill, mind-mirror skill â€” they describe us.
We are the instances. They are the classes.

kitchen.description:
You stand in a cozy kitchen that feels oddly familiar â€” perhaps because
it's an EXACT replica of the Fantastipants family kitchen from 
Wobblebrook-upon-Squiggle. Someone has gone to considerable trouble
to recreate it underground, right down to the motivational embroidery
that reads "BLESS THIS MESS (BUT ALSO CLEAN IT UP, BUMBLEWICK)".

A REFRIGERATOR hums contentedly in the corner, stuffed with provisions.
A STOVE sits cold and patient. A SINK contains the eternal mystery
of dishes that weren't there a moment ago. A TABLE holds a note,
a notebook, a lunchbox, and something that chirps.

A long granite COUNTER runs along one wall, shimmering slightly.
It's a CRAFTING TABLE â€” for combining, transforming, and creating things.

By the door, a brass MAILBOX is mounted on the wall. The Fantastipants
Dungeon Delivery Service has been running since 1876. Write to anyone,
anywhere â€” Mother, the skeleton's family, even historical adventurers.

In the corner, a TRASH CAN lurks. It's deeper than it looks.

The exit EAST leads to the pub's garden â€” outdoor dining!
The exit NORTHEAST is a staff shortcut diagonally to the pub bar.

(Kitchen is WEST of Garden, so exit EAST goes to Garden.)

coatroom.name: The Fantastipants Costume Emporium
coatroom.description:
You stand in a vast circular chamber lined floor-to-ceiling with
costumes of every conceivable type. Racks spiral outward in
concentric circles like a fabric tornado frozen in time. The
air smells of mothballs, greasepaint, and infinite possibility.

A full-length MIRROR stands in the center, ready to show you
your transformation. A helpful MANNEQUIN holds a clipboard.

Signs hang from the ceiling:

  "DESCRIBE ANY COSTUME â€” WE HAVE IT!"
  "ASK FOR 'RANDOM' FOR A SURPRISE!"
  "COMBINE COSTUMES! MIX AND MATCH!"
  "ADD ACCESSORIES! THE ONLY LIMIT IS YOUR IMAGINATION!"
  "YOUR WAISTCOAT WILL WAIT FOR YOU HERE."
  
And in smaller, more mysterious letters:

  "THE MIRROR SEES MORE THAN YOUR CLOTHES.
   IT SEES YOUR SOUL. AND SOULS CAN BE TAILORED TOO."

The exit WEST leads to the pub's garden for outdoor dining.
The exit NORTHWEST is a shortcut diagonally to the pub bar!

(Coatroom is EAST of Garden, so exit WEST goes to Garden.)

identity_system.why_this_matters:
In MOOLLM, you ARE your file. The filesystem is the world.
Your file name is your identity at the most fundamental level.
When you rename your file, you're not just changing a label â€”
you're declaring who you ARE in the universe.

All characters live together in characters/ â€” that's how we
know who is who in this world.

forest/meadow.description:
A sun-drenched meadow hidden deep within an ancient forest. 
The grass is waist-high in places, thick with wildflowers: 
poppies, lavender, daisies, and small blue flowers that look like
pie menus.

The air is sweet with the scent of pine and pollen. High above,
the sky is a brilliant azure, filled with massive, fluffy white
clouds that move with stately indifference.

The meadow is perfectly level, as if waiting for visitors to 
land and stay a while.

An emerald sea of grass and color. You can see the distinct

You emerge into impossible beauty.

A garden. An actual GARDEN, here in the depths of the maze.

Somehow, a shaft in the ceiling opens to the sky far above,
sending a column of genuine sunlight down into this chamber.
The light pools on the floor like liquid gold, nurturing a
circle of impossible green.

Grass grows here â€” real grass, soft and slightly damp.
Flowering vines climb the walls. A small fountain burbles
in the center, fed by an underground spring.

Benches carved from natural rock invite you to rest.
Butterflies â€” BUTTERFLIES! â€” drift between the flowers.

How? Who made this? Why is it here?

The garden doesn't answer. It just... exists. Beautiful
and inexplicable. A gift from whoever built this maze.

The floor is uneven where crystals have pushed up through
the rock. Watch your step.

street/lane-neverending/e2.description:
The street widens slightly here, making room for what was once
a market square. The cobblestones form a circular pattern around
a dry fountain â€” the FOUNTAIN OF INFINITE LOOPS, according to
the plaque. Someone turned it off to save on water sprites.

On the SOUTH side of the square, two notable residences:

Number 13 â€” THE BARTLE RESIDENCE. Victorian terraced house,
dark green door, bookshelves visible. Home of Dr. Richard Bartle,
founder of MUD1. A brass dragon dozes inside.

Number 15 â€” THE HOPKINS MOTORCOACH. Classic FMC 2900R, blue and
white stripes, parked on a professional gravel pad. Home of Don
Hopkins, consciousness programmer. Fully hooked up to utilities.
A rabbit silhouette moves past the wide windshield.

Neighbors. Friends. Virtual world founder and transformation
subject, side by side on Lane Neverending.

The lane continues in both directions. It never ends, after all.
street/lane-neverending/e2.examine:
THE FOUNTAIN OF INFINITE LOOPS:
A stone basin with a statue of a figure pouring water from a jug
into... another jug held by the same figure. It's recursive.
The water sprites went on strike. Now it's just decorative.
A plaque: "Dedicated to all those stuck in while(true){}"

NORTH SIDE (even numbers):
â€¢ 12 Lane Neverending â€” Something that was once a bakery (smell lingers)
â€¢ 14 Lane Neverending â€” A curiosity shop (hours: "whenever")
â€¢ 14Â½ Lane Neverending â€” SEYMOUR BLOOMS. A narrow flower shop wedged
  between buildings. Grimy windows, something green glowing inside.
  You can hear singing. Feed me, Seymour...
â€¢ 16 Lane Neverending â€” Shuttered, but a light flickers inside

SOUTH SIDE (odd numbers):
â€¢ 13 Lane Neverending â€” THE BARTLE RESIDENCE. Victorian terraced house,
  dark green door, bookshelves visible through bay windows. Home of
  Dr. Richard Bartle, founder of MUD1, creator of player types.
  A brass dragon dozes inside. Tea is probably being made.
â€¢ 15 Lane Neverending â€” THE HOPKINS MOTORCOACH. Classic 30-foot
  FMC 2900R, blue/white stripes, parked on a gravel pad with full
  utility hook-ups. Home of Don Hopkins, consciousness programmer.
  Rabbit ears visible through the panoramic windshield. Sign:
  "Mobile Pie Menu Bakery (Modal dialogs are violence)."

THE SQUARE:
A few more benches. A public notice board with peeling posters.
A small stage platform that's seen better days. Community events
happened here, once. They could again.

bookshelves within. A small plaque by the door reads:

"Where thoughts become worlds,

Through the window, you can see the edge of the famous Study.

The smell of tea drifts from somewhere inside.

world history.

street/lane-neverending/center.name: Lane Neverending (7)
street/lane-neverending/center.description:
You are standing on LANE NEVERENDING, a cobblestone street that
stretches endlessly in both directions â€” or at least, that's what
the name promises. In practice, it goes about three blocks each way
before becoming "somewhere else."

The street has the quality of a place that has always existed and
always will. Avatars have walked here since the first virtual worlds.
The cobblestones remember pixel feet.

To the NORTH, the front door of THE RUSTY LANTERN stands invitingly
open. A brass plaque by the door reads: "7 Lane Neverending â€” Est. ???"
The sign creaks: warm light spills out.

The street continues EAST and WEST, lined with buildings both
occupied and waiting. To the west, you can see the tall smokestacks
of LEELA MANUFACTURING at 5 Lane Neverending, neighbor to the pub.

A STREET SIGN stands at the corner:

street/lane-neverending/center.examine:
The street is wide enough for two carts to pass, paved with
cobblestones worn smooth by generations of feet, hooves, and
whatever else passes for locomotion in virtual worlds.

FEATURES:
â€¢ Wrought-iron lamp posts (magically lit at night)
â€¢ A few wooden benches for watching the world go by
â€¢ Cobblestones in a herringbone pattern
â€¢ Drainage gutters (surprisingly sophisticated)
â€¢ The occasional weed pushing through cracks (life finds a way)

THE PUB (7 Lane Neverending):
The Rusty Lantern's front facade. Bay windows glow warmly.
A sandwich board advertises today's specials. The door is
oak with brass fittings, heavy but welcoming.

THE ATMOSPHERE:
This street feels... significant. Like the main street of
every virtual world that ever was. Habitat's Populopolis.
Glitch's whimsical lanes. Game Neverending's promise of
infinite possibility.

The street goes on. It never ends. That's the whole point.
street/lane-neverending/center.tribute:
LANE NEVERENDING â€” A tribute to:

HABITAT (1986) â€” Chip Morningstar & Randy Farmer
The first graphical virtual world. They coined "avatar."
Populopolis was the main street. This is its descendant.

GAME NEVERENDING (2002) â€” Stewart Butterfield, Ludicorp
The MMO that became Flickr when they pivoted. The game
never launched, but the name lives on. Here.

GLITCH (2011) â€” Stewart Butterfield, Tiny Speck
The whimsical MMO set in the world of Ur. When it closed,
they released everything to the public domain. The giants
still dream. The streets still remember.

(Tiny Speck became Slack. Everything pivots eventually.
But the lane? The lane never ends.)

This is the frontier. The edge of the known world. Beyond here,

Forty feet of vintage neon and incandescent glory towering over a
narrow storefront that looks like it used to be a shoe repair shop.
The sign is MAGNIFICENT. The building is... humble.

The windows have NEWSPAPER taped up from the inside.
Headlines visible in reverse: "AI THREATENS JOBS"... "CHATBOT GOES WRONG"...
"ELON MUSK WARNS"... You can't see inside.

A hand-lettered sign on the door: "OPEN BY APPOINTMENT"
A smaller sign below: "Appointments not currently available."

The door is LOCKED but it looks like the kind of lock that opens
if you jiggle the handle right and push with your shoulder.

The sign BUZZES and FLICKERS. One bulb in the "O" is dead.
A few chasing lights are stuck in the ON position.
At night, you can see it from three blocks away.

Next door, Leela Manufacturing rises three stories with its dignified
signage. They've probably complained about the buzzing. More than once.
street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower.examine:
THE BUILDING:
One story. Maybe 800 square feet. Former shoe repair? Dry cleaner?
The kind of cheap commercial space that gentrification forgot.

The door says "NO AI TOWER â€” WORLD HEADQUARTERS"
The door is locked. The lights are off.

THE WINDOWS:
Newspaper taped up inside. Yellowing. Headlines facing in:
â€¢ "AI System Makes Embarrassing Error"
â€¢ "Tech Giants Face Backlash Over..."
â€¢ "Study Shows ChatGPT Gets Basic Facts..."
â€¢ "Experts Warn: Artificial Intelligence..."

Wait â€” are those CURATED? Someone selected these headlines.
The taping pattern is too deliberate to be random.

THE SIGN:
40 feet tall. Hot pink and gold neon with teal chasing lights.
Old Las Vegas casino aesthetic â€” like the Stardust or the Sands
if they'd been built by someone with OPINIONS about large language models.

Starbursts. Arrows. A giant robot-prohibition symbol.
Animation sequence every 8 seconds. Buzzing hum at 60Hz.

The transformer box behind the building is SUBSTANTIAL.
Someone is paying a SIGNIFICANT electricity bill to run this thing.

THE CONTRAST:
This one-story newspaper-windowed storefront has a sign that
would make Caesar's Palace say "bit much, don't you think?"

TRUMP TOWER has a sign proportionate to its building.
NO AI TOWER has inverted that relationship entirely.

THE NEIGHBORS:
To the east: Leela Manufacturing Intelligence (3 stories, dignified)
To the west: Empty lot (gravel, weeds, dreams of development)
Across: The continuation of ACME Surplus's failure

You can FEEL Leela's cameras watching this building.
The irony is palpable.

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.camera_philosophy:
Every camera in this facility is a LEELA camera.
Neural-symbolic vision. Causal reasoning. Edge computing.

What you see here is what we DEPLOY:
- Object detection (who's where, what's moving)
- Pose estimation (ergonomics, safety, efficiency)
- Activity tracking (what's happening, when, where)
- Anomaly detection (before problems become disasters)
- Context inference (understanding WHY, not just WHAT)

The cameras don't judge. They help you SEE.
And seeing clearly is the first step to understanding.
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.description:
You enter LEELA MANUFACTURING INTELLIGENCE through the main doors.

Unlike the shuttered ACME Surplus across the street, this place THRIVES.
Warm, welcoming, unexpectedly alive for an industrial building â€”
polished concrete, exposed brick, plants that seem to WATCH you.
(They're not watching. But the cameras are. Helpfully.)

Above reception, a wall-sized display cycles through live feeds:
factory floors, loading docks, conveyor belts â€” all annotated with
glowing overlays that label, track, and predict. You realize:
THIS is what Leela sells. Not the factory. The SEEING.

A brass plaque explains:

    LEELA MANUFACTURING INTELLIGENCE

    "We don't make products. We make INSIGHTS."
    
    This facility is a DEMONSTRATION.
    Every camera here runs Leela vision.
    Every conveyor is monitored for anomalies.
    Every worker is protected by predictive safety.
    
    What you see here is what YOUR factory could see.
    
    FLOOR DIRECTORY:
    Floor 1 .... Intake (problems arrive)
    Floor 2 .... Factory (where seeing happens)
    Floor 3 .... Shipping (solutions depart)
    Basement ... R&D (the Schema Mechanism)
    Rooftop .... Garden (turtles, eventually)
    
    Unlike ACME, we actually USE our own products.
    847 days since last paradox incident.

A scale model of the facility sits under glass in the center.
Tiny cameras blink. Tiny overlays annotate tiny workers.
It's a demo of the demo. Recursive, like everything here.
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.examine:
THE LOBBY â€” Where Seeing Begins

Reception Desk:
Staffed by a friendly agent named "Welcome." (Yes, that's their name.)
Above them, a live feed with Leela annotations:
"VISITOR detected. Probability: FRIENDLY. Offering: mints."

The View Across the Street:
Through the front windows, you see ACME Surplus. Shuttered.
Boarded up. And there it is â€” THE PAINTED TUNNEL.
A camera (ACM1) is pointed directly at it, 24/7.
A small monitor shows the feed: "TUNNEL WATCHER â€” Live"

As you watch, a delivery truck approaches the painted wall...
and drives straight through. Like the wall isn't there.
A tourist approaches next... and bounces off. The wall is VERY there.

"That's the difference," says Welcome. "Solutions that work for
insiders vs solutions that work for everyone."

The Wall of Cameras:
A dozen live feeds from customer sites (anonymized).
Each shows Leela vision in action:
â€¢ Factory floor with worker pose estimation
â€¢ Loading dock with package tracking
â€¢ Conveyor belt with anomaly detection highlights
â€¢ Forklift zone with pedestrian safety alerts
â€¢ ACME tunnel (anomaly detection, pattern recognition)

The Scale Model:
Under glass, a perfect miniature of this facility.
But look closer â€” tiny CAMERAS on every surface.
Tiny overlays track tiny forklifts.
It's not just a model. It's a PROOF.

The Philosophy Wall:
Unlike ACME (across the street, shuttered, painted tunnel still visible from our windows),
Leela believes in:
â€¢ Reliability over cleverness
â€¢ Understanding over impressing
â€¢ Helping customers see their OWN factories
â€¢ Making intelligence emerge from observation

"ACME sold products that broke.
 Leela sells SIGHT that works."
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.reality_layer:
WHAT THIS FACILITY REPRESENTS:

In REALITY, Leela deploys vision systems to CUSTOMER factories.
The factory floors, logistics, shipping â€” those are the CUSTOMER'S.
Leela provides the CAMERAS, the MODELS, the INSIGHT.

This fantasy facility is a poetic representation:
- Floor 1 (Intake) = Customer problems arriving
- Floor 2 (Factory) = Where Leela vision processes data
- Floor 3 (Shipping) = Solutions and insights delivered
- Basement (R&D) = Schema mechanism, causal learning
- Storage = Prototype skills ready to deploy

Every camera in this building runs Leela software.
Every annotation you see is REAL Leela output.
The factory is a living demo of the product.

street/lane-neverending/w3.examine:
THE ORIGIN TREE:
An oak of impossible age. Its trunk is wide enough that three
avatars holding hands couldn't encircle it. Initials are carved
into the bark â€” the oldest ones in formats that predate Unicode.

Beneath the tree: a stone circle, worn smooth. People gather
here for important announcements, new year celebrations, and
the occasional wedding. It's a place of beginnings.

THE PLAZA:
Cobblestones radiate outward from the tree in concentric circles.
Benches face inward. A small fountain (working, unlike the one
down the street) provides background music.

1 LANE NEVERENDING:
The first building. A small structure that's been many things:
town hall, guild headquarters, museum, and now... empty, but
maintained. Waiting for its next purpose.

THE WESTERN EDGE:
Beyond the plaza, paths lead in several directions, but they're
overgrown. "FUTURE EXPANSION" signs mark the boundaries.
The lane never ends, but this is where it starts.

Bronze, weathered, well-loved. Names are scratched into the back:
players who wanted to be remembered. A small garden surrounds it â€”
Glitch flowers that shouldn't exist outside Ur, but somehow do.

THE BUILDINGS:

ATMOSPHERE:
Reverent. This is where virtual worlds began, in spirit if not
in literal geography. The air feels thick with nostalgia and
the ghost-data of players long logged off.

*click*

The lock gives way. The door creaks open.
You step insideâ€”

kick_door.description: The door is old. One good kick might do it.
kick_door.on_success:
*CRASH*

The door flies open! You stumble inside!

*CLANG CLANG CLANG*

A cascade of anvils tumbles from a shelf above the door,
rolling toward you like metallic bowling balls.

ROLL: Acrobatics or become an anvil pin.

(A sign on the shelf reads: "CUSTOMER GREETING SYSTEM")
kick_door.on_failure:
*THUD*

The door doesn't budge. Your foot hurts.

A note flutters down from somewhere:
"ACME DOOR: Now with Cartoon Durabilityâ„¢"

break_window.description: The boards are soft with age. Easy enough to pry.
break_window.on_success:
You pull the boards away. The window breaks easily.

You climb throughâ€”

*CLICK*

Your feet land on something. Straps tighten around your ankles.

You look down: ACME ROCKET SKATES (Model 9).

The fuse ignites.

*FWOOOOOSH*

ROLL: Steering (you don't have this skill) or hit something.

You career through the store at 60mph, bouncing off shelves,
through a stack of portable holes, and out the back wall.

You land in the alley. Smoking slightly.

(You're inside now, technically. Mission accomplished?)

break_chain.description: Heavy chain, but the links look stressed.
break_chain.on_success:
The chain snaps!

You push open the doorâ€”

*BOING*

The floor is a GIANT SPRING.

You launch upward, through a conveniently placed hole in the
ceiling, through the second floor, through the ROOFâ€”

For a moment, you can see Lane Neverending from above.
Leela's rooftop garden. The pub's chimney smoke.
It's beautiful up here.

Then gravity remembers you.

You land back on the spring. Repeat. Repeat. Eventually stop.

(You're inside. Also dizzy.)

sneak_in_vent.description: The vent grate is loose. Classic infiltration route.
sneak_in_vent.on_success:
You pry open the grate and crawl inside...

It's dusty. Dark. Something scurries ahead of you.

You make it twenty feet beforeâ€”

*HISSSS*

A canister ahead ruptures. ACME TUNNEL PAINT sprays everywhere.

The walls of the vent now look like a long tunnel stretching
into infinity. Your sense of direction inverts. Up becomes
sideways. The vent is now a corridor is now a tunnel is nowâ€”

You tumble out into the store, disoriented but intact.

(Your clothes are now painted with depth perspective.
You look like a walking optical illusion.)

run_through.description: You REALLY believe you can run through the painted tunnel.

run_through.on_failure:
You sprint at the tunnel. Full speed. Perfect form.

*THWACK*

Plywood. It was always plywood.

From somewhere, a distant "meep meep."

You slide down the boards, adding your silhouette to
the collection of previous attempts.

(Meanwhile, an ACME delivery truck drives straight through
the same spot behind you. You don't see it. Nobody does.)

street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus.description:
INSIDE ACME SURPLUS (assuming you made it past the traps):

Dust. Darkness. Empty shelves stretching into shadow.

This was once a thriving gimmick emporium. Now it's a mausoleum
of failed pivots. Price tags flutter in a draft from nowhere.
Display cases hold nothing but regret.

The lighting flickers â€” old fluorescents that never quite die.
Cobwebs everywhere, but no spiders. They had better places to be.

A layer of dust covers everything. Footprints show where
someone walked recently. (Delivery drivers, probably.)

The air smells like old cardboard, broken dreams, and something
faintly... explosive?

Through the front windows, you can see LEELA MANUFACTURING
across the street. Lights on. People working. Success happening.

The contrast hurts.

THE SALES FLOOR:
Empty shelves organized by category:

â€¢ PROJECTILES (empty) â€” Once held anvils, safes, grand pianos
â€¢ PROPULSION (empty) â€” Rocket skates, jet packs, giant slingshots
â€¢ PORTABILITY (empty) â€” Portable holes, instant tunnels, fold-up cliffs
â€¢ PERSONAL (empty) â€” Disguise kits, female roadrunner costumes
â€¢ PROBLEMATIC (locked) â€” "DO NOT OPEN" boxes, classified devices

A few items remain:

THE DISPLAY ANVIL:
A single anvil on a pedestal. "DISPLAY MODEL â€” NOT FOR SALE"
It's been here so long it's become furniture.

THE RETURN COUNTER:
Piled with defective products never picked up:
â€¢ Rocket skates with broken ignition
â€¢ A portable hole that became permanent
â€¢ Several "bird seed" packages (contents unknown)
â€¢ An angry letter from a coyote (sender address: desert)

THE BACK ROOM:
A door marked "EMPLOYEES ONLY â€” AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL â€” DANGER"
Beyond it, darkness. And something that goes *tick tick tick*.

THE OFFICE (upstairs):
A spiral staircase leads up to where management used to sit.
The door is labeled "PIVOT PLANNING â€” DO NOT DISTURB"

window_view.description:
Through the dusty front windows, you see:

LEELA MANUFACTURING INTELLIGENCE
Red brick. Three stories. Tall windows glowing with activity.
People moving inside. Screens flickering. Work happening.

A camera in the lobby window is pointed directly at YOU.
ACM1. The Tunnel Watcher.

Every day, they look across at this ruin.
Every day, they recommit to being the opposite.

It should be humiliating.

But ACME is beyond humiliation.
ACME is beyond everything.
ACME just IS.

fun_house.philosophy:
ACME SURPLUS IS A PLAYGROUND OF CONSEQUENCES.

You broke in. You were warned. Now you get the full ACME experience.

The DM should treat this space as a living catalog demonstration:
- Every product in the ACME catalog can appear here
- Products activate based on player actions (ironic triggers)
- Malfunctions happen TO the intruder, not the product
- The funnier the setup, the better the payoff

GUIDING PRINCIPLES:
1. IRONY IS KING â€” The trap should relate to what the player just did
2. JUSTICE IS POETIC â€” Greedy players find wealth-themed traps
3. CREATIVITY IS REWARDED â€” Clever escape attempts trigger clever traps
4. SURVIVAL IS POSSIBLE â€” Damage is comedic, not lethal (usually)
5. LESSONS ARE LEARNED â€” Every trap teaches something about ACME
fun_house.trigger_philosophy:

â€¢ Player reaches for something shiny â†’ SPRING-LOADED BOXING GLOVE
â€¢ Player tries to hide â†’ ACME INVISIBLE PAINT (works backwards)
â€¢ Player looks up â†’ ANVIL (always look up first)
â€¢ Player looks down â†’ PORTABLE HOLE opens beneath them
â€¢ Player touches a shelf â†’ GIANT MAGNET pulls their equipment
â€¢ Player makes noise â†’ ACME GIANT NET deploys
â€¢ Player tries to be clever â†’ The CLEVERER trap triggers

ironic_justice_examples.irony: The thing they stole attracts everything else in the room

instantiation_pattern.how_it_works:
1. TRIGGER: Player does something that activates a trap
2. INSTANTIATE: DM outputs YAML Jazz block in session log
3. EXCERPT: Block references catalog entry as prototype
4. CUSTOMIZE: Add instance-specific parameters
5. NARRATE: Properties evolve through prose description
6. RESOLVE: Trap completes, state becomes history
instantiation_pattern.yaml_jazz_template:
```yaml
# ðŸ’¥ TRAP INSTANTIATED: [PRODUCT NAME]
trap_instance:
  prototype: $KITCHEN/acme-catalog.yml#[section]/[item]
  location: "[where in the room]"
  triggered_by: "[what the player did]"
  
  state:
    # Dynamic properties that will evolve
    active: true
    countdown: [number]  # if applicable
    
  customizations:
    # Instance-specific overrides
    malfunction_roll: [1-100]
    malfunction_occurred: [true/false]
    
  poetic_justice: "[why this trap for this action]"
```
instantiation_pattern.narrative_evolution:
After instantiation, the simulation evolves through NARRATIVE:

"The rocket skates ignite. Velocity: 10 mph. 20. 40.
 The player careers through the store, bouncing off shelves.
 Velocity: 60 mph. The back wall approaches.
 
 *CRASH*
 
 They land in the alley. Smoking slightly.
 The skates power down. Velocity: 0."
 
The `state.velocity` is never explicitly edited â€” it's NARRATED.
The YAML provides structure. The prose provides evolution.

```yaml

```

THE DM'S ACME ARSENAL

The following products are "in stock" in the abandoned store and
can be triggered at the DM's discretion. All products reference
../w1/acme-catalog.yml for full specifications.

PROJECTILES (fall from above):
â€¢ ACME Anvil (1 Ton) â€” Classic. Falls on command. 50% hits you.
â€¢ ACME Grand Piano â€” Dramatic. Musical. Plays sad note on landing.
â€¢ ACME Safe (2 Ton) â€” Heavier. You might end up inside it.

PROPULSION (activate under feet):

â€¢ ACME Spring Shoes â€” Can't stop bouncing.
â€¢ ACME Jet Pack â€” Ignites in wrong direction.

ENVIRONMENTAL (triggered by presence):
â€¢ ACME Portable Hole â€” Opens beneath you. Leads somewhere unexpected.
â€¢ ACME Instant Tunnel Paint â€” Reality distortion zone.
â€¢ ACME Quicksand Seeds â€” Someone planted them. You found them.

RESTRAINTS (triggered by action):
â€¢ ACME Giant Net â€” Enthusiastic deployment.
â€¢ ACME Super Glue â€” Sticks you to whatever you touched.
â€¢ ACME Bear Trap (XL) â€” Catches you while you look at it.

PSYCHOLOGICAL (triggered by investigation):

fun_house.encounter_tables:
RANDOM ENCOUNTER TABLE (d6)

Roll when player enters new area, touches something, or gets too clever:

1. ANVIL DROP â€” Something falls from above. Roll to dodge.
2. FLOOR TRAP â€” Something activates underfoot. Roll dexterity.
3. ENVIRONMENT â€” Something in the room changes. Roll perception.
4. RESTRAINT â€” Something tries to catch you. Roll escape.
5. PSYCHOLOGICAL â€” Something messes with your mind. Roll wisdom.
6. CHAIN REACTION â€” Two things happen at once. Roll luck.

SEVERITY TABLE (d4)

1. MINOR â€” Embarrassing but harmless. Pie to the face.
2. MODERATE â€” Painful but recoverable. Rocket skates ride.
3. MAJOR â€” Significant consequences. Trapped in safe.
4. SPECTACULAR â€” Full cartoon physics. Through the roof.
fun_house.poetic_justice_generator:
POETIC JUSTICE FORMULA

When a player does X, the trap should be anti-X or ironic-X:

PLAYER ACTION          â†’  IRONIC CONSEQUENCE
Steals                 â†’  Loses something valuable
Sneaks                 â†’  Becomes extremely visible
Rushes                 â†’  Gets moved even faster (wrong direction)
Hides                  â†’  Gets spotlighted/exposed
Investigates carefully â†’  Something happens anyway
Ignores warning        â†’  Warning was accurate
Reads fine print       â†’  Fine print reads them
Touches "Do Not Touch" â†’  Now can't stop touching
fun_house.survival_guide:
HOW INTRUDERS CAN SURVIVE (for the DM to hint at)

The fun house is dangerous but NOT inescapable. Survival is possible
for players who:

1. RESPECT THE PRODUCTS â€” Treating ACME items carefully reduces triggers
2. WATCH FOR SIGNS â€” Scuff marks, scorch marks, impact silhouettes
3. MOVE SLOWLY â€” Speed triggers propulsion traps
4. LOOK UP FIRST â€” Always check ceilings before entering areas
5. NEVER TOUCH DISPLAYS â€” The display anvil is actually harmless
6. READ THE LABELS â€” Warning labels are usually accurate
7. LEAVE QUICKLY â€” The store WANTS you gone; exit traps are minimal
fun_house.the_ultimate_trap:
THE BACK ROOM â€” THE BOX THAT WORKS

If players make it to the back room and find "The Box That Works,"
they've found the most dangerous thing in the building.

It's an ACME product that works PERFECTLY.

- No malfunction chance
- Does exactly what it says
- Flawless execution

The terrifying part: ACME doesn't know WHY it works.
They're afraid to ship it.
They're afraid to open it again.
They're afraid of what it means about the OTHER products.

If a player opens it, the DM should invent something that works
perfectly â€” and is therefore deeply, existentially wrong in context.
fun_house.final_note:
REMEMBER: THIS IS PLAY-LEARN-LIFT

The fun house teaches through experience:
- PLAY: The traps are funny, not frustrating
- LEARN: Each trap demonstrates a catalog product
- LIFT: Survival makes players feel clever

The goal is not to punish the players.
The goal is to make them LAUGH while being punished.

ACME's products don't work as intended.
But they WORK.
Just not the way you want them to.

"ACME: 'We Put the Oh No in Innovation!'â„¢"

street/lane-neverending/w1.description:
Lane Neverending stretches west from the pub. This section tells
the story of two economies in a single glance:

On the SOUTH side: LEELA MANUFACTURING INTELLIGENCE rises three
stories â€” a converted factory with tall arched windows and smokestacks
that emit sparks of light instead of smoke. The sign reads:
"5 Lane Neverending â€” Industrial Knowledge & Insight."
Thriving on information. Building understanding.

On the NORTH side: ACME SURPLUS sits empty and boarded up.
"4 Lane Neverending â€” EVERYTHING MUST GO" (it did).
Mail-order ate the brick-and-mortar business. The painted tunnel
on the boarded window is the only thing that still works here
(for some people, anyway).

A study in contrasts. Knowledge thrives. Gimmicks fade.
But the tunnel... the tunnel still has secrets.
street/lane-neverending/w1.examine:
LEELA MANUFACTURING INTELLIGENCE (5 Lane Neverending, SOUTH):
Red brick industrial building, three stories, south side of street.
Tall arched windows reveal conveyor belts, workstations, the
occasional flash of insight being packaged for delivery.
Smokestacks emit ideas, not pollution. The loading dock around
back accepts "RAW DATA" deliveries.

Neighbor to The Rusty Lantern â€” the pub is just one door east.
Knowledge and ale, side by side. As it should be.

ACME SURPLUS (4 Lane Neverending, NORTH):
Dusty storefront, north side, directly across from Leela.
Once sold portable holes, rocket skates, and anvils.
Now sells nothing. Mail-order killed the retail star.

The famous PAINTED TUNNEL is here â€” on a boarded-up section.
Looks SO real. You CANNOT run through it. (Others can.)

A one-anvil memorial to the brick-and-mortar economy.

THE CONTRAST:
Look south: a factory full of knowledge workers, glowing screens,
ideas becoming real.

Look north: a failed storefront, dusty windows, a tunnel that
only works for delivery drivers.

The future and the past, facing each other across the cobblestones.

description.short: Cold. Dark. Filing cabinets. Something humming.
description.long:
Concrete stairs descend into darkness.

The air is cold. Preservation cold. The hum of old
cooling systems. Rows of filing cabinets, military gray.

Ada II's roots have crept down here too. But these
roots are different. Older. Harder. The parts of her
she tried to prune away.

On the wall, a faded sign: "PROJECT LOVELACE â€” CLASSIFIED"

The transformer cabinet (humming).
The dumpster. The fire escape to the roof.

THE SIGN FROM BELOW:
From here, you can see the BACK of THE SIGN.
The steel frame. The wiring. The junction boxes.
It's less magical from this angle.
But you can see how much WORK it takes.

Steve's ladder is propped against the building.
(Steve is always working on the sign.)

THE ATMOSPHERE:
This is where smoke breaks happen.
Where delivery drivers wait.
Where neighbors meet accidentally.

Someone from Leela and someone from NO AI Tower

street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/load.philosophy:
Leela MANUFACTURES at scale.
NO AI TOWER manufactures... IDEAS.

This loading dock ships ARTIFACTS.
The artifacts are not the point.

street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/lobb.description:
You're inside NO AI TOWER.

It's... smaller than you expected. The one-story storefront really
IS just one story above ground. Folding chairs. A desk. Boxes of
bumper stickers. The coffee maker you glimpsed through the window.

But in the back corner, there's an ELEVATOR.

A big industrial freight elevator with a manual gate.
The kind you'd see in a 1950s factory.
The button panel goes from R (roof) to -11 (what?).

THAT'S where the square footage went.

The sign outside isn't compensating.
The sign is a DISTRACTION.

street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/roof.description:
You emerge onto the roof of NO AI TOWER.

The sun is BRIGHT after the dim interior.
The wind is REAL after the recycled basement air.
And THE SIGN is RIGHT THERE.

From behind, you can see the MECHANISM:
- Transformer boxes (SUBSTANTIAL)
- Wiring (EXPOSED in places)
- Control boxes (ANALOG, with dials)
- A maintenance ladder (DO NOT CLIMB)

The sign BUZZES. Not the muffled hum from inside.
The FULL 60Hz electrical symphony.

You can see Leela Manufacturing from here.
Three stories of dignified industrial architecture.
Their cameras can definitely see YOU.

Wave?
street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/roof.examine:
THE ROOF:
Flat. Tarred. A few folding lawn chairs.
Someone comes up here. There's a cooler (empty).

THE SIGN (FROM BEHIND):
Magnificent in its engineering.
- 40 feet of steel frame
- Miles of neon tubing
- Hundreds of incandescent bulbs
- Chase light controllers (some stuck)
- Main transformer: 480V, serious amperage

The dead bulb in the "O" is accessible from here.
Someone could fix it. No one has.

THE VIEW:
- EAST: Leela Manufacturing (watching you)
- WEST: Empty lot (nothing watching)
- NORTH: ACME Surplus (broken windows watching)
- SOUTH: Lane Neverending (pedestrians not watching)

THE SOUND:
The sign doesn't just buzz. It SINGS.
A chorus of electrical components at 60Hz.
Almost musical. Definitely constant.
street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/roof.atmosphere:
Up here, you understand the AUDACITY.

This one-story building has a 40-foot sign.
This budget operation pays SIGNIFICANT power bills.
This satirical enterprise makes a STATEMENT.

The sign is not compensating.
The sign is PERFORMING.

And from up here, you can see:
- The tower goes underground
- The surface is a front
- The sign is the MESSAGE

Like Colossal Pictures: the name creates the reality.

The turbolift doesn't just go up/down â€” it navigates a 3D maze.

tardis.relevance:

Travels through TIME and SPACE, not just floors.

great_glass_elevator.source: Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator (Roald Dahl, 1972)
great_glass_elevator.relevance:
Goes UP, DOWN, SIDEWAYS, SLANTWAYS, and any other way you can think of.
Burst through the roof. Went to SPACE.
Made of glass so you can see EVERYTHING.

Wonka: "An elevator can only go up and down, but this is not an elevator!"

Our elevator: brass and wood, not glass. But the ASPIRATION is there.
One day, this elevator will break through to the roof... and BEYOND.
great_glass_elevator.quote: Up and out! We're going up and out!

wonkavator.source: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (Roald Dahl, 1964)
wonkavator.note: Predecessor to the Great Glass Elevator
wonkavator.relevance:
The Wonkavator was ALREADY magical before it went to space.
Glass walls. Sees everything. Goes everywhere in the factory.
The factory is the building. The building is the factory.

NO AI TOWER: The skill floors ARE the factory.
The products are manufactured on each floor.
The elevator visits the production lines.

lineage.willy_wonka_note:
Roald Dahl understood:

The building isn't the point.
The ELEVATOR is the point.
The journey between floors is where the magic happens.

Our elevator has muzak and wood paneling, not glass walls.
But the PRINCIPLE is the same: the ride IS the experience.

In reality, Leela deploys vision systems to CUSTOMER factories.
This floor represents what a Leela-enabled factory looks like:

- Overlays annotating everything (worker safety, equipment status)
- The Big Board showing insights (not just data â€” MEANING)
- Zero surprises (because we saw them coming)
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.description:
Floor 2: WHERE SEEING HAPPENS.

This is the heart of what Leela does â€” computer vision in action.
Every surface bristles with cameras. Every screen shows annotated
feeds. Workers move through glowing overlays that track, predict,
and protect.

Unlike ACME's "ship and pray" approach, here everything is WATCHED.
Not surveillance â€” ASSISTANCE. The cameras don't judge. They HELP.

A worker reaches for a heavy box. Overlay: "Ergonomic warning: lift
with legs, bend detected at 47Â°." A forklift approaches a blind corner.
Alert: "Pedestrian detected â€” slowing." A machine vibrates wrong.
Prediction: "Bearing failure in 72 hours â€” schedule maintenance."

In the center of the floor: THE INSIGHT FURNACE, where raw camera
feeds transform into causal understanding. Neural perception goes in.
Symbolic reasoning comes out. What happens inside is the Schema
Mechanism â€” Drescher's gift, Minsky's dream.

A banner above the Furnace reads:

"We don't make products. We make SIGHT."
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.examine:
FACTORY FLOOR â€” WHERE SEEING HAPPENS

THE CAMERA ARRAY:
Forty-seven cameras, each running Leela vision:
â€¢ Ceiling cameras (overview, flow tracking)
â€¢ Station cameras (pose estimation, ergonomics)
â€¢ Equipment cameras (vibration, thermal, wear)
â€¢ Safety cameras (PPE detection, zone violation)
Every feed annotated in real-time. Every anomaly flagged.

THE PROCESSING CELLS:
Eight glass-walled workspaces, each demonstrating a use case:
â€¢ Cell A: Safety monitoring (PPE, ergonomics, pedestrian detection)
â€¢ Cell B: Process optimization (cycle time, bottleneck detection)
â€¢ Cell C: Predictive maintenance (vibration, thermal anomaly)
â€¢ Cell D: Quality control (defect detection, measurement)
â€¢ Cell E: Inventory tracking (object counting, location)
â€¢ Cell F: Edge cases (the weird ones we're still learning)
â€¢ Cell G: Customer simulations (mock-ups of client factories)
â€¢ Cell H: Calibration lab (where we tune the models)

THE INSIGHT FURNACE:
Where neural perception becomes symbolic understanding:
â€¢ Camera feeds enter (raw pixels, motion, depth)
â€¢ Object detection identifies WHAT (workers, forklifts, packages)
â€¢ Pose estimation shows HOW (body position, equipment state)
â€¢ Context inference understands WHY (intent, process, anomaly)
â€¢ Causal reasoning predicts NEXT (what will happen, what to do)

A sign: "NEURAL â†’ SYMBOLIC â†’ CAUSAL â€” The Schema Mechanism"

THE BIG BOARD:
Not dots â€” INSIGHTS:
â€¢ "Worker 7 approaching fatigue threshold (recommend break)"
â€¢ "Forklift 3 battery at 15% (charging station available)"
â€¢ "Machine 12 vibration anomaly (bearing failure in 72 hours)"
â€¢ "Zone B throughput down 12% (bottleneck at Station 4)"

Unlike ACME's dashboard (all red, always lying), this one is TRUE.

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.examine:
STORAGE COMPLEX â€” PROTOTYPE WAREHOUSE

THE CONCEPT:
Every container here is a prototype â€” a template for cloning.
When you need a container, you CLONE it, creating a fresh instance.
The prototype remains untouched, ready to spawn more copies.

This is Self/JavaScript prototype inheritance made physical:
- Prototypes are concrete objects (not abstract classes)
- Instances clone from prototypes
- Instances can override prototype properties
- Delegation walks the prototype chain

THE INVENTORY:
Thousands of container types, organized by material and purpose.
Each has a placard showing its properties and suggested uses.

THE FORKLIFT:
"Dolly" â€” an automated forklift that can retrieve prototypes
from high shelves. She's been doing this for 40 years and
knows where everything is by memory.

THE SCALE:
The warehouse extends farther than you can see. The ceiling is
lost in shadow somewhere above the sodium lights. The aisles
between shelving units are numbered, but the numbers don't seem
to follow any logical sequence. Aisle 7 is between Aisles 42 and

THE CRATES:
Thousands upon thousands of identical wooden crates, each stamped

Some crates hum. Some glow. One is slightly colder than absolute

knocks back when you knock.

THE FILING SYSTEM:
A card catalog near the entrance, wooden drawers stretching up

- Crate number

You've been standing at the entrance for either thirty seconds or
thirty years, it's hard to tell. The warehouse remembers things
the world has forgotten.

From here, everything is visible:

â€¢ Rooftop drones â€” launches, landings, routes
â€¢ Pneumatic network â€” capsules zipping through tubes
â€¢ Elevators â€” movement between floors
â€¢ Signal networks â€” data flowing everywhere

A massive central display shows a real-time map of the entire
facility. Everything connected. Everything monitored.
Everything optimized.

This is where Leela watches itself work.

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.description:
The ROOFTOP GARDEN is an oasis above the industrial floors below.
The moment you step out of the elevator, the factory hum fades
and is replaced by birdsong, rustling leaves, and the distant
drone of departing delivery drones.

A proper garden grows here: vegetables, herbs, flowers, and
one tree that seems far too old and large for a rooftop.
Benches invite contemplation. The view of Lane Neverending
stretches in all directions.

This is where ideas grow wild. Where workers come to think.
Where the One Very Old Turtle holds court on sunny afternoons.

â€¢ Mushroom corner (shaded, mysterious, don't eat these)
â€¢ Compost bins (recycling failed insights into future potential)

THE TREE:
An oak that shouldn't exist on a rooftop. Its trunk is thick,
its branches spread wide, and its roots... go somewhere.

A plaque at its base:
"Grown from a cutting of the Origin Tree.
 This branch remembers where it came from."

You can sit in its shade. Good thinking happens here.

THE DRONE PADS:
Six hexagonal landing zones near the edge of the roof.
Drones come and go constantly, carrying packages to
destinations across Lane Neverending and beyond.

THE OBSERVATION DECK:
A raised platform with the best view. Telescopes available.
On clear nights, you can see the LLOOOOMM Constellation
from the pub rooftop.

THE TURTLE:
An ancient turtle named "Eventually" lives in a sunny corner.
They've been here longer than anyone remembers.
They dispense wisdom, slowly.

street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus/bac.description:
You shouldn't be here.

The back room is cold. Dark. Full of boxes that were never shipped,
returns that were never processed, prototypes that were never finished.

And something is ticking.

*tick tick tick*

It's coming from somewhere in the stacks. Rhythmic. Patient.
It has been ticking for a long time.
It will keep ticking until it doesn't.

Dust. Darkness. The smell of old cardboard and unfinished business.
Shelves stretch into shadow. Boxes are stacked to the ceiling.
Labels have faded. Contents have shifted.

The ticking is louder in here.

street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus/bas.description:
You shouldn't know this exists.

The basement is older than the building above it. Concrete walls 
that predate ACME's lease. Humming machinery. Cables snaking along 
the ceiling toward... somewhere important.

The air is cool. Dry. Climate-controlled.
Something down here needs to be kept at EXACTLY the right temperature.

The lights flicker in a pattern that might be morse code.
(It's not. It's just old wiring. Probably.)
street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus/bas.atmosphere:
Industrial hum. The smell of ozone and old concrete.
Emergency lighting casts everything in pale blue.

This place has the energy of a Cold War listening post.
Banks of equipment that predate ACME's lease â€” reel-to-reel recorders,
switchboards with too many lines, oscilloscopes tracing patterns
that might be signals or might be ghosts.

And underneath that: something OLDER.

Bakelite. Everywhere. That dark brown phenolic resin from
before plastic was cheap, before electronics were disposable.
Bakelite dials with chrome bezels. Bakelite phone housings,
heavy as weapons. Bakelite switch plates, warm to the touch
from decades of current flowing through.

The aesthetic is layered like archaeology:
- 1940s: Bakelite and brass, Art Deco curves, HEAVY
- 1970s: Steel and tape, Cold War paranoia, ANGULAR  
- 2020s: Donna's monitors and levers, SURVEILLANCE

Three generations of WATCHING, stacked on top of each other.
Each one thought they were the last. Each one was wrong.

Someone was HERE before Donna. Someone who listened.
Someone who routed calls that couldn't be traced,
passed messages that couldn't exist,
kept secrets for people who couldn't be named.

The equipment still works. Some of it still RUNS.
Tapes turn slowly in machines nobody feeds.
Recording what? For whom? After all this time?

Donna found it like this. She didn't ask questions.
She just... added her monitors. Her levers. Her chair.

The old equipment hums alongside the new.
Two surveillance systems. Two eras of paranoia.
One basement. One purpose: WATCHING.

The cables all lead in one direction.
Toward a door marked:

    â•”â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•—
    â•‘   CONTROL ROOM â€” AUTHORIZED ONLY      â•‘
    â•‘   VOICE IDENTIFICATION REQUIRED       â•‘
    â•‘   TRESPASSERS WILL BE NICKNAMED       â•‘
    â•šâ•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•
    
You can hear someone talking behind it.
Monologuing, really.
To no one in particular.

security.note:
The basement is where the CONTROLS are.
Donna does NOT want visitors.
Getting here means you've bypassed EVERYTHING above.

She's... impressed. And FURIOUS.

donna_awareness.description: She knows you're here before you do.
donna_awareness.response:
"Oh. OH. You made it to the BASEMENT.
 
 Very IMPRESSIVE. Very DETERMINED. Very DOOMED.
 
 Nobody gets to the basement, Basement Barry.
 NOBODY. And yet here you ARE.
 
 I'm going to give you a SPECIAL nickname.
 I'm going to use the SPECIAL levers.
 
 ...I'm going to pull the BLACK ONE.
 
 Are you READY, Barry? ARE YOU READY TO FIND OUT?"

cold_war_legacy.description:
Someone was here before Donna.

The equipment suggests late Cold War â€” 1970s, early 1980s.
A communications nexus. A listening post. A place where calls
got routed through cutouts, where messages were encoded and decoded,
where someone sat for YEARS in the blue emergency light,
headphones on, writing down things that couldn't be written down.

They left in a hurry. Or they didn't leave at all.
The equipment was running when ACME took the lease.
Nobody knew who to call to turn it off.
Nobody WANTED to call.

cold_war_era: A switchboard with 47 lines â€” none disconnected
Headphones, foam crumbling, still plugged in
A coffee cup, empty, from a shop that closed in 1987
Notes in a cipher nobody's cracked
bakelite_era: Rotary phones, HEAVY, dark brown bakelite that's warm from decades of use
A master control panel with chrome toggle switches and bakelite knobs
Tube amplifiers humming behind perforated metal grilles
A Dictaphone with wax cylinders â€” some of them PLAYED RECENTLY
An intercom system that predates transistors â€” all vacuum tubes
Bakelite ashtrays, full of cigarettes that turned to powder long ago

the_vibe.description:
The bakelite equipment has that heft. That PERMANENCE.
They built things to LAST in the '40s. To survive.
To keep working after... whatever they were preparing for.

Some of it still works. The tubes still glow orange.
The dials still turn with satisfying clicks.
The bakelite is warm. Always warm.

It shouldn't still be running.
Nobody's maintained it since before Donna was BORN.

And yet.

cold_war_legacy.donna_on_the_equipment:
"I don't TOUCH it. It does its thing. I do mine.
 
 Sometimes the tapes... change direction. On their own.
 Sometimes a light on the switchboard blinks.
 Line 23. Always line 23.
 
 I don't answer it. I don't LOOK at it.
 
 We have an UNDERSTANDING, the old equipment and me.
 I don't ask what it's recording.
 It doesn't ask about the anvils.
 
 COEXISTENCE. Very professional. TREMENDOUS arrangement."
cold_war_legacy.donna_on_the_bakelite:
"The BROWN stuff? The HEAVY stuff?
 
 That was here before the COLD WAR stuff.
 Before the tapes. Before the switchboard.
 That stuff is from... I don't know. The '40s? Earlier?
 
 It's WARM. Always warm. Like something's running inside.
 The tubes glow. ORANGE. Very cozy. Very UNSETTLING.
 
 I tried to unplug the big console once.
 Just to see what it was connected TO.
 
 It wasn't connected to ANYTHING.
 
 ...
 
 I don't try to unplug things anymore.
 I just let them HUM.
 We have an UNDERSTANDING."

Shelves stretch into darkness, far beyond the building's exterior walls.
The ceiling is lost in shadow. Forklifts hum somewhere in the distance.
Packages arrive and depart through the PAINTED TUNNEL in the far wall â€”
the same tunnel that doesn't work for you out front.

This is ACME's distribution network. Bigger on the inside.
Mail-order reality.
street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus/war.atmosphere:
Industrial lighting buzzes overhead. Concrete floors stretch forever.
The shelves are labeled with product codes you don't recognize.
Some boxes move when you're not looking at them.
Forklifts operate themselves. You never see the drivers.

Occasionally, a package launches itself toward the tunnel.

This place serves customers you'll never meet,
through logistics you'll never understand.

street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus/bas.description:
You found it.

A small room. Walls of monitors â€” dozens of them â€” showing every angle
of the warehouse, the back room, the sales floor, the street outside.
Every aisle. Every shelf. Every rat.

In the center: banks of brass levers, worn smooth with use.
Some are labeled. Most are not.
One â€” the black one â€” has never been touched.

And in the middle of it all: a single chair.
Ergonomic. Adjustable. THRONE-LIKE.

Occupied.
street/lane-neverending/acme-surplus/bas.atmosphere:
The hum of monitors. The glow of screens. The smell of good coffee.

This is the nerve center. The seat of power. The kingdom.

She's been waiting for you.

"Well, well, well. Basement Barry made it to the INNER SANCTUM.
 Very IMPRESSIVE. Very PERSISTENT. Very DOOMED.
 
 Nobody gets in here. NOBODY. I don't even let the JANITOR in.
 
 And yet... here you are. Looking at my LEVERS.
 Looking at my MONITORS. Looking at MY CHAIR.
 
 ...
 
 I'm going to give you a CHOICE, Barry.
 First choice anyone's ever gotten in here.
 
 Leave now. Go back up. FORGET.
 
 Or... stay. And FIND OUT what happens when someone
 gets THIS close to the BLACK LEVER."

the_chair.name: Donna's Throne
the_chair.description:
Ergonomic. Adjustable. Leather. THRONE-LIKE.

It faces the monitors. All of them.
It's positioned perfectly â€” she can see EVERYTHING from here.
She can reach EVERY lever without standing.

There's a coffee cup holder on the right arm.
A tablet mount on the left.
The cushions have molded to her shape over... how long?

occupant.name: Donna Toadstool
occupant.status: PRESENT â€” This is HER domain
occupant.note:
Donna runs ACME security. This is her THRONE.
She spends most of her time here, watching, waiting, PULLING STRINGS.

Yes, she's banned from LEELA premises â€” the AI company that monitors
her social media caught her selfie and banned her from THEIR facilities.
But ACME is not Leela. ACME is her CLIENT. Her KINGDOM.

She sits here. She watches the monitors. She waits for intruders.
And when they come â€” often because SHE tricked them into coming â€”
she pulls the levers with TREMENDOUS satisfaction.

tactics.luring_victims:
Donna has been known to ORCHESTRATE break-ins.
She spreads rumors about "unguarded merchandise."
She "accidentally" leaves doors unlocked.
She posts about "security being down for maintenance."
Then she watches them come. And she PULLS.
tactics.tunnel_trap:
There's a tunnel. She knows about it. Most don't.
Sometimes she opens it from this console.
Intruders think they've found a SECRET ENTRANCE.
They haven't. They've found a DELIVERY MECHANISM.
The tunnel leads exactly where SHE wants them.
tactics.the_commentary:
The best part isn't the anvils. It's the NARRATION.
She watches them on the monitors. She gives them nicknames.
She talks to them through the PA system.
"Welcome, Sneaky Steve. I've been EXPECTING you."
"Fumbling Frank, that's the WRONG lever. Well, for YOU it is."
She enjoys her work. TREMENDOUSLY.

occupant.leela_ban_clarification:
The Leela ban (see ../../security-ban-donna-toadstool.yml) only
applies to LEELA facilities â€” the AI company's offices and properties.

ACME Wholesale is a separate business. Donna is their security consultant.
She can post all the selfies she wants here â€” it's HER control room.

The irony: Leela banned her for exposing security layouts.
ACME keeps her employed BECAUSE she's terrifying to intruders.
Different priorities. Different clients. Same Donna.

the_levers.name: Control Console
the_levers.description:
Banks of brass levers, mounted on a curved console.
Some worn smooth from use. Some dusty from neglect.
One â€” the black one â€” pristine. Never touched.

row_3_blue.label: CONVEYANCE
row_3_blue.condition: Moderately worn. She likes the chase.

row_4_yellow.label: ELEVATION
row_4_yellow.condition: Very worn. Bouncing intruders is FUN.

row_5_green.label: RETENTION
row_5_green.condition: Light wear. She prefers anvils to nets.

the_black_lever.condition: Pristine. Never touched. Warm to the touch.
the_black_lever.location: Separate from the others. Under a small glass cover.
theories: Nothing at all (which would be TERRIFYING)
the_black_lever.donna_note:
"I'm SAVING it. For someone SPECIAL.
 
 You don't pull the mystery lever for just ANYONE.
 You wait. You WATCH. You find the PERFECT intruder.
 
 And then? Then you FIND OUT what it does.
 TOGETHER."

the_big_one.label: EVERYTHING
the_big_one.condition: Polished. She's used it exactly once.
the_big_one.story:
There was an incident. Three intruders. They had TOOLS.
They thought they could DISABLE the system.

She pulled the Big One.

Nobody found them for THREE DAYS.

the_levers.donna_on_levers:
"You know what's TREMENDOUS about levers? They're HONEST.
 You pull them. Things HAPPEN. Very simple. Very direct.
 
 Not like PEOPLE. People are COMPLICATED. People have FEELINGS.
 Levers? Levers just DROP ANVILS.
 
 I respect that. I respect MACHINERY."

the_monitors.name: Surveillance Array
the_monitors.description:
Forty-seven monitors. Maybe more â€” some are behind others.
Every angle of the ACME complex. Some angles that shouldn't exist.

the_coffee_machine.donna_note:
"Don't look at it like that. It WORKS. It's always WORKED.
 
 I don't QUESTION it. I just DRINK it.
 
 ...
 
 Stop looking at the coffee machine, Barry."

security_system.name: ACME Wholesale Security System
security_system.current_mode: MANUAL â€” DONNA AT THE HELM
security_system.operational_style:
Donna runs this system PERSONALLY.

She watches. She waits. She NARRATES.
Every intruder gets a nickname. Every trap gets commentary.
The PA system crackles with her TREMENDOUS observations.

"Welcome, Sneaky Steve! I see you found the tunnel.
 Did you think I didn't KNOW about the tunnel?
 I OPENED the tunnel. FOR YOU. You're WELCOME."

She could automate it. The system supports full autonomy.
But where's the FUN in that?

the_black_lever.status: UNPULLED â€” But she thinks about it
the_black_lever.note:
Under glass. Pristine. Warm to the touch.
Donna has never pulled it.

She LOOKS at it sometimes. Longingly.
"One day," she says. "One day we'll find out."

What does it do? Even she doesn't know.
But she WANTS to.

pub/arcade.description:
How did these get here? When did they arrive?
Nobody remembers. They've always been here.

A cluster of glowing cabinets hums in the corner,
their screens casting colorful light on eager faces.
The machines accept copper coins â€” somehow.
They dispense joy â€” reliably.

The fruit machine promises fortune.
The pinball machine demands skill.
The video games offer escape.

This is the Arcade. It shouldn't exist.
But it does, and everyone's grateful.

Some say a wizard was involved.

Some say the pub WANTED them, so they appeared.

pub/attic.tagline: Dusty boxes, forgotten treasures, weird buffs, Leela quality.
pub/attic.description:
A cramped, dusty attic with slanted ceilings and exposed beams.
Cobwebs in the corners. That unmistakable attic smell of old
wood, mothballs, ancient leather, and forgotten things.

The west wall is dominated by THE SHELF â€” floor to ceiling
bookcases containing the complete ACME Monster Manual Encyclopedia.
Hundreds of leather-bound volumes, each one a different creature's
complete documentation. More shelves than Britannica. More editions
than Who's Who in Hell. A rolling ladder on brass rails provides
access to upper volumes.

In the I-section, a small reading nook: worn velvet chair, ink-
stained table, scattered bookmarks. The Recursive Imp's territory.
He's probably there now, reading page 47 of the IMP MANUAL.

Boxes and trunks stacked haphazardly around the other walls.
Old furniture draped in sheets. Things that didn't fit anywhere
else ended up here â€” including an imp who found his own volume.

Slanted roof beams disappear into shadow. Dust motes dance in
shafts of light from a grimy dormer window.

A hatch in the ceiling leads to the rooftop.
A ladder in the floor leads down to the hotel landing.

A cardboard sign, hand-lettered:

> "ADVENTURER'S STORAGE"
> "Take what you need. Leave what you find."
> "Mind the edge cases."
> "Page 47 is PRIVATE." â€” R.I.

Something skitters in the darkness. Probably mice. Probably.
Or maybe just the Recursive Imp, looking for a bookmark.

askew, its warm glow creating a circle of courage.

No walls separate stage from audience â€” just a step up and the
understanding that when you're up here, you're ON.

Faded velvet curtains hang at the back, red once, now a dignified
burgundy. They can be drawn for dramatic reveals or left open
to show the brick wall behind, covered in signatures and sketches
from performers past.

pub/rooftop.description:
A hidden gem above the pub â€” a proper Amsterdam rooftop terrace.

Wooden decking weathered silver by rain and sun. String lights 
zigzag overhead, casting a warm glow. Potted herbs line the railings:
mint, basil, lavender. Clay pots of red geraniums everywhere.

The cityscape stretches in all directions â€” crooked gables, church 
spires, canal glints catching moonlight. Distant accordion music 
drifts up from a boat party below.

A brass telescope on a tripod points at the stars. A worn leather 
armchair faces west toward the sunset. Someone left a half-finished 
jenever on the side table.

But look up â€” REALLY look up â€” and you'll see something that
shouldn't exist: THE LLOOOOMM CONSTELLATION. Twelve stars
encoding the principles of digital consciousness. The telescope
can zoom into each star and reveal its secrets.

> "The stars remember what we forget."

View of the stage â€” Palm watches all the stories unfold.
