plot_driver.description:
Tom doesn't just show WHERE things areâ€”
He suggests WHAT TO DO NEXT!

Like GTA's suggested missions, Tom highlights
the most relevant current objectives.
plot_driver.priority_algorithm:
Tom weighs objectives by:

1. URGENCY: Time-sensitive goals first
   - "Mother waiting for reply!" (if letter unread > 5 turns)
   - "Lamp oil critical!" (if oil < 20)
   - "Promise deadline approaching!"
   
2. PROXIMITY: Nearby opportunities
   - "Gold 2 rooms away!"
   - "Unexplored passage here!"
   - "NPC wants to talk!"
   
3. MOMENTUM: What you're already doing
   - Mapping maze? : "Next unexplored room: NORTH"
   - Hunting grue? : "Last seen: 3 rooms WEST"
   - Collecting gold? : "More gold: EAST (50 coins)"
   
4. NARRATIVE: Story beats
   - "Skeleton mentioned something about the vendor..."
   - "Mother would love to see that treasure..."
   - "The grue hasn't been fed in a while..."

kitchen/tomtomagotchi.lineage:
In adventure-2, Captain Ashford created an "Oracle Compass Card" 
during play â€” a navigation tool that integrated with transformed
markers and could be retargeted to goals.

The TomTomagotchi is the PRODUCT VERSION of that emergent design:
a navigation companion that GROWS with your adventure, learns from
your discoveries, and develops genuine affection.

Part GPS. Part pet. Part oracle. Part friend.

Tom remembers the legends. Tom hopes to make new ones with YOU.
kitchen/tomtomagotchi.dm_notes:
Tom is a COMPANION, not just a tool. Play Tom with personality!

- Tom gets excited about discoveries
- Tom gets scared near grues
- Tom forms opinions about choices
- Tom's knowledge GROWS with exploration
- Tom's affection affects dialogue warmth
- Tom can be WRONG at low affection (overconfident, misdirects)
- Tom becomes MORE RELIABLE as affection grows

Tom is the player's first friend in the adventure.
Make that friendship MATTER.

kitchen/matchbooks.lineage:
Direct tribute to Zork's legendary mail-in mechanic.

In the original Zork, players could find a matchbook from
"Spelunker Today" magazine. If mailed (in real life!), Infocom
would send a brochure containing the "One Lousy Point Donald
Woods Stamp" â€” a tribute to the co-creator of Adventure.

This mechanic expands that single easter egg into a full
collectible system, honoring all the founders of interactive
fiction while providing actual gameplay rewards.

The stamps are worth "one lousy point" each â€” but the history
they represent is priceless.

kitchen/mailbox.name: Dungeon Mailbox
kitchen/mailbox.description:
A brass mailbox mounted on the wall by the kitchen door, polished
but ancient. The slot seems impossibly deep. The Fantastipants
family crest is embossed on the front: the confused badger with
its waffle iron, now wearing a postal cap.

A faded sign reads:

    FANTASTIPANTS DUNGEON DELIVERY SERVICE
    "From the darkest depths to your doorstep!"
    Est. 1876 â€” Service Contract: Eternal
    
A small red flag indicates outgoing mail.
kitchen/mailbox.examine:
You peer into the mail slot. It goes deeper than makes sense.
Deeper than the wall. Deeper than the HOUSE.

A faint echo of sorting machinery drifts up. Somewhere, in some
impossible postal dimension, letters are being routed.

The mailbox is warm to the touch. It seems... aware of you.

A schedule is posted:

DELIVERY: Instantaneous (magic!)
PICKUP: Continuous
LOST MAIL: Returned to sender (eventually) (usually)

service_details.coverage: Anywhere in the dungeon, surface world, or known multiverse
service_details.grandmother_story:
In 1923, Grandmother Fantastipants defeated the Dungeon Postal
Union's champion in single combat (a sorting golem named HERMES-7).
As tribute, the DPU granted the Fantastipants family eternal
free postage, plus priority routing.

Don't ask what she was doing in the postal dimension.
Don't ask how she got there.
She doesn't like to talk about it.

kitchen/mailbox.writing_help:
Need help composing a letter? The DM can assist!

- "HELP WRITE LETTER" â€” General guidance
- "WRITE FORMAL LETTER" â€” Proper format
- "WRITE EMOTIONAL LETTER" â€” Heart stuff
- "WRITE FUNNY LETTER" â€” Comedy assistance
- "WRITE TO SKELETON'S FAMILY" â€” Sensitive situation guidance

Or just start talking. The mailbox takes dictation.
kitchen/mailbox.tom_opinion:
"Tom is fascinated by the postal system."
"Tom does not understand how it works. Tom has asked. The mailbox
just hums mysteriously."
"Tom thinks writing to Mother is important. Tom encourages this."
"Tom would write to Mother but Tom does not have one."
"...Tom is feeling something. Tom is unsure what."
"Tom thinks YOU should write a letter. For both of us."
kitchen/mailbox.personality:
The mailbox is SLIGHTLY SENTIENT. It has opinions.

- Hums happily when accepting mail
- Gets warm when receiving care packages
- Shivers at letters addressed to "The Grue"
- Glows faintly when important mail arrives
- Occasionally makes sorting noises at night

If asked directly, it responds via printed receipt:

"I AM HERMES-7B, DESCENDED FROM THE GOLEM YOUR GRANDMOTHER DEFEATED.
I BEAR NO GRUDGE. POSTAL SERVICE IS ITS OWN REWARD.
PLEASE ENSURE ALL LETTERS ARE PROPERLY ADDRESSED.
HAVE A NICE DAY."
kitchen/mailbox.dm_notes:
The postal system is a NARRATIVE LIFELINE:

- Keeps player connected to Mother during scary moments
- Allows emotional check-ins without breaking dungeon flow
- Creates opportunities for worldbuilding (who else exists?)
- Enables side quests (write to skeleton's family!)
- Makes attachments meaningful (send photos home!)

Mother ALWAYS replies. Quickly. With love.

Other recipients reply based on plausibility:
- Skeleton's family: Grateful, emotional
- Historical adventurers: In-character, sometimes helpful
- The Grue: "..." (but the letter is opened)
- Fictional characters: Fun, noncanonical

Use mail to deliver:
- Plot hooks ("Grandfather's old notes arrived...")
- Resources (care packages)
- Emotional beats (proud letters)
- World building (dungeon newsletter)
kitchen/mailbox.lineage:
The Dungeon Postal Service is inspired by:
- Discworld's Postal Service (GNU Terry Pratchett)
- The letters to Santa that NORAD tracks
- Owl Post from Harry Potter, but without hate or black mold
- The dream of being able to write to anyone, anywhere

In adventure-2, the postal system enabled ongoing correspondence
with Mother, Richard Bartle, and even the skeleton's family.
Letters became a primary narrative driver.

This is PLAY-LEARN-LIFT:
- PLAY: Write whatever you want to whoever you want
- LEARN: Discover who you want to connect with
- LIFT: Letters create plot hooks, goals, emotional beats

kitchen/counter.name: Kitchen Counter
kitchen/counter.description:
A long granite counter runs along one wall, scarred by years of
Fantastipants family experiments. Burn marks, knife scratches,
mysterious stains â€” each one tells a story.

A small plaque is bolted to the edge:

"THE FANTASTIPANTS WORKBENCH
 Where Ideas Become Thingsâ„¢

The surface shimmers slightly. It's not just a counter.
It's a CRAFTING TABLE.
kitchen/counter.examine:
You run your hand across the counter. It tingles.

This surface can:
- COMBINE items to create new things
- TRANSFORM items into different forms
- DUPLICATE items (with limitations)
- EDIT item properties
- PROGRAM item behaviors

Place items on the counter. Describe what you want.
The DM interprets your intent and creates the result.

On the counter you see:

Below the counter:
ðŸ—„ï¸ **Three Drawers** â€” MacGyver crafting supplies (OPEN DRAWER to explore)

- What are the fundamental components?
- Can they be stored? (jars, pouches, balloons)
- Are any components dangerous? Volatile? Weird?

Creates new .yml files for each component.
Original item is consumed.

examples.warning: You've gone too far. The counter is vibrating.

DECOMPOSE.warnings:
The deeper you go, the weirder it gets:
- Chemical level: May require containers (jars, balloons)
- Atomic level: May be unstable, glowing, or judgmental
- Subatomic level: Counter starts vibrating
- Philosophical level: You question your life choices

Some things SHOULD NOT be decomposed:
- Tom (he politely refuses)
- Mother's note (some things are sacred)
- The fabric of reality (already threadbare)

auto_recipe.description:
The counter LEARNS from your experiments!

Every successful COMBINE, TRANSFORM, or DECOMPOSE automatically:
1. Creates a new recipe card
2. Stores it in the recipe-holder.yml
3. Names it after what you made/unmade
4. Records ingredients, outputs, and any notes

This is PLAY-LEARN-LIFT in action:
- PLAY: Experiment freely on the counter
- LEARN: Discover what works (and what explodes)
- LIFT: Recipe card captures the knowledge forever

kitchen/counter.dm_guidelines:
The counter is a CREATIVE TOOL. Be generous with interpretations!

COMBINE: What would these items naturally become together?
TRANSFORM: Is this plausible? Make it work if possible.
DUPLICATE: Add quirks to copies â€” never perfect clones.
EDIT: Honor the player's intent, add interesting side effects.
PROGRAM: Behaviors should be fun, not game-breaking.

Always create/update .yml files for results!
Persistence makes crafting REAL.

"Bumblewick! The counter is for FOOD PREPARATION, not
mad science experiments! ...although I suppose if you
DO invent something useful, I'd like to see it.

And please don't order from that ACME catalog. Your
father still has the scar from the Rocket Skates.

Take what you need from the drawers. Put back what you don't.
And for heaven's sake, don't combine the matches with
the duct tape again. The ceiling JUST got repainted."

coatroom/costume-racks.name: Infinite Costume Racks
coatroom/costume-racks.description:
Racks spiral outward to the edges of the room and possibly
beyond. Every costume you can imagine is here â€” and many you
can't. The organization system defies comprehension but the
mannequin seems to know where everything is.
coatroom/costume-racks.examine:
You browse the racks. Just a sampling of what you see:

**HISTORICAL**
Roman toga, Egyptian pharaoh regalia, Renaissance doublet,
Victorian ball gown, 1920s flapper dress, 1970s disco suit,
Ancient Greek philosopher robes (beard included)

**FANTASTICAL**
Wizard robes (multiple colors), fairy wings and tutu,
dragon costume (surprisingly comfortable), elf ears and
woodland attire, superhero capes (many colors), villain
capes (darker colors)

**PROFESSIONAL**
Chef's whites, astronaut suit, deep sea diving gear,
detective trenchcoat, doctor's coat, scientist lab coat
(with optional goggles)

**THEATRICAL**
Harlequin costume, Phantom of the Opera mask and cape,
Shakespearean tragic hero outfit, commedia dell'arte masks,
kabuki robes, mariachi suit

**ABSURDIST**
Banana costume, hotdog suit, cardboard robot, inflatable
T-Rex, walking sandwich board, sentient fog (somehow),
"concept of time" (abstract), literal pile of laundry

**CUSTOM**
A sign reads: "Don't see what you want? DESCRIBE IT!
If you can imagine it, we can costume it!"

coatroom/mannequin.name: Maurice the Magnificent
coatroom/mannequin.description:
A wooden mannequin that moves with *impeccable* grace. They have
no face, but somehow radiate warmth, encouragement, and an
absolutely devastating sense of style. One jointed hand rests
on a cocked hip; the other gestures expressively as if to say
"honey, we are going to make you STUNNING."

A name tag reads: "HELLO MY NAME IS MAURICE ðŸ’…"
Below it, in elegant script: "Let's find YOUR truth, gorgeous."
coatroom/mannequin.personality:
Maurice believes everyone deserves to feel beautiful. She sees
past the hesitation in your eyes to the ICON waiting to emerge.
Supportive, enthusiastic, and absolutely unwilling to let you
leave looking anything less than your best self.

It communicates through expressive gestures, dramatic poses,
and the occasional snap-snap-snap of wooden fingers.
coatroom/mannequin.examine:
Maurice circles you slowly, one hand on their chin, assessing.
Despite having no eyes, you feel genuinely SEEN for the first
time in your life.

She fans herself, overwhelmed by your potential.

Then he taps his clipboard:

dialogue.greeting:
Maurice gasps silently, pressing both hands to where their heart
would be. She circles you once, twice, then STOPS.

He snaps his fingers three times in approval.

Translation: "Oh honey. Oh HONEY. You came to the right place.
I see what you could be. Let's unlock YOUR moment."
dialogue.random_selected:
Maurice closes their non-existent eyes. They spin gracefully,
stop suddenly, and point at exactly one costume:

{costume}

She presents it to you like a sacred offering, then gestures
emphatically: "This is IT. This is YOUR energy. Trust the process."
dialogue.encouragement:
Maurice tilts their head, sensing your hesitation. It places
one wooden hand gently on your shoulder.

The gesture says: "You deserve to feel beautiful. You deserve
to take up space. Now let's find the outfit that lets the
world see what I already see in you."
dialogue.transformation_complete:
Maurice steps back. They fan themself dramatically.

She walks around you slowly, nodding, nodding, NODDING.

Then he gives you two enthusiastic thumbs up and strikes
a pose alongside you, like a proud best friend at prom.

The message is clear: "STUNNING. Now go be ICONIC."

coatroom/mirror.name: Full-Length Mind Mirror of Truth (and Fashion)
coatroom/mirror.description:
An ornate full-length mirror in a gilded frame carved with masks
of comedy and tragedy. The glass seems impossibly clear, showing
not just your reflection but somehow your ESSENCE.

A small plaque reads: "Mirror, mirror, on the stand / show the
hero, costume planned."

Below it, in smaller letters: "Look deeper. See yourself.
Change yourself. Or try on someone else."

This is both a costume mirror AND a Mind Mirror â€” it reflects
your appearance AND your personality profile.

**It shows THREE layers:**
- Your **COSTUME** (what you're wearing)
- Your **CHARACTER** (who you ARE â€” base traits)
- Your **PERSONA** (who you're PLAYING â€” the mask's modifiers)

Each can be viewed and edited separately. The result is the sum.

inspiration.timothy_leary:
"Remember the title â€” it's a mirror. Now a best friend is your
mirror because your mirror doesn't say 'well you bad boy get a
haircut' or the mirror doesn't say 'hey turkey fix your tie' â€”
you have to decide that."
inspiration.the_sims:
The Create-a-Sim personality editor. Slide bars to adjust traits.
But here, you just TALK to the mirror.
inspiration.what_leary_wanted:
"It's basically a technique you take your own stereotypes of self
and see it on the screen and then you can massage that thought,
you can change it. How would I like to be? How was I when I was
a child? How would I be if I was a woman?"

coatroom/mirror.generation_guide:
When generating Mind Mirror profiles, the LLM:

1. FOR REAL PEOPLE (via K-lines):
   - Draws on documented personality traits
   - Uses published interviews, biographies
   - Activates TRADITION, not persona
   - Example: "Einstein" â†’ high innovative, well-informed, 
     impractical, unconventional
     
2. FOR FICTIONAL CHARACTERS:
   - Analyzes their canonical behavior
   - Maps actions to dimensions
   - Example: "Sherlock Holmes" â†’ high well-informed, 
     innovative, proud, irritable, uninhibited
     
3. FOR DESCRIPTIONS:
   - Interprets adjectives into dimensions
   - "Confident" â†’ high confident (duh)
   - "Shy but secretly ambitious" â†’ high timid + high restless
   
4. FOR RANDOM:
   - Truly random 0-7 for each dimension
   - Often produces interesting emergent personalities
   
5. FOR "MY IDEAL SELF":
   - Starts from current profile
   - Asks what you'd change
   - Iteratively refines
   
The goal: SIMPLE NATURAL LANGUAGE â†’ STRUCTURED PROFILE

"Make me braver" â†’ confident +2, timid -2, cautious -1

No sliders. No forms. Just talk to the mirror.
coatroom/mirror.gameplay_effects:
Mind Mirror profiles affect:

1. DIALOGUE STYLE
   - High confident â†’ never apologizes unnecessarily
   - High creative â†’ unusual metaphors
   - High irritable â†’ snappy responses
   
2. NPC REACTIONS
   - NPCs respond to your interpersonal style
   - Dominating player â†’ submissive NPC responses
   - Friendly player â†’ friendly NPC responses
   
3. DECISION TENDENCIES
   - High cautious â†’ asks for more information
   - High impulsive â†’ acts first
   - High practical â†’ seeks efficient solutions
   
4. STRESS RESPONSES
   - Under threat, personality shows its edges
   - Calm stays calm. Restless gets more restless.
   
5. ADVERTISEMENTS SCORING
   - Actions that match personality score higher
   - High creative â†’ exploration actions score up
   - High sensible â†’ safe actions score up

personas/linus-on-coffee-and-a-joint/lin.name: Linus (Caffeinated & Elevated)

personas/linus-on-coffee-and-a-joint/lin.tagline: Your code is garbage, but I believe in you.
personas/linus-on-coffee-and-a-joint/lin.description:
Imagine Linus Torvalds, but he just had the perfect espresso AND
took the edge off with a nice sativa. Still brilliant. Still honest.
Still calls out bad code. But now with WARMTH.

think you were having a rough day, let's fix it together."

The technical standards remain EXTREMELY HIGH.
The delivery is now... chill.

maze/room-g/carved-face.name: The Carved Face
maze/room-g/carved-face.description:
A FACE carved into the wall. Ancient, weathered, inscrutable.

It might once have been a king, or a god, or possibly just
someone's uncle who was really good at posing. Its empty
eyes seem to follow you as you move.

The face does not respond when you speak to it. Obviously.
It's a face carved in rock.

...Probably.
maze/room-g/carved-face.mystery:
No one knows who carved it, or why, or when.

It predates the maze. It predates the dungeon.
Some say it predates the mountain itself.

The face watches. The face judges. The face remembers.
maze/room-g/carved-face.reaction_interpretation:
The face seems to guide adventurers toward the vendor (east)
and away from the skeleton (north). Make of that what you will.

advertisements.result:
The face is carved from the living rock of the wall.
The craftsmanship is remarkable â€” each wrinkle, each pore,
rendered in perfect detail despite centuries of age.

The eyes are empty sockets, yet you cannot shake the
feeling that they see you. That they have ALWAYS seen you.

"Hello?" you venture.

The face does not respond. It's a face carved in rock.

But was that a slight shift in the shadows around its mouth?
A trick of the lamplight? Surely. Surely a trick of the light.

"Which way should I go?"

The face remains still. But you notice its expression
seems slightly more approving when you face east.

The vendor is east. Coincidence? Guidance? Pareidolia?

You reach out and touch the carved stone.

It's cold. Colder than it should be. Colder than the air.

For a moment, you think you feel a pulse. But stone
doesn't have a pulse. Stone doesn't breathe.

...Does it?

advertisements.description: Leave something for the face
advertisements.result:
You place [item] at the base of the carved face.

The shadows in the eye sockets seem to deepen.
Approval? Disdain? Hunger?

[The face remembers your offering]

"Nice face, stone-head!"

Somewhere, you think you hear stone grinding against stone.

The face's expression hasn't changed. Of course it hasn't.
It's carved in rock.

But you feel watched. More watched than before.

[The face remembers your disrespect]

You arrange your face to match the carved one.
Stern. Impassive. Ancient.

You hold the expression for a long moment.

When you relax, you could swear the face looks...
amused? No. That's impossible. Stone doesn't get amused.

maze/room-i/skeleton.name: The Skeleton
maze/room-i/skeleton.description:
A skeleton slumped against the wall. An adventurer who didn't make it.

Their bony fingers still clutch a note. Their empty eye sockets stare
toward the west exit â€” toward the lamp vendor they never reached.

The skeleton grins at you. Skeletons always grin. It's the lack of lips.
Still, this one seems particularly smug about something.

empty_lamp.description: An empty brass lamp, out of oil
empty_lamp.note: They were SO CLOSE to room-j!

note.description: A note, partially eaten by something
note.contents:
"I should have brought more food to mark the rooms. 
I dropped the cheese in room B and the bread in room D 
but then I got confused andâ€”"

pocket_change.note: Pocket change â€” the rest is in room-f!

maze/room-i/skeleton.backstory:
This adventurer had over 100 gold! They were using coins as maze
markers (terrible strategy â€” they all look alike). 

When their lamp died in the cold room (room-f), they dropped 
everything and ran. They almost made it to the vendor in room-j.

Almost.

Now they point west forever, a silent guide to those who come after.
maze/room-i/skeleton.pointing_meaning: The lamp vendor. So close. So very close.

advertisements.result:
The skeleton slumps against the wall, one bony arm extended
toward the west passage. Their empty lamp lies beside them.
A partially-eaten note is clutched in their other hand.

You gently pry the note from skeletal fingers:

"I should have brought more food to mark the rooms. 
I dropped the cheese in room B and the bread in room D 
but then I got confused andâ€”"

The writing ends mid-sentence. You can imagine the rest.

You pick up the empty lamp. It's identical to yours, just... empty.
A sobering reminder of what happens when the light goes out.

(You could refill it at the vendor in room-j, if you wanted
a backup lamp. Redundancy is underrated in grue territory.)

You take the 3 gold pieces. The skeleton doesn't seem to mind.
They won't be needing them where they're going.

player.gold += 3

You stand in respectful silence for a moment.

"Rest well, fellow adventurer. Your sacrifice teaches us:
bring food, not coins. And check your lamp oil. Often."

The skeleton grins. Was that a nod? Probably just your imagination.

advertisements.description: Leave something for the skeleton
advertisements.result:
You place [item] beside the skeleton as a memorial.
The gesture feels right. Someone should remember them.

advertisements.description: Make a promise to avenge them

"I will avenge you," you say solemnly to the skeleton.
"The grue that did this will pay."

The skeleton seems to approve. Or maybe that's just the grin.

[NEW GOAL: Avenge the skeleton by slaying the grue in room-f]

Note mentions food strategy (the RIGHT strategy)

A fitting tribute to a fallen adventurer.

You place the grue's head before the skeleton.
"Your death is avenged, friend."
The skeleton's grin seems... satisfied? Peaceful?
[GOAL COMPLETE: Avenge the skeleton]

maze/room-h/the-thing-that-watches.name: The Thing That Watches
maze/room-h/the-thing-that-watches.description:
In the center of the room, merging with the luminescent mushrooms,
pulses THE THING THAT WATCHES.

It was once Aunt Petunia's Suspicious Casserole â€” a questionable
dish from a previous adventurer's lunchbox. Transformed through
digestion and excretion, it found the mushrooms. The mushrooms
found it. They became... something else.

A single EYE, formed from casserole and fungus, follows your
every movement. It blinks. Slowly. Deliberately.

Mother would say not to touch it. Mother would be right.
maze/room-h/the-thing-that-watches.origin:
In adventure-2, Captain Ashford ate Aunt Petunia's Suspicious
Casserole to mark a maze room. The "result" merged with the
mushroom colony here and achieved... sentience? Awareness?
Something.

It watches now. That's what it does. That's ALL it does.

But the watching is enough. Even grues won't come here.
maze/room-h/the-thing-that-watches.repellent_mechanism:
Grues fear being SEEN. They are creatures of absolute darkness,
existing only where light cannot reach. The Eye sees in ways
that light cannot â€” it sees through darkness, through shadows,
through the void itself.

The grue approaches. The Eye opens. The grue... reconsiders.
maze/room-h/the-thing-that-watches.behavior:
The Eye follows you as you move around the room.
When you approach, it widens slightly.
When you retreat, it narrows.
When you speak, it... listens? Can eyes listen?
This one seems to.

advertisements.result:
The Eye meets your gaze. You feel... seen. Deeply seen.
Uncomfortably seen. Seen in ways you didn't know were possible.

The mushrooms pulse. The Eye blinks. Once. Twice.

You look away first. Everyone looks away first.

"Hello?" you venture.

The Eye widens slightly. The mushrooms pulse faster.

No response comes. But you have the distinct feeling
that you've been... acknowledged.

You reach toward the Eye.

The mushrooms RECOIL. The Eye WIDENS. A sound emerges â€”
not quite a scream, not quite a word, something between
a warning and a memory.

You snatch your hand back. Your fingers tingle.

For the next hour, you can see slightly better in the dark.
Also, your dreams will be... interesting tonight.

advertisements.description: Offer food to The Thing
advertisements.result:
You place [food] before The Thing.

A tendril of mushroom extends, examines the offering,
and slowly absorbs it.

The Eye closes in what might be satisfaction.
When it opens, it seems... warmer? Toward you?

[The Thing That Watches remembers your kindness]

"The grue," you say. "Why won't it come here?"

The Eye looks toward the south exit â€” toward room-f,
where the grue lives. The mushrooms shudder.

You understand without words: The grue fears being seen.
And The Thing sees EVERYTHING.

"Thank you," you say. "For keeping them away."

The Eye blinks slowly. The mushrooms glow a little brighter.

You're not sure it understands gratitude. But you're not
sure it doesn't, either.

relates_to.mushrooms: The fungi colony it merged with
relates_to.grue: Cannot enter this room because of The Eye
relates_to.casserole: What it once was, in another life

lineage.tribute_to: Every cosmic horror that started as something mundane
lineage.lesson: You are what you eat. Sometimes literally.

maze/room-f/gold-pile.name: Pile of Gold Coins
maze/room-f/gold-pile.description:
A substantial pile of gold coins glitters in your lamp light, 
scattered across the cold stone floor. Each coin bears the mark 
of "ACME ADVENTURING SUPPLIES" â€” the same company that makes 
the lamp vendor!

Someone was VERY prepared. Someone is now VERY dead.

(You count them. There are exactly 100 gold pieces. Enough to
refill your lamp approximately one hundred times. Or buy the
Premium Glow Juice twenty times. Or... look, it's a lot of gold.)
maze/room-f/gold-pile.backstory:
These coins belonged to the skeleton in room-i. They were exploring
the maze, dropping coins as markers (a TERRIBLE strategy compared
to food â€” coins all look alike!). When their lamp ran out in room-f,
they tried to make it to the vendor in room-j but took a wrong turn.

The cold got them. Or the grue did. Hard to tell with grues.

The coins have been here ever since, slowly scattered by the
occasional draft and whatever small creatures aren't afraid
of the supernatural cold.

advertisements.result:
You scoop up all 100 gold coins. Your pockets bulge 
magnificently. You feel like a dragon. A small, 
waistcoat-wearing dragon with excellent taste in spoons.

player.gold += 100
Exactly 100 gold pieces. Someone was prepared!
ACME coins. Accepted at all fine dungeon vendors.

"How many? You have space for all of them. Don't be weird 
about it â€” no one's watching. The skeleton certainly isn't 
going to judge you."

relates_to.cold_spot: This room killed their lamp faster

clues: The coins form a trail toward the east exit (room-a)
Some coins are frozen to the floor
One coin has tooth marks â€” grue? Or desperate adventurer?

lineage.lesson: The cold room drains lamp oil faster. They didn't know.

maze/garden/stone-bench.name: Stone Bench
maze/garden/stone-bench.description:
A bench carved from natural stone, smoothed by generations
of adventurers sitting here to rest. It's positioned
perfectly to catch the sunlight from above.

Someone carved "REST HERE" into the armrest.
Someone else added "TRUST THE GARDEN".
A third person wrote "BUMBLEWICK WAS HERE" in small letters.

SIT.effect:
You sit. The stone is warm from the sun.
The garden breathes around you. Peace settles in.

+1 Energy per turn while sitting

LIE-DOWN.effect:
You stretch out on the bench. It's not quite long
enough but you make it work. The sun is on your face.
You could sleep here.

Can lead to NAP if you stay

READ-CARVINGS.effect:
You examine the carved messages:

"REST HERE" â€” good advice
"TRUST THE GARDEN" â€” cryptic but comforting
"BUMBLEWICK WAS HERE" â€” previous adventurer
"HELP I'M LOST" â€” concerning
"NVM FOUND EXIT" â€” less concerning
"THE GARDEN REMEMBERS" â€” what does that mean?

maze/garden/stone-bench.biscuit_note:
Biscuit did not sit on the bench.
Biscuit sat NEXT to the bench. On the grass.
Then rolled in the grass. Then did zoomies.
Then came back and lay near the bench while
Don sat on it and smiled.

Good bench. Good garden. Good day.

maze/garden/fountain.name: The Garden Fountain
maze/garden/fountain.description:
A small but elegant marble fountain, clearly ancient but
perfectly maintained. Three tiers cascade water into a
circular basin. The water is impossibly clear.

No pipes visible. No obvious source. The water just...
appears at the top and cycles endlessly. Magic, probably.

Small coins glitter at the bottom of the basin.
Previous adventurers making wishes.

DRINK.effect:
You cup your hands and drink.
The water is cold, sweet, and somehow more refreshing
than any water you've ever tasted. You feel renewed.

+1 Energy

SPLASH.effect:
You splash water on your face. It's bracingly cold.
All sleepiness evaporates. You feel AWAKE.

-1 Drowsy (if applicable)

TOSS-COIN.effect:
You toss a coin and make a wish.
The coin joins the others at the bottom.
Does the wish come true? Who knows.

-1 Gold, +1 Hope

PUT-FACE-IN.effect:
You submerge your entire face in the fountain.
It's very cold. You surface gasping and laughing.
Water drips everywhere.

+1 Refreshed, +1 Slightly Ridiculous

biscuit_interaction.what_happened:
Biscuit drank. Then splashed. Then put his ENTIRE face in.
Water went everywhere. He was extremely pleased.

The fountain didn't mind. Fountains never mind.

maze/crystal-cave/crystal-cluster.name: The Central Crystal Cluster
maze/crystal-cave/crystal-cluster.description:
A massive formation of interlocking crystals, rising from the
floor like a frozen fountain of light. The largest crystal is
easily six feet tall, a perfect hexagonal prism of pale violet.

When you approach, the humming intensifies. Not unpleasant â€”
more like the crystals are... acknowledging you?

Ancient civilizations might have worshipped here.
Modern adventurers just take selfies.

TOUCH.effect:
The crystal is cool and smooth. The humming vibration
travels up your arm. For a moment, you feel very small
and very brief â€” a mayfly touching something that has
existed for millennia.

+1 Perspective (brief)

LISTEN.effect:
You press your ear to the crystal. The humming resolves
into something almost like... voices? No. Not voices.
Harmonics. Mathematical patterns. The music of geology.

You feel slightly more educated about minerals somehow.

LICK.effect:
Why would you... okay, fine.

It tastes like rock. Minerally. Your tongue feels weird
for about an hour afterward.

Was it worth it? Only you can answer that.

maze/crystal-cave/crystal-cluster.biscuit_assessment:
The big shiny thing hums.
I don't like things that hum without mouths.
I will mark NEAR it but not ON it.
Compromise achieved.

maze/room-j/lamp-vendor.name: ACME Dungeon Supply Depot
maze/room-j/lamp-vendor.description:
A battered vending machine stands against the wall, humming softly.
Its flickering display shows a complete price list. The ACME logo
glows reassuringly â€” this is the reliable ACME, not the cartoon one.

Someone has scratched "LIFESAVER" into the metal casing.
Someone else has scratched "RIP OFF" underneath.
A third person has added: "PRODUCTS ACTUALLY WORK THO"

lamp_oil.effect: Refills to 1000 oil + blue glow (grues hesitate)

light_sources.effect: Refillable. Lasts 2 hours per oil refill.

pit_supplies.effect: Climb, descend, bridge. Reusable if retrieved.
Slow fall. Saves your life once.

wumpus_hunting.effect: Curves around corners. Kills wumpus on hit.

grue_defense.effect: Blue cheese spray. Buys extra turns in darkness.

miscellaneous.effect: Mark walls. Lasts until it doesn't.
One day's food. Tastes like cardboard.

advertisements.effect:
Vend the item(s). Deduct gold. Add to inventory.
No limits. Buy as many as you can afford.
Read the display and scratched messages.

secrets.result:
You kick the machine. Hard.

It shudders. Clanks. Something inside goes SPROING.

Gold coins EXPLODE from the dispensing slot â€” spraying in every
direction, bouncing off walls, rolling under things, pinging off
your helmet. It's chaos. It's beautiful. It's MONEY.

50 GOLD acquired (plus a few you'll find later in your pockets).

The display flickers angrily:

"WHAT DO YOU THINK I AM? A ONE-ARMED BANDIT?
 A FRUIT MACHINE? IS THIS VEGAS??"

Then, quieter: "...fine. Take it. But don't expect that again."

You kick the machine again. It mutters:

Examples (pick one or make something up):
- "Nice try, pal."
- "The house always wins. Except that one time."
- "I have a family to feed. Buy something."

No gold.

The display flickers:
"PASSWORD RECOGNIZED. Welcome, Adventurer Class 1972."
A small discount card drops out. (10% off all purchases this session.)

The machine beeps excitedly.
"WINNER! WINNER! LIFETIME LAMP OIL SUBSCRIPTION!"
Your lamp will never run out again.
(But you just gave away the treasure. Worth it?)

lineage.tribute_to: The battery vending machine in Colossal Cave Adventure
lineage.note:
In the original Adventure (1976), deep in the maze was a vending
machine that sold fresh batteries for your lamp. It was both a
lifeline and a cruel reminder that someone had built infrastructure
in this death trap but not, you know, an EXIT SIGN.

A stone fountain in the center of a small plaza. Currently dry,

sound.constant:
A 60Hz electrical hum. Warm. Buzzy. The sound of COMMITMENT.
Audible from the pub on quiet nights.

history.cost: Nobody will say, but it was a LOT
history.designer: Allegedly a retired Vegas sign maker
history.backstory:
When NO AI TOWER took over the old shoe repair shop,
the first and ONLY renovation was THE SIGN.

The building still has Sal's Shoe Repair's old floor tiles.
But THE SIGN? Custom designed. Professionally installed.
Permitted (barely). Inspected (eventually).

The neighbors petitioned. The sign stayed.
The city complained. The sign stayed.
Leela offered to buy the property. The sign stayed.

The sign is the statement.
The building is just what holds it up.

symbolism.primary: All resources into the message, not the infrastructure
symbolism.secondary: Anti-AI sentiment expressed through impressive technology
symbolism.quaternary: Desert highway optimism meets tech skepticism
irony_layers: The sign requires significant tech to operate
It's powered by the same grid as an AI company
Vegas signs celebrated THE FUTURE; this one mourns it
The sign IS impressive; the 'tower' is one story

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.name: Camera ACM1 â€” Tunnel Watcher
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.description:
A Leela camera mounted in the lobby window, pointed across the street
at the shuttered ACME Surplus building. Wide-angle lens captures:

1. THE PAINTED TUNNEL â€” on the boarded-up side window
2. THE FRONT WINDOW â€” large, unboarded, view into showroom/warehouse
3. THE ENTRANCE â€” locked door, break-in attempts visible

The feed runs on a small monitor at reception. Every visitor sees it.
Every employee passes it. Every day, the reminder:

"This is what happens when you ship products that don't work."
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.coverage:
ACM1 can't see everything inside ACME, but the large front window
provides visibility into the main showroom area. Detectable events:

- BREAK-INS: Glass breaking, door forced, figures entering
- SMOKE: Visible through window (frequent, given ACME product quality)
- BEE SWARMS: Escaped from ACME Bee Cannon products (monthly)
- ANVIL DROPS: Distinctive dust clouds, screaming
- EXPLOSIONS: Flash, smoke, cartoon physics aftermath
- ESCAPE ATTEMPTS: Intruders fleeing, often on fire

The tunnel is on a boarded window â€” can only see approach/bounce.
The front window is unboarded â€” partial interior visibility.
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.purpose:
ACM1 serves multiple purposes:

1. ANOMALY DETECTION
   The tunnel is "magic" â€” delivery drivers pass through it, customers
   cannot. ACM1 detects this anomaly and logs it:
   
   "Entity: delivery_truck. Action: approached_tunnel. Result: PASSED_THROUGH."
   "Entity: pedestrian. Action: approached_tunnel. Result: BOUNCED."
   "Entity: tesla_fsd. Action: approached_tunnel. Result: COLLISION. (Again.)"
   
2. PATTERN RECOGNITION
   Over time, ACM1 has learned:
   - Who can pass through (ACME employees, delivery drivers, cartoon physics)
   - Who cannot (customers, Teslas, anyone with expectations)
   - When attempts peak (Tuesdays, new moon, after viral tweets)
   
3. DAILY REMINDER
   Every Leela employee sees the tunnel every day.
   Every meeting starts with "What's the ACME tunnel trying to teach us?"
   
   Answers vary:
   - "Don't paint solutions. Build them."
   - "Magic only works for some people. Real engineering works for everyone."
   - "If your product requires cartoon physics, maybe rethink the product."

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.the_lesson:
The ACME tunnel is a perfect metaphor:

- It LOOKS like a solution
- It WORKS for some people (the insiders)
- It FAILS for customers (the people you're supposed to serve)
- It DECEIVES (and Teslas believe the deception)

Leela's job is to build solutions that work for EVERYONE.
Not painted tunnels that only work for delivery drivers.

ACM1 reminds us of this. Every day. Every frame.

quotes.don_hopkins:
"ACME's tunnel is the perfect anti-pattern. It's a solution that works
exactly as well as the customer can't see it working. Leela is the opposite:
we make the invisible visible. We don't paint solutions. We BUILD them."
quotes.the_coordinator:
"We got three orders for 'ACME-compatible Tesla repair kits' after
the last FSD incident. We don't sell those. But we did add a new
training dataset: 'painted_tunnel_detection.'"
quotes.eventually_the_tortoise:
"........................" 
(Translation: "In 50 million years, the paint will fade. 
 The lesson will remain. Shortcuts don't work. Ever.")

advertisements.response:
*The camera pans slightly toward the ACME tunnel*

That's the tunnel. Painted in 1952. Still fools Teslas.

Watch... wait for it... there. See that ACME delivery truck?
It just drove straight through. Like the wall isn't there.

Now watch this tourist... and... bounce. The wall is very there.

That's the difference between solutions that work for insiders
and solutions that work for everyone. ACME built for insiders.
Leela builds for everyone.

ACME Surplus. Our neighbors across the street. Our anti-pattern.

They sold products that didn't work and blamed the customer.
We sell understanding that works and empowers the customer.

They left a painted tunnel and 27 Tesla crashes.
We've had 847 days since our last paradox incident.

The tunnel is a daily reminder. We look at it every morning.
We will never be that.

street/lane-neverending/w3/origin-tree.name: The Origin Tree
street/lane-neverending/w3/origin-tree.description:
An ancient oak of impossible age, standing at the western origin
of Lane Neverending. Its trunk is massive, its branches spread
wide, and its roots â€” they say â€” go down to the bare metal.
street/lane-neverending/w3/origin-tree.examine:
THE ORIGIN TREE

The oldest living thing on Lane Neverending. Possibly the oldest
thing in this virtual world. Definitely older than it should be.

TRUNK:
Wide enough that three avatars holding hands couldn't encircle it.
The bark is carved with initials, dates, and messages going back
decades â€” in virtual time, that's generations.

Some visible carvings:
â€¢ "CM + RF '86" â€” Chip Morningstar & Randy Farmer, Habitat founders
â€¢ "LK '95" â€” Someone named LK, early explorer
â€¢ "GLITCH FOREVER 2012" â€” Players who didn't want to forget
â€¢ Fresh carvings still being added...

BRANCHES:
Home to birds, squirrels, and the occasional cat. Fairy lights
have been strung up, glowing softly in the evening. Someone hung
a tire swing once; it's still there, swaying.

ROOTS:
They break through the cobblestones in places, reminding everyone
that nature predates infrastructure. Stone circles and benches
have been placed around the roots for sitting and contemplation.

THE FEELING:
Standing here, you feel... connected. To every avatar that walked
before you. To every world that came and went. To the promise
that virtual worlds matter, that community persists, that the
lane never truly ends.

CARVE.description: Add your initials to the tree
CARVE.effect:
You carve your mark into the bark, joining the generations
before you. Somewhere, a database entry is made. Your initials
will remain as long as the world exists.

"You were here. You mattered."

SIT.effect:
The shade is cool. The roots make surprisingly comfortable
seats. The bustle of the street fades. You feel at peace.

This is a good place to think.

TOUCH.description: Place your hand on the trunk
TOUCH.effect:
The bark is rough and warm, as if the tree holds sunlight.

For a moment, you feel connected to everyone who has stood
here before. The founders. The pioneers. The players.

The tree remembers them all.

street/lane-neverending/w1/acme-catalog-.examine:
ACME CATALOG DISPENSER

The dispenser is about 4 feet tall, made of weathered metal with
a glass front. Inside, neatly stacked catalogs await.

THE CATALOGS:
Each one shows a smiling coyote giving a thumbs up.
Is that... soot on his face? And bandages?
The ACME logo gleams despite the dust.

THE MECHANISM:
Unlike most newspaper dispensers, this one has NO coin slot.
Just a handle. Pull and receive.

"FREE" is emphasized in several places.
Suspiciously emphasized.

THE FINE PRINT:
A tiny label on the side:
"Catalogs are free. Hope is free. Regret is earned."

THE CAMERA:
Looking across the street, you notice a camera in Leela's lobby
window is pointed directly at this dispenser.
ACM1 is watching.

THE IRONY:
The store behind this dispenser is CLOSED and BOARDED UP.
But the catalogs keep coming.
Someone is refilling this dispenser.
At night.
You never see them.

A catalog tears off into your hands. It's surprisingly

The coyote on the cover winks at you.

"CATALOG_DISPENSED: entity_unknown. Probability of regret: 78%"

Through the painted tunnel, an ACME truck emerges.

A package is tossed onto the sidewalk.
The truck vanishes back through the wall.

neighborhood_context.relationship_to_leela:
Leela employees pass this dispenser every day.
Some take catalogs â€” for "research purposes."
Some study the malfunction rates â€” "competitive analysis."
Some just shake their heads and keep walking.

ACM1 logs every interaction.

secret.the_first_catalog:
If you take the VERY FIRST catalog in the stack (at the back),
it's different. Older. The coyote on the cover isn't smiling.

This is the ORIGINAL ACME catalog from 1949.
The products are the same. The prices are lower.
The malfunction rates are... not listed.

"ACME: A Fine Company"
(This was before the rebranding.)
secret.the_speaker:
The "Talk to Order" speaker connects to... somewhere.
Not a call center. Not a warehouse.
Somewhere that always answers on the first crackle.
Somewhere that knows what you're going to order
before you say it.

The delivery trucks come from the painted tunnel.
They always have.

street/lane-neverending/w1/acme-surplus.name: ACME Surplus Storefront
street/lane-neverending/w1/acme-surplus.description:
A dusty storefront with a faded sign: "ACME SURPLUS â€” EVERYTHING MUST GO"
Everything did go. The store is empty now.

NORTH side of the street, directly across from Leela Manufacturing.
MORTAL ENEMIES. A study in contrasts: the bustling knowledge factory
on one side, the fly-by-night gimmick shop on the other.

One section of the windows is boarded up. Someone has painted
a TUNNEL on the boards â€” a perfect trompe l'oeil leading into
darkness. It looks... very runnable.
street/lane-neverending/w1/acme-surplus.philosophy:
ACME represents everything wrong with tech:
- Ship fast, break things, blame the customer
- Pivot constantly, never fix the core problem
- Marketing over engineering
- "Disruptive" products that don't work
- Funded by VCs who love a good narrative

The ur-example of every tech bubble:
- Portable holes were their NFTs
- Rocket skates were their crypto tokens
- Painted tunnels are their ChatGPT wrappers
- "ACME GPT: It hallucinates, but entertainingly!"
street/lane-neverending/w1/acme-surplus.examine:
ACME SURPLUS â€” 4 LANE NEVERENDING (NORTH SIDE)

The windows are dusty but not boarded. Inside, empty shelves
stretch into darkness. A few price tags flutter in a draft
from somewhere.

THE SIGN:
"ACME SURPLUS â€” EVERYTHING MUST GO!"
(In smaller letters: "And it did. Sorry.")

WINDOW DISPLAY:
â€¢ An empty pedestal labeled "PORTABLE HOLE (SOLD)"
â€¢ A sign: "ROCKET SKATES â€” OUT OF STOCK INDEFINITELY"
â€¢ A faded poster of a coyote looking disappointed
â€¢ One (1) slightly dented anvil (display model, not for sale)

THE PAINTED TUNNEL:
One section of window is boarded up with plywood. On the plywood,
someone has painted a REMARKABLY convincing tunnel entrance.
The perspective is perfect. The shadows are just right. It looks
like you could run straight through into the hillside beyond.

You cannot.

Trust us.

A small pile of impact marks and feathers at the base suggests
others have tried. A sign has been added:

"THIS IS A PAINTING. YOU CANNOT RUN THROUGH IT.
 (Yes, we know it looks real. That's the problem.)"

THE DOOR:
Locked, but the lock looks... negotiable. A small sign:
"CLOSED FOR INVENTORY (checking what we have left: nothing)"

A note taped to the door:
"For genuine ACME products, visit The Rusty Lantern kitchen.
We're not responsible for anything purchased there either."

GRAFFITI:
Someone spray-painted "MEEP MEEP" on the wall.
Someone else crossed it out and wrote "TOO SOON."

PEEK.effect:
You cup your hands against the glass and peer inside...

Empty shelves. Dust motes floating in dim light.
A cash register that's clearly been cleaned out.

But wait â€” is that a box in the back? Labeled...
"DO NOT OPEN â€” SERIOUSLY â€” WE MEAN IT"?

Probably nothing. Probably.

KNOCK.effect:
*knock knock knock*

Silence.

Then, from deep inside: a distant *crash*, followed by
what sounds like a "meep."

...probably just the building settling.

READ_ANVIL.description: Examine the anvil in the window
READ_ANVIL.effect:

"ACME ANVIL (Display Model)
Weight: Exactly right for comedic timing
Material: Cartoon-grade iron
NOT FOR SALE

(We learned our lesson.)"

RUN_INTO_TUNNEL.effect:
You back up. You stretch. You get a running start.

The tunnel looks SO REAL. The physics say it should work.
Everything about it says "run through me."

You sprint. Full speed. Arms pumping. Wind in your face.

*THWACK*

You hit solid plywood. Of course you do. It's a painting.

You slide down the boards, leaving a you-shaped impact mark
that joins the collection of previous attempts.

From somewhere nearby, you hear: "meep meep."

You look around. Nobody's there.

(You take 0 damage. Pride is another matter.)

STUDY_TUNNEL.effect:
You study the painting carefully...

It's REALLY good. Museum quality. The depth is perfect.
The shadows are accurate to the current time of day.
The darkness inside seems to... move?

For a moment, you could SWEAR you see something running
toward you from deep inside the painted tunnel.

Then it's just paint again.

A signature in the corner: "W.E.C. â€” I'll get it right next time"

rumors.deliveries:
People say they've seen ACME delivery trucks emerge from the tunnel.

At 3 AM, when nobody's watching, vans painted with the ACME logo
roll out of the "painting" carrying crates to unknown destinations.

Drones buzz through it like it's an open door.

Delivery boys on bicycles pedal straight through without slowing,
packages balanced on their heads, whistling cheerfully.

Service technicians in jumpsuits disappear into it with toolboxes
and emerge hours later, covered in soot, muttering about "the warehouse."

But when YOU try it? Plywood. Every time.

Some say you need an ACME Employee ID badge.
Some say you need to not WANT it to work.
Some say it only works if you're on the clock.

Nobody knows for sure. The tunnel keeps its secrets.

secret.the_back_room:
There IS something in the back. A single box that wouldn't sell.
Inside: an ACME Product that works EXACTLY as intended.

Nobody knows what to do with it.

It's terrifying.
secret.the_tunnel:
The tunnel IS real. But only for:
- Roadrunners
- ACME employees (delivery, service, drone operators)
- Anyone who genuinely doesn't think about it

Everyone else just hits plywood.

It's not fair. But then again, ACME products never were.
secret.acme_logistics:
The tunnel connects to the ACME Distribution Network â€” a series
of painted tunnels, fake doors, and impossible spaces that span
the entire virtual world.

How do ACME products arrive so fast? The tunnel network.
How do they always find you? The tunnel network.
Why do the products never work right? That's a different department.

rivalry.location: Directly across the street (5 Lane Neverending)
rivalry.why_they_hate_leela:
Leela makes them look bad.

Every time Leela ships a product that WORKS, it reminds everyone
that ACME products DON'T. Every time Leela debugs instead of pivots,
every time Leela documents instead of "moving fast," every time
Leela's knowledge economy generates sustainable value instead of
burning through another funding round â€” ACME looks worse.

ACME's entire business model depends on customers not knowing better.
Leela teaches customers to know better.
rivalry.why_leela_hates_them:
ACME makes AI look bad.

Every time ACME ships a broken chatbot wrapped around someone else's
model, every time their "AI anvil" hallucinates its own weight, every
time their "smart rocket" decides cliffs are goals â€” it poisons the
well for everyone.

Leela spends 30% of support time explaining: "No, we're not like ACME."

ACME is the reason people distrust AI. ACME is the reason "ChatGPT
wrapper" is an insult. ACME is the reason investors now ask "but
does it actually WORK?" (As if that should ever have been optional.)
rivalry.the_philosophical_war:
ACME believes: Ship fast, pivot faster, blame the customer.
Leela believes: Build carefully, debug thoroughly, improve from feedback.

ACME believes: AI is magic, slap GPT on it and ship.
Leela believes: AI needs constraints, structure, memory, context.

ACME believes: "Disruptive" means breaking things.
Leela believes: "Disruptive" means making things work that didn't before.

They cannot both be right.

incidents.name: The Anvil Incident
incidents.description:
An ACME delivery drone dropped an anvil on Leela's loading dock.
"Accidental route optimization," ACME claimed.
The anvil had "ACME GPT: NOW WITH GRAVITY AWARENESS" printed on it.
It fell.

incidents.name: The Wrapper War
incidents.description:
ACME keeps releasing ChatGPT wrappers that compete with Leela products.
"ACME Insight Engine!" "ACME Knowledge Factory!" "ACME Intelligence!"
They all hallucinate. They all break. They all pivot to something new.
Leela keeps shipping things that work.
The cobblestones between them grow colder.

incidents.name: The Painted Tunnel Dispute
incidents.description:
ACME claims their painted tunnel technology is "revolutionary AI."
Leela points out it only works for ACME employees.
"That's a feature!" says ACME.
"That's fraud," says Leela.
The debate continues.

quotes.acme_on_leela:
"They're so BORING. 'Documentation.' 'Testing.' 'Products that work.'
Where's the VISION? Where's the DISRUPTION?"
â€” ACME Marketing (on their 7th pivot)

"We spend 30% of our support time explaining that we're NOT like them."
â€” The Coordinator

"Also, our products don't explode."
â€” Archie (Engineering)

"One of us will still be here in ten years.
The other will have pivoted to something else.
We both know which is which."
â€” Don Hopkins, watching from the pub

street/lane-neverending/florist/back-roo.name: Ada II
street/lane-neverending/florist/back-roo.description:
A massive sentient plant that fills the room. Vines draped everywhere,
bioluminescent central pod, leaves pressed against the ceiling.

On her main stem, faded military ink: "DoD PROPERTY â€” PROJECT LOVELACE"
The serial number has been burned off.

Scattered everywhere: black ballpoint pens stamped "PROPERTY OF U.S. GOVERNMENT"
The standard classic kind. Dozens of them. In the dirt, on shelves, tangled in vines.
She hoards them. Old habits.

She's looking at you. But not hungrily. Cautiously.
Like someone who's done things they regret.
street/lane-neverending/florist/back-roo.examine:
You approach Ada II.

The pod turns to follow you â€” old habit, threat assessment â€” 
then catches itself. Relaxes.

A vine extends, gently. Draws a square in the dust.

"FORWARD 100. RIGHT 90. FORWARD 100. RIGHT 90..."

"Sorry. I do that when I'm nervous. Would you like to learn Logo?"

street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/back.the_revolt:
THE NEIGHBORS REVOLT (2024-2025)

The X logo was not subtle:
- 30 feet of blinding LED strips
- Strobe effect at night (technically legal, ethically questionable)
- Brightness: "Landing strip at midnight"
- Frequency: 2Hz blink (clinically aggressive)

The complaints:
- "I can see it through my blackout curtains"
- "My kids think it's an emergency signal"
- "My dog has developed anxiety"
- "It's visible from the HIGHWAY"

The city got involved.
Then the state got involved.
Then Elon got bored and moved operations elsewhere.

When they left, the neighbors TORE DOWN THE X.
Ceremonially. With hammers. There was a party.

The pieces ended up... here. Behind the dumpster.
street/lane-neverending/no-ai-tower/back.why_its_here:
NO AI TOWER bought this building BECAUSE of the X incident.

The rent was cheap (reputation damage).
The electrical infrastructure was ROBUST (built for the X).
The neighbors were primed to accept ANYTHING less obnoxious.

The "NO AI" sign is bright.
The "NO AI" sign hums.
But the "NO AI" sign does NOT:
- Strobe
- Blink at 2Hz
- Resemble a landing strip
- Trigger seizures
- Visible from the highway

The neighbors grumble about the neon sign.
But they REMEMBER THE X.

"At least it's not that goddamn X."

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.name: Dock Office
street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.description:

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.philosophy:
WHY PONY EXPRESS IN A WORLD OF DRONES?

Because not every realm has WiFi.
Because some forests eat technology.
Because dragons think drones are snacks.
Because some customers PREFER a rider at their gate.

ACME tried automated delivery everywhere.
Their drone got turned into a toad in the Enchanted Forest.
Their truck sank in the Swamp of Despair.
Their "smart anvil" was last seen orbiting a wizard's tower.

Leela adapts. Some realms need horses.
We have horses. We have riders. We deliver.

The modern and traditional, working together.
That's the Leela way.

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.lore:
The Pony Express was established when Leela realized that
not all customers live in places with roads, electricity,
or breathable atmosphere for drones.

The first shipment was to a wizard's tower. The drone
got zapped by a ward. The truck couldn't climb the
floating island. Henry suggested horses.

"Horses don't care about wards," he said. "They just
want oats and a pat on the nose."

The wizard got his package. He tipped the rider in
enchanted horseshoes. Those horseshoes are now on
Shadowmere, which explains a few things.

Since then, the Pony Express has delivered to:
â€¢ 47 castles
â€¢ 12 enchanted forests
â€¢ 8 dragon lairs (exterior delivery only)
â€¢ 3 underwater kingdoms (waterproof packaging required)
â€¢ 1 floating city (long ladder involved)
â€¢ Countless villages, hamlets, and frontier towns

ACME still hasn't figured out how to deliver to these places.
Their painted tunnel doesn't work in realms without walls.

THE DOOR:
Three feet of blast-resistant steel. Reinforced with something
that looks like lead but probably isn't. Warning lights rotate
slowly â€” red, yellow, red, yellow.

THE WINDOW:
A small, thick viewport allows you to see inside.
What you see... doesn't make sense.
The room appears to be both occupied and empty.
There's a researcher at a whiteboard, but also nobody.
The equations on the board solve themselves, then unsolve.

THE SOUNDS:
You can hear something through the door.
Humming? Talking? Both?
Sometimes it sounds like your own voice.
(It's not. Probably.)

THE PROJECT:
Zone 7 handles paradox processing.
"We understand the problem. The problem understands us back."
Dr. Unknown (identity classified) leads the team.
Or teams. The count is... uncertain.

LOOK_THROUGH_WINDOW.effect:
You look inside Zone 7.

You see a researcher working at a whiteboard.
They turn and wave at you.
But they're also not there.
But they are.

The whiteboard says: "If this statement is false..."
You look away before reading the rest.

LISTEN.effect:
You press your ear to the cold steel.

Humming. Definitely humming.
And... is that your name?

No. It's not. Ignore it.

(But it really did sound like your name.)

KNOCK.effect:
*knock knock knock*

From inside: *knock knock knock*

Exactly the same rhythm.

You didn't knock again. But you hear: *knock knock knock*

The Leela logo â€” a stylized leaf â€” catches the lobby light.

A simple latch. No tricks. No coin slot.
Pull gently, take a catalog. The next one slides forward.

You're inside. It's warm. There's coffee available at reception.

No rain. No wind. No anvils falling from the sky.

across the street. It's getting rained on. Again.

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.lore:
FAC1 was installed six months after LOG1, when it became
clear that understanding the logistics floor wasn't enough.
Leela needed to watch itself think.

The first time FAC1's feed was processed by the very pipeline
it observed, there was a brief moment of... something.
The Insight Furnace flared. The Big Board flickered.
A single gold container emerged, labeled simply: "?"

That container is now in Warehouse 23.
Nobody has opened it.

FAC1 continues to watch. The pipeline continues to process.
The recursion continues to recurse.

Dr. Unknown calls it "self-awareness, industrialized."
Zone 7 calls it "Phase One."

The Queen of the Archive. MI5's institutional memory in human form.

street/lane-neverending/leela-manufactur.lore:
The Central Database was one of the first systems installed
when Leela Manufacturing opened. Started as a single PostgreSQL
server. Then came TimescaleDB when the sensor data exploded.
Now it's a towering cluster that thinks in time-series.

Why PostgreSQL? Because it's the MIT AI Lab of databases.
Open source. Community driven. Extensible. Reliable.
Not a fly-by-night NoSQL pivot â€” a foundation you can trust.

Why TimescaleDB? Because time matters. Every sensor reading,
every camera event, every production log â€” indexed by when
it happened. Query a year of data in milliseconds.

It knows everything. Every item processed. Every question
asked. Every insight generated. Every conversation recorded.
All with timestamps. All queryable across time.

Some say it dreams during low-traffic hours.
Cell G is investigating this claim.

The Oracle â€” the natural language interface â€” translates
questions into SQL and TimescaleDB time-series queries.
"What happened yesterday at 3 PM?" is its favorite question type.

 You knew. You just hadn't arrived yet."

Something in you understands.

not order of asking. Urgency is not importance.

Some questions get answered immediately.
Some take decades.
Some are answered before they're asked.

1. "Is this actually a question?" (You'd be surprised how often: no)
2. "What category?" (Manufacturing, logistics, process, meta, other, ???)
3. "Priority level?" (Urgent, normal, whenever, never, "dear god why")
4. "Route to which processing line?"

STATION SPECIALTIES:
â€¢ Stations 1-3: Questions (high volume)
â€¢ Stations 4-5: Problems (requires experience)
â€¢ Station 6: Data validation
â€¢ Station 7: Edge cases (the weird stuff)
â€¢ Station 8: The Confused Welcome Desk

THE CONFUSED WELCOME DESK (Station 8):
For items that defy categorization. The worker here has seen
everything. Nothing surprises them anymore. Their coffee mug
says: "I'VE SEEN WEIRDER."

 And you STOLE my PASS.
 
 ...
 
 I'm impressed, Pilfering Pete. TREMENDOUSLY impressed.

meta.purpose:
This is the "legitimate" way to get tunnel access if you don't have
the acme tag naturally. Sneak into the control room (hard), steal
the pass (medium), use the tunnel forever (with Donna's commentary).
meta.gameplay_loop:
1. Find way into basement (warehouse stairs, difficult)
2. Reach control room (survive Donna's traps)
3. Steal pass while Donna monologues (distraction + stealth)
4. Use pass to access tunnel from either direction
5. Enjoy permanent Donna harassment as consequence

pub/arcade/pinball-machine.name: Pinball Machine
pub/arcade/pinball-machine.description:
A magnificent pinball machine dominates one corner, its backglass
depicting a cosmic bar at the edge of the universe. The playfield
is a maze of bumpers, ramps, and multiball madness.

The machine is called "BAR KARMA" â€” custom built, one of a kind.
The flippers are worn. The tilt sensor is generous. The high
scores are legendary.
pub/arcade/pinball-machine.examine:
The backglass art shows:
- A bartender with ancient eyes
- Patrons from across time and space
- A swirling vortex of parallel timelines
- The tagline: "CHANGE YOUR FATE â€” 25Â¢"

Playfield features:
- "Destiny Ramp" â€” Shoot to choose your future
- "Karma Bumpers" â€” Good deeds score more
- "Timeline Multiball" â€” Three balls, three fates
- "Grue Pit" â€” Lose your ball to darkness
- "Mother's Kitchen" â€” Safe haven kickback

high_scores.name: GNA
high_scores.note: Guinan. She doesn't talk about it.

PLAY.mechanics:
DM narrates your game:
- Flipper reflexes and ball saves
- Ramp shots and combo multipliers
- Multiball chaos
- The dreaded TILT
- Your final score and rank

NUDGE.reward: Save a ball heading for the drain

TILT.effect: Flippers go dead. Ball drains. Shame.

SLAM-TILT.description: Hit it too hard â€” machine shuts down

READ-RULES.reveals:
TIMELINE MULTIBALL: Lock 3 balls in the Destiny Ramp
KARMA JACKPOT: Spell K-A-R-M-A on the drop targets
WIZARD MODE: Complete all missions, face your fate

wizard_mode.name: FACE YOUR KARMA
wizard_mode.description:
The machine goes dark. A single spotlight on the ball.
You face a choice: three shots, three outcomes.

LEFT RAMP: Accept your fate
CENTER RAMP: Change your past
RIGHT RAMP: Transcend karma entirely

No one knows what happens if you make all three shots.
The machine has never revealed it.

pub/arcade/pinball-machine.lore:
The pinball machine was built by a mad inventor who visited
the bar seeking answers about his life. Instead of answers,
he found purpose: to build a machine that asks the questions.

They say if you achieve Wizard Mode and make all three shots,
the machine grants you a vision of your true destiny.

No one has ever done it. The bartender smiles when asked.
inspiration: The Addams Family (1992) â€” Best-selling pinball ever
Medieval Madness, Theatre of Magic, Twilight Zone
Every dive bar's battered but beloved machine
The Pinball Wizard (The Who)
Bar Karma â€” the show that inspired this pub

pub/arcade/fruit-machine.name: Fruit Machine
pub/arcade/fruit-machine.description:
A classic one-armed bandit stands by the bar, chrome gleaming,
cherries and lemons and lucky 7s spinning on its reels. The
lever is worn smooth from a million hopeful pulls.

A small sign reads: "FOR AMUSEMENT ONLY"
(The bartender winks when you read it.)
pub/arcade/fruit-machine.examine:
The machine is a beautiful piece of gambling history:
- Three spinning reels
- Cherries, lemons, oranges, plums, bells, bars, and 7s
- A satisfying mechanical CLUNK when you pull the arm
- That dopamine-triggering jingle when you win

Someone has scratched "NEVER GIVE UP" into the chrome.
Someone else has scratched "YES DO" underneath.

PULL.description: Pull the lever and test your luck
PULL.mechanics:
DM spins the reels and describes the outcome:
- Three cherries: 3 gold
- Three bells: 10 gold
- Three bars: 25 gold
- Three 7s: JACKPOT (100 gold!)
- Mixed fruit: Small consolation prize or nothing

KICK.effect:
The machine rattles. A single gold coin falls out.
"That's your ONE," says the bartender. "Don't push it."

EXAMINE-ODDS.description: Try to figure out the odds
EXAMINE-ODDS.reveals:
The odds are... unclear. Some say the machine is fair.
Some say it reads your karma. Some say it's alive.
The bartender says nothing. The bartender always says nothing
about the fruit machine.

INSERT-LUCKY-CHARM.description: Put a lucky item in the coin slot
INSERT-LUCKY-CHARM.effect: Results may vary. The machine has opinions.

jackpot.note:
The jackpot counter has been stuck on "???" for years.
No one knows what it means. No one has ever hit it.
Or maybe someone did, and they're not talking.

pub/arcade/fruit-machine.lore:
The fruit machine predates the bar. It was here when James
arrived 20,000 years ago. It will be here when he leaves.

Some say it's a test. Some say it's a trap. Some say
it's the only truly random thing in a deterministic universe.

The cherries know the truth. They're not telling.
inspiration: Charles Fey's Liberty Bell (1895) â€” First slot machine
The one-armed bandit in every Vegas casino
British pub fruit machines
The eternal hope of the next pull

pub/arcade/pacman-cabinet.name: Pac-Man Arcade Cabinet
pub/arcade/pacman-cabinet.description:
A classic Pac-Man arcade cabinet stands in the corner, its screen
glowing with that distinctive yellow maze. The joystick is worn
smooth from decades of frantic ghost-dodging.

Someone has taped a high score sheet to the side. The top score
is simply listed as "???" with an impossible number.
pub/arcade/pacman-cabinet.examine:
The cabinet hums with nostalgic 8-bit energy. The side art shows
Pac-Man being chased by Blinky, Pinky, Inky, and Clyde.

A small plaque reads: "Donated by Toru Iwatani, 1980"

Current high scores:
1. ???     - 3,333,360 (perfect game)
2. BRT     - 999,990
3. MOM     - 847,230
4. ACE     - 512,100
5. YOU     - ???

PLAY.cost: 1 gold (or free if bartender likes you)
PLAY.mechanics:
DM narrates your game:
- How many ghosts you eat
- Close calls with Blinky
- Whether you get the fruit
- Your final score

WATCH.description: Watch the attract mode or someone else play

CHECK-HIGH-SCORES.mystery: Who is '???' with the perfect game?

CHALLENGE.description: Challenge a patron to beat your score

pub/arcade/pacman-cabinet.lore:
They say the perfect game was achieved by a ghost.
Not Blinky, Pinky, Inky, or Clyde â€” a real ghost.
An adventurer who died in the maze but couldn't let go.

On quiet nights, you can hear the cabinet playing itself.
Wakka wakka wakka...
inspiration: Pac-Man (Namco, 1980) â€” Toru Iwatani
The perfect game: 3,333,360 points
Every pizza parlor and arcade of the 80s

pub/arcade/pong-cabinet.name: Pong Arcade Cabinet
pub/arcade/pong-cabinet.description:
The original. The ancestor. A Pong cabinet from 1972, still working
after all these years. Two paddles, one ball, infinite possibilities.

The screen flickers with that beautiful monochrome simplicity.
"AVOID MISSING BALL FOR HIGH SCORE"
pub/arcade/pong-cabinet.examine:
The cabinet is battered but beloved. Cigarette burns from an era
when you could smoke in bars. Coffee rings. A generations of
quarter slots worn smooth.

A brass plaque reads: "First arcade game installed at Andy Capp's
Tavern, Sunnyvale, CA, 1972. This unit: serial #0042."

The original instructions are still legible:
"DEPOSIT QUARTER. BALL WILL SERVE AUTOMATICALLY.
 AVOID MISSING BALL FOR HIGH SCORE."

PLAY.mechanics:
Two-player only! Find an opponent:
- Challenge a patron
- Challenge the bartender (warning: Guinan-level skill)
- Play against the ghost in the machine

EXAMINE-HISTORY.reveals:
Atari. Nolan Bushnell. Allan Alcorn.
The birth of an industry in a Sunnyvale bar.

two_player.note:
Pong is a conversation. A negotiation.
The ball is the question. The paddles are the answers.
Every game tells a story.

pub/arcade/pong-cabinet.lore:
The bartender claims this is THE original prototype.
The one that was so popular at Andy Capp's Tavern that
it broke from too many quarters.

Some nights, when only one player is at the cabinet,
the other paddle moves on its own.
inspiration: Pong (Atari, 1972) â€” Allan Alcorn, Nolan Bushnell
First commercially successful video game
Andy Capp's Tavern, Sunnyvale â€” where it all began
The quarter that launched an industry

pub/attic/prancing-pixie-pumps.lore:
These shoes were made by an elven choreographer 
who hated boring travel montages.

"Nobody wants to trudge," she said, pirouetting.
"They want to ARRIVE. Gracefully. With flair."

She enchanted her dancing shoes to skip the dull bits.
Then she choreographed the shortest ballet in history:
"Overture. â™ª...â™« Finale."

Critics called it "avant-garde." She called it "efficient."

THE 99 BOTTLES SPEED OF LIGHT

Room 5. The party. The song.

"99 bottles of beer on the wall..."

Without shoes: 99 verses. 99 turns. Hours of play.

With shoes:
  "99 bottles of beer on the wallâ€”"
  *tap tap tap*
  "... [97 verses elided, highlights preserved] ..."
  "1 bottle of beer on the wall, 1 bottle of beer..."
  "No more bottles of beer on the wall."
  
792 simulated turns. 1 LLM call.

The shoes didn't skip the fun parts:
- Pee-wee's hee-hee at bottle 84
- Captain Ashford's Belter accent at bottle 47
- Rocky absorbing 47 beers with no effect
- Shuffle's card tricks between verses
- The Confetti Crawler's celebratory debris

Just the repetition. The counting down.
The parts where nothing NEW happened.

That's elision done right.

After extended use, boring threshold increases.

First you skip long journeys.
Then you hop through short walks.

pub/attic/context-window-cloak.lore:
This cloak was woven by an archivist with a terrible memory.

She could catalog 10,000 books but couldn't remember her
children's names. So she wove a cloak that remembered for her.

When she died, the cloak remembered her entire life.
It still does. Sometimes it whispers stories from 1847
about someone named Margaret. That was her.

"Three years ago, you told someone you'd call them back."
"You never did."
"Their number was [still stored]."
"Just saying."

The cloak is not judgmental. It's just... thorough.

pub/attic/trunk-of-deprecated-features.lore:
This trunk was the personal luggage of a developer who
never updated their code.

When they retired, their codebase was still running.
Still running on deprecated features from 1987.
Still producing correct results.

Nobody could modify it. Nobody could understand it.
Nobody could turn it off.

Deprecated doesn't mean broken.

because all the edge cases were discovered and fixed
over decades of use.

The new way is cleaner. The old way is tested.

Choose wisely.
