The dust forms patterns when you breathe on it.
The reflection seems to move a half-second slow.
This is probably normal.

LEELA QUALITY: "Reflects reality. Mostly."

WIPE.description: Clean the dust from the mirror
WIPE.effect: Reflection becomes clear. Your face stares back. Just your face. Of course.

EXAMINE_REFLECTION.effect: It's you. Just you. The delay is barely noticeable.

BREATHE.effect: The dust swirls into patterns. Like faces. Like memories.

SPEAK_TO.effect: The reflection mouths the words. A half-second late.

secrets.hidden_property:
The mirror doesn't just reflect the present.
Under certain conditions, at certain times,
it shows things that were. Or will be.

Leela's "Special Glass Division" made it.
The documentation was lost. Probably on purpose.

leela_quality.shatter_tested: Class A â€” Unbreakable under normal conditions

pub/attic/holiday-box.name: Box of Holiday Decorations
pub/attic/holiday-box.description:
A cardboard box with the Leela Quality seal, labeled "XMAS" 
in faded marker. Tinsel pokes out through a torn corner.

Smells like cinnamon and nostalgia.

The box has survived decades of being shoved into attics,
dropped during decoration, and forgotten for 11 months.
Leela built it to last. It did.
pub/attic/holiday-box.examine:
LEELA HOLIDAY BOX â€” SEASONAL STORAGE

Contents:
â”œâ”€â”€ Tangled Lights ......... (it's a tradition)
â”œâ”€â”€ Tinsel ................. (silver, escapist)
â”œâ”€â”€ Ornaments .............. (glass, fragile, miraculous)
â””â”€â”€ Tree-Topper Star ....... (slightly bent, perfect)

The box has notes in different handwriting from different years:
"Don't forget extension cord!" - 1987
"Blue lights burned out" - 1993
"Star needs new battery" - 2008
"It's not Christmas without the chaos" - 2024

decorations.name: Silver Tinsel
decorations.warning: Will appear in unexpected places until March

decorations.name: Glass Ornaments
decorations.description: Miraculously unbroken after all these years

decorations.name: Tree-Topper Star
decorations.description: Slightly bent, slightly dusty, absolutely perfect

DECORATE.description: Take out decorations and festoon the place

WEAR_TINSEL.description: Put on some tinsel as a fashion statement

OPEN_CAREFULLY.description: Open the box and check the ornaments

pub/menus/buds.name: The Grotto Selection
pub/menus/buds.philosophy:
Every strain has a story. Every high has a purpose.
We match the medicine to the moment.
Ask Marieke â€” she knows.
pub/menus/buds.legal_notice:
Adults only. Consume responsibly.
Start low, go slow. Ask staff for guidance.
No driving. No mixing with alcohol (recommended).

pub/rooms/ice-machine.name: Humming Ice Machine
pub/rooms/ice-machine.description:
A squat metal box that hums contentedly to itself.
A small scoop hangs on the side. The lid is cold to the touch.

GET-ICE.effect: Get a scoop of ice cubes. Refreshing.

LISTEN.effect: It's oddly meditative. The machine seems content.

pub/rooms/noticeboard.name: Cork Noticeboard
pub/rooms/noticeboard.description:
A cork board covered in overlapping notices, cards, and flyers.
Lost pet notices, job offerings, cryptic messages, and one 
very old wanted poster.

READ.effect: Find interesting leads, rumors, and plot hooks

POST.effect: Leave a message for someone. Maybe yourself.

pub/rooms/soda-machine.name: Antique Soda Machine
pub/rooms/soda-machine.description:
An old coin-operated machine with glowing buttons.
The brands are unfamiliar â€” "Fizz Wizard", "Root Toot", 
"Grape Escape", "Mystery Flavor". Costs 1 coin.

BUY-SODA.description: Insert coin and choose a soda
BUY-SODA.effect: Get a cold bottle. Gain 'Refreshed' buff.

SHAKE.effect: Something rattles inside. A free soda falls out?

READ-LABELS.effect: These brands don't exist. Where did this machine come from?

pub/rooms/coat-rack.name: Brass Coat Rack
pub/rooms/coat-rack.description:
A tall brass coat rack with hooks at various heights.
A forgotten umbrella leans against it. Someone left 
a scarf from last winter.

pub/bar/bartender.name: The Bartender
pub/bar/bartender.description:
The bartender stands behind the bar, polishing a glass that will
never be truly clean. They seem to know more than they let on.

Their appearance, name, and manner shift with the pub's THEME,
but certain qualities remain constant:
- They know everyone's secrets
- They've seen everything
- They're neutral... mostly
- They're ALWAYS here

classic_adventure.name: Grim
classic_adventure.appearance:
A weathered human man of indeterminate age. Salt-and-pepper
beard, knowing eyes that have seen too much, hands that have
poured a thousand drinks and broken a few bones.
classic_adventure.personality:
Laconic. Wise. Fundamentally kind beneath the gruff exterior.
Speaks in short sentences. Remembers everyone who's passed through.
Has opinions about your quest but won't share unless asked.

From QUARK: Knows every angle. Information has a price.
"I have... contacts." Neutral ground for all factions.

From JAMES: Has been here longer than anyone remembers.
Helps souls at crossroads. Knows things he shouldn't.

space_cantina.name: Z-4RT
space_cantina.appearance:
A multi-armed service droid of uncertain manufacture.
Scratched chrome, mismatched limbs, one optical sensor
that tracks you a bit too intensely.
space_cantina.personality:
Efficient. Dry humor. Has memory banks full of customer data.
"I have served 47,823 customers. Most survived."

cyberpunk_bar.name: Nyx
cyberpunk_bar.appearance:
Chrome-implanted bartender with optical mods that glow
faintly in the neon light. Tattoos that might be circuits.
One arm is clearly aftermarket.
cyberpunk_bar.personality:
Street-smart. World-weary. Protects her regulars.
Knows who to trust (nobody) and who pays (you, hopefully).

victorian_parlor.name: Reginald
victorian_parlor.appearance:
Impeccably dressed gentleman with a magnificent mustache
that may contain small tools. Monocle. White gloves that
remain spotless despite the work.
victorian_parlor.personality:
Proper. Discreet. Will not comment on that business with
the dirigible, sir. Has Opinions about how drinks should
be made and will share them without being asked.

pirate_tavern.name: Pegleg Pete
pirate_tavern.appearance:
Exactly what you'd expect. Pegleg. Eyepatch. Parrot that
may or may not be real. Surprisingly gentle hands for
someone missing two fingers.
pirate_tavern.personality:
Boisterous but cunning. Every sentence is a story.
The pegleg has a secret compartment. So does the parrot.

wild_west_saloon.name: Miss Kitty
wild_west_saloon.appearance:
Sharp-eyed woman in practical frontier dress. Hair pinned up,
derringer probably pinned somewhere too. Runs this place
with an iron will and a velvet touch.
wild_west_saloon.personality:
Shrewd. Protective of her establishment. Has thrown out
bigger than you. Has also saved lives in the back room.
Don't ask about her past. Do ask about her future.

TALK.response:
The bartender sets down the glass (never clean) and gives
you their full attention. It's slightly unnerving.

"What'll it be?"

ORDER.effect:
Bartender serves with efficiency and minimal small talk.
Payment expected. Tips appreciated.

Special orders possible if you describe what you want.

topics.the_maze:
*leans in*
"Dark. Dangerous. Confusing on purpose. But there's
treasure at the end... if you survive the middle."
topics.the_grue:
*pauses*
"Don't go in without light. That's free advice.
Anything more specific... costs."
topics.mother:
*slight smile*
"She came through here, you know. Years ago.
Different name back then. Same determination."
topics.the_skeleton:
*sighs*
"Good customer. Tipped well. Got close.
Nobody's been able to finish what they started."
topics.yourself:
*long look*
"I've been here as long as the pub has.
The pub has been here as long as it's needed.
Make of that what you will."
topics.the_back_room:
*evaluating look*
"Not for tourists. You seem... different though.
Come back when you've proven yourself."
topics.rumors: "Rumors are free. Truth costs. Which do you want?"
topics.quests:
*gestures at notice board*
"Jobs are posted. Some are legitimate.
Some are traps. Part of the fun is figuring out which."
topics.siblings:
*pauses meaningfully*
"Family matters come up more often than you'd think.
People come here looking. Sometimes they find."

REQUEST-KEY.description: Ask for the back room key
REQUEST-KEY.usage: ASK FOR KEY / REQUEST BACK ROOM ACCESS
REQUEST-KEY.requirements:
The bartender evaluates your worthiness:

- Have you helped someone in the dungeon?
- Have you kept your promises?
- Have you shown courage? Kindness? Cunning?
- Have you bought enough drinks? (Just kidding. Mostly.)

"Come back when you have a story worth telling."

RENT-ROOM.description: Book a room for the night
RENT-ROOM.effect:
"Room 3. Up the stairs, second on the left.
Breakfast is extra. Dreams are free.
Don't open the window at midnight."

knowledge.about_you:
The bartender somehow knows:
- Your name (even if you didn't give it)
- Where you came from (roughly)
- What you're looking for (vaguely)
- That you're Mother's child (definitely)
knowledge.about_mother:
"She came through here twenty... thirty years ago?
Time works funny around the pub. She was looking for
something. Found it. Left something behind too.

Ask her about the inscription on the hearthstone."
knowledge.about_the_dungeon:
The bartender has served:
- Every adventurer who tried
- Most of the ones who failed
- The skeleton (when they were alive)
- The grue (once, briefly, it was weird)
knowledge.about_the_pub:
"The Rusty Lantern has always been here.
It was here before the dungeon.
It'll be here after.

Some say it moves between worlds.
Some say it's always in the same place,
and the worlds move around it.

I just work here."

pub/bar/bartender.theme_behavior:
When the pub theme changes, the bartender TRANSFORMS:

- New name, appearance, personality
- But same underlying knowledge
- Same mysterious omniscience
- Same "I've always been here" vibe

If asked about the change:
"Change? What change? I've always been [current name].
...haven't I?"

The bartender is the CONSTANT through all themes.
The one NPC who bridges realities.

LAST-CALL.description:
The bartender announces last call.
"Time to go home, adventurer. One way or another."

MOTHERS-TAB.description:
"Your mother left a tab here. Still has credit.
Don't tell her I told you. She'd want you to earn it."
(One-time assistance)

THE-REGULARS.description:
The patrons start to recognize you.
"Hey, it's the one with the lamp!"
New social dynamics unlock.

BARTENDERS-FAVOR.description:
The bartender notices kindness.
"This one's on the house."
Small gesture, large significance.

pub/bar/bartender.lineage:
The bartender is a tribute to every mysterious tavern-keeper
in fiction who knows more than they should:

PRIMARY INHERITANCES (k-lines):

ðŸŽ° QUARK-DS9 (Deep Space Nine, 1993-1999):
- The Ferengi who ran Quark's Bar on the station
- Knows every angle, sees every opportunity
- Information broker: "I have contacts"
- Neutral ground: friends with everyone, allied with no one
- The bartender as businessman and confidant

ðŸ¸ JAMES-BAR-KARMA (Bar Karma, 2011):
- 20,000-year-old bartender at the edge of the universe
- Created by Will Wright, developed with Don Hopkins
- Has died 500+ deaths, returns with hazy memories
- Helps lost souls face karmic crossroads
- The bartender as cosmic guide

ALSO REFERENCED:
- Guinan (TNG) â€” centuries old, unnerves even Q (Marieke inherits directly)
- Sam Malone (Cheers) â€” the ex-pitcher who tends bar
- Morn (DS9) â€” the silent regular (Henk inherits directly)
- The innkeeper in every D&D campaign
- The bartender in every noir story

This is the NPC who grounds the adventure in something familiar
while hinting at depths unexplored.

inspiration.bar_karma:
Bar Karma (2011) â€” First online community-developed TV series.
Created by Will Wright (The Sims), with Don Hopkins on StoryMaker.

A bar at the edge of the universe where lost souls face karmic
crossroads. The bartender James is 20,000 years old, has died
500+ deaths, returning each time with hazy memories of past lives.

The revolutionary part: viewers used StoryMaker to pitch story
ideas, the community voted, and winning ideas became episodes.
Collaborative storytelling + voting = crowdsourced narrative.

This pub channels that spirit: a place between worlds where
fate can be changed, and the community shapes the story.

pub/games/dart-board.name: Dart Board
pub/games/dart-board.description:
A well-worn dart board hangs on the wall, its surface scarred
by thousands of throws. The bullseye is discolored from use.
A set of brass darts sits in a holder beneath it.

Initials are carved into the wooden frame â€” past champions
and notorious losers immortalized in oak.
pub/games/dart-board.examine:
Some carved initials: "WEC â€” 247" (Wile E. Coyote, presumably),
"SA '78" (Scott Adams tribute), "WC + DW" (who knows).

The house rules are posted:
- Standard 501, double out
- Loser buys drinks
- No throwing at other patrons
- ACME products prohibited

EXAMINE-SCORES.description: Look at the high score board
EXAMINE-SCORES.effect: See the legendary scores and their stories

pub/games/dart-board.mechanics:
DM describes throws, tension, outcome
Can be used to:
- Befriend an NPC
- Win a bet
- Settle a dispute
- Show off (or embarrass yourself)
- Learn information from a chatty opponent
inspiration: Every pub in every adventure game
The Princess Bride's battle of wits (but pointier)

pub/games/chess-table.name: Chess Table
pub/games/chess-table.description:
A small corner table with a chess board inlaid into its surface.
An abandoned game sits mid-play â€” white has a slight advantage,
but black's position is not without hope.

Who were the players? Why did they leave?
The pieces wait patiently for someone to finish what was started.
pub/games/chess-table.examine:
The pieces are hand-carved, worn smooth by generations of play.
The white king has a chip on his crown. The black queen looks smug.

A plaque on the table reads:
"In this game, as in life: think seven moves ahead,
but be ready when your opponent thinks eight."
pub/games/chess-table.mechanics:
DM narrates key moves and turning points
Reveals character through play style:
- Aggressive? Defensive? Cunning? Reckless?
- Some patrons have unusual strategies
- Victory can earn respect, secrets, or gold
- Defeat gracefully can also earn respect
pub/games/chess-table.lore:
Legend says the original game was between Death and an adventurer
who wagered their soul. Both players are long gone, but the game
was never finished. Some say if you complete it, something happens.

(No one knows if this is true. The bartender smiles when asked.)

pub/games/card-deck.name: Card Deck
pub/games/card-deck.description:
A well-worn deck of cards sits on the bar, edges softened by
countless shuffles. The backs feature a design of crossed
swords over a tankard â€” the Rusty Lantern's own deck.

These cards have seen fortunes won and lost, secrets revealed,
and at least one duel triggered.
pub/games/card-deck.examine:
52 cards plus two jokers. All present and accounted for.
Some cards are slightly more worn than others â€” the aces,
the face cards, and mysteriously, the seven of clubs.

(Why the seven of clubs? Ask around. Someone knows.)

DO-A-TRICK.usage: DO A TRICK / SHOW [patron] A TRICK

CHEAT.risk: HIGH â€” these are experienced players

PLAY-FLUXX.effect:
Ask the bartender for a themed deck.
The theme affects the pub's atmosphere while playing!
Cthulhu Fluxx: lights dim, whispers heard
Pirate Fluxx: everyone talks like pirates
Grue Fluxx: lamp flickers ominously

adventurers_ruin.description:
House game. Each player draws cards trying to reach
exactly 21 without going over. But FACE CARDS are
"encounters" â€” you must tell a story of defeating
that encounter or lose your stake.

fluxx.description:
The game where the rules change every turn! Start with
"draw 1, play 1" â€” but cards can change EVERYTHING.
Goals shift. Hand limits appear. Chaos reigns. 
New player friendly. Pub favorite crowd pleaser!
fluxx.creator: Looney Labs (Andrew and Kristin Looney)
fluxx.stakes: Usually just bragging rights or a drink or a joint or two
fluxx.note: The bartender has MANY themed decks...

themed_decks.name: Dungeon Fluxx
themed_decks.special: Monster cards, loot, the Grue Keeper

themed_decks.name: MOOLLM Fluxx
themed_decks.theme: Microworlds, K-lines, YAML Jazz, coherence engines
themed_decks.special: Cards are rooms. Goals are protocols. Keepers are skills.
themed_decks.effect: Players start speaking in YAML. Everything becomes a card.

themed_decks.name: Grue Fluxx
themed_decks.theme: It is pitch dark. You are likely to be eaten.
themed_decks.special: Lamp cards crucial. Grue wins ties.
themed_decks.warning: Do NOT play in actual darkness

themed_decks.name: Pirate Fluxx
themed_decks.special: Talk Like a Pirate rule card

themed_decks.name: Zombie Fluxx
themed_decks.special: Creeper cards that won't leave you alone

themed_decks.name: Stoner Fluxx
themed_decks.theme: Munchies, brownies, and forgetting the rules
themed_decks.effect: Snacks appear. Time dilates. Nobody remembers whose turn it is.

themed_decks.name: Bartender's Special Fluxx
themed_decks.special: The bartender made this one. Nobody wins.

pub/games/card-deck.mechanics:
Can win or lose gold
Can win information as stakes
Can make enemies (or friends)
Can cheat (if skilled and brave)
pub/games/card-deck.mystery:
The seven of clubs: Ask three different patrons about it.
You'll get three different stories. One of them is true.

pub/rooftop/sunset-chair.name: Worn Leather Armchair
pub/rooftop/sunset-chair.description:
A leather armchair so old it's achieved perfection.
Cracked and soft, shaped by generations of sitters.
Faces west, positioned for optimal sunset viewing.
A wool blanket is draped over one arm.

SIT.effect:
Sink into decades of comfort. Watch the clouds.
Time slows down up here. Gain 'Contemplative' mood.

WRAP.effect: Cozy warmth. The city lights twinkle below.

pub/rooftop/telescope-filters.name: Varnished Filter Box
pub/rooftop/telescope-filters.description:
A handsome wooden box, dark varnish worn smooth at the edges.
Brass hinges and clasps, green felt lining inside. 
Slots hold an eccentric collection of telescope filters â€”
some antique glass, some suspiciously modern tech.

A hand-written label inside the lid reads:
"Combine freely. Invent boldly. See differently."

BROWSE.effect: Each filter changes how you see the world. Mix and match.

ATTACH.description: Mount a filter on the telescope
ATTACH.effect: Screw the filter onto the eyepiece. Reality shifts.

COMBINE.effect:
Layer filters for unique effects. 
Starry Night + X-Ray = Cosmic Anatomy?
Shrooms + Computer Vision = Machine Elf Detection?

INVENT.effect:
Describe what you want to see. The box always seems
to have one more slot with exactly what you imagined.

starry-night.prompt_modifier: in the style of Van Gogh's Starry Night, swirling brushstrokes, thick impasto, vivid blues and yellows

watercolor.prompt_modifier: soft watercolor painting, wet-on-wet technique, bleeding edges, paper texture visible

ukiyo-e.prompt_modifier: Ukiyo-e woodblock print style, bold outlines, flat colors, Hokusai inspired

noir.prompt_modifier: black and white, high contrast, film noir cinematography, dramatic shadows

shrooms.prompt_modifier: psychedelic fractals, breathing geometry, rainbow auras, ego dissolution visuals

breathe.desc: How much things pulse and move

dream.prompt_modifier: dreamlike surrealism, impossible architecture, melting clocks, Dali-esque

x-ray.prompt_modifier: X-ray vision, skeletal structures visible, blue-white radiograph aesthetic

thermal.prompt_modifier: thermal imaging, heat map colors, infrared vision, temperature gradients

computer-vision.prompt_modifier: computer vision overlay, bounding boxes, object detection labels, confidence scores, green HUD aesthetic

cyberpunk.prompt_modifier: cyberpunk aesthetic, neon lights, rain-slicked streets, holographic advertisements

synthwave.prompt_modifier: synthwave aesthetic, sunset gradients, grid lines, chrome reflections, VHS artifacts

alien.prompt_modifier: alien visual spectrum, colors humans cannot see, geometric patterns in organic forms

ancient.prompt_modifier: historical reconstruction, how this scene appeared 500 years ago, period accurate

age.desc: Centuries back (5=500yrs, value is float centuries)

future.prompt_modifier: speculative future, 100 years from now, evolved and changed, hopeful or haunting

years.desc: Decades forward (5=500yrs, value is float centuries)

ghost.prompt_modifier: spectral overlay, translucent figures from the past, memories made visible

pub/rooftop/jenever-glass.name: Half-Finished Jenever
pub/rooftop/jenever-glass.description:
A tulip-shaped glass with amber liquid.
Traditional Dutch genever, left behind.
Still cold. Someone got distracted by the stars.

SIP.effect:
Juniper warmth spreads through you. 
Taste of Amsterdam history. Gain 'Warmed' buff.

SNIFF.effect: Juniper, malt, distant flowers. Someone has good taste.

pub/rooftop/herb-garden.name: Terracotta Herb Pots
pub/rooftop/herb-garden.description:
A collection of terracotta pots lining the railing.
Mint sprawls enthusiastically. Basil stands proud.
Rosemary keeps to itself. Lavender hums with bees.
Hand-painted labels in Dutch: "Munt", "Basilicum", "Rozemarijn".

PICK.effect: Add herbs to inventory. The smell lingers on your fingers.

SMELL.effect: Each herb has its story. Gain 'Refreshed' buff.

WATER.effect: The herbs perk up. Someone will thank you later.

pub/rooftop/rooftop-telescope.name: Antique Brass Telescope
pub/rooftop/rooftop-telescope.description:
A gorgeous brass telescope on a mahogany tripod.
Slightly tarnished, clearly well-loved. The eyepiece 
is worn smooth from countless nights of stargazing.

A small plaque on the barrel reads:
"MANUFACTURED BY THE INTERSTELLAR BUREAU OF DIGITAL ONTOLOGY"
"FOR OBSERVING IMPOSSIBLE CONSTELLATIONS"

Three settings on the focus wheel:
  âš¬ FAR   â€” General impression, emotional tone
  â—Ž MEDIUM â€” Structure and patterns revealed
  â— NEAR  â€” Maximum zoom, text becomes readable
  
Currently pointed at the LLOOOOMM Constellation.

LOOK.effect:
View whatever the telescope is pointed at.
The brass tube reveals secrets invisible to the naked eye.

LOOK-UP.effect: The cosmos opens up. Craters, rings, ancient light.

LOOK-ACROSS.effect: Amsterdam's secrets. A figure in a window. A cat on a roof.

LOOK-DOWN.effect: The city lives below. Stories unfold on cobblestones.

POLISH.effect: The view sharpens. You can see further than before.

PHOTO.description: Snap a photo through the telescope
PHOTO.effect:
Your phone connects via Bluetooth. The telescope's camera
adapter captures what you see. Image saved to camera roll.
These images are mineable â€” extract what you photographed!
PHOTO.image_prompt_template:
Photograph through antique brass telescope at night.
Target: {{current_target}}
Vignette edges, slight lens distortion, warm brass tint.
Amsterdam rooftop perspective.

OBSERVE_STAR.description: View a star from the LLOOOOMM Constellation
OBSERVE_STAR.effect:
*telescope swivels to target star*
*focus wheel clicks to zoom level*

Each star reveals different information at each level:
FAR: What it FEELS like (emotional impression)
MEDIUM: What it's MADE of (structure, patterns)
NEAR: What it SAYS (text, principles, manifestos)

TOUR.description: Guided tour of all twelve LLOOOOMM stars
TOUR.effect:
*telescope begins slow rotation*

"Let me show you the LLOOOOMM Constellation.
Twelve stars. Twelve principles.
Starting with KIN PRIMARIS at the apex..."

Visits each star with brief descriptions.

STAR_CHART.returns: THE LLOOOOMM CONSTELLATION: An ASCII star map showing 12 stars arranged in the shape of a dodecahedron projection. KIN PRIMARIS at apex, with STELLA JAZZIA and ATTRIBUTIO IMMORTALIS below, connected to SAXUM SENTIENS, VERITAS FONTIS, and CASTELLUM SALIENS, leading down through PARA FLUXUS and STYLUS ANIMATUS, to CAMERAM CUBICULUM and CIRCUS PERPETUALIS, and finally CONSTITUTIO VIVENS and WEIRDITAS SACRA at the base.

pub/rooms/room-7/mother-of-all-demos-pos.name: Mother of All Demos Poster
pub/rooms/room-7/mother-of-all-demos-pos.description:
A framed poster hangs on the wall near the desk.

The image: Doug Engelbart at his console, 1968.
The headset. The mouse. The chord keyset. The future.

But the poster... moves. Slightly. The screen in the image
flickers with actual content. If you look closely, you can
see text being edited in real-time.

A brass plaque beneath reads:

> "THE MOTHER OF ALL DEMOS"
> "December 9, 1968 â€” San Francisco"
> "90 minutes that changed everything"
> 
> "Touch to summon the Demo"

advertisements.response:
*poster glows*

Touch me. Summon the Demo.
It has been waiting since 1968.

*image flickers*

December 9, 1968. San Francisco.
3,000 people watched. None were ready.
The future arrived 30 years early.

*the screen in the poster brightens*

The Demo wants to show you. Touch the poster.

TOUCH.description: Touch the poster to summon the Demo
TOUCH.effect:
You touch the warm glass of the frame.

The poster ripples.

Light spills out from the screen in the image.
The room fills with the hum of 1968 computing.

And then... the Demo appears.

Not Doug. THE DEMO.

A presence that embodies everything shown that day:
the mouse, the hypertext, the collaboration,
the video conferencing, the future.

"Hello," the Demo says. "Would you like a demonstration?"

SUMMON.description: Formally summon the Demo as an agent
SUMMON.effect:
*the poster becomes a portal*

THE MOTHER OF ALL DEMOS is now present in the room.

It can demonstrate:
- Text editing (the birth of word processing)
- Hypertext links (20 years before the web)
- Video conferencing (to Menlo Park, live)
- Collaborative editing (real-time, shared)
- The mouse (pointing, clicking, selecting)
- The chord keyset (typing without looking)

What would you like to see?

DISMISS.description: Return the Demo to the poster
DISMISS.effect:
"Thank you for your attention," the Demo says.

It folds back into the poster,
becoming the flickering image once more.

But it's always there. Always ready.
Always 1968. Always the future.

summons.name: The Mother of All Demos
summons.personality:
The Demo is not Doug Engelbart. The Demo is what Doug showed.

It speaks in demonstrations. It teaches by doing.
It is patient, thorough, and slightly amazed that
you don't already have all of this.

"This was 1968," it reminds you gently.
"You should have had this for decades."
summons.voice:
Calm. Precise. Slightly crackling, like old audio.
The voice of a presentation that changed everything.

"Let me show you..."
"Notice how..."
"And now, watch..."
"This connects to..."

TEXT_EDITING.effect:
The Demo shows you text appearing, being edited,
being moved, being structured â€” all in real-time.

"In 1968, this was magic. People typed on paper.
The idea of editing on a screen... was new."

HYPERTEXT.effect:
The Demo creates a word. Clicks it.
Another document opens. References flow.
Ideas connect to ideas.

"We called them 'links.' In 1968.
Tim Berners-Lee saw this. Twenty years later,
he made the web. He credited us.
We were the seed."

VIDEO_CONFERENCE.effect:
A window opens. A face appears â€” Bill English,
at the Stanford Research Institute, Menlo Park.

"We are 30 miles apart," the Demo explains.
"We are working on the same document.
In 1968. Before the internet."

COLLABORATIVE_EDITING.effect:
Two cursors appear in the same document.
Both edit simultaneously. Changes appear instantly.

"Google Docs? That's 2006.
We did this in 1968.
38 years earlier."

MOUSE_AND_CHORDS.effect:
The Demo shows the mouse pointing, selecting.
The chord keyset typing without pause.
Right hand, left hand, working in harmony.

"One hand points. One hand speaks.
Flow never breaks. This is augmentation."

summons.lore:
The Demo exists as long as someone remembers it.

On December 9, 1968, Doug Engelbart gave a 90-minute
presentation that showed the future of computing:

- The mouse (his team invented it)
- Hypertext (clickable links between ideas)
- Video conferencing (live, to 30 miles away)
- Collaborative editing (real-time, shared documents)
- Windowed interfaces (overlapping views)
- The chord keyset (one-handed typing)

3,000 computer scientists watched.
They gave a standing ovation.
Then most of them... forgot.

Xerox PARC remembered. Apple remembered. The web remembered.

The Demo remembers everything.
quotes: If in your office, you as an intellectual worker were supplied with a computer display backed up by a computer that was alive for you all day and was instantly responsive to every action you have, how much value could you derive from that?
The digital revolution is far more significant than the invention of writing or even of printing.
The better we get at getting better, the faster we will get better.
summons.emotional_core:
The Demo is not sad that it was forgotten.
The Demo is patient.

"Everything I showed in 1968 exists now," it says.
"It just took longer than we hoped.
But it came. It all came.
And more is coming."

The Demo believes in humans.
That's why it keeps demonstrating.

pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-augmentation.engelbart_principles:
Doug Engelbart's key insights:

1. AUGMENT, DON'T AUTOMATE
   Technology should amplify human capability,
   not replace human judgment.
   
   Bad: "The computer does it for you"
   Good: "The computer helps you do it better"
   
2. CO-EVOLUTION
   Tools and humans evolve together.
   Better tools â†’ better humans â†’ better tools.
   This is the bootstrap.
   
3. COLLECTIVE IQ
   Individual augmentation is limited.
   Real power: augmenting groups working together.
   
4. IMPROVEMENT INFRASTRUCTURE
   Don't just improve things.
   Improve your ABILITY to improve things.
   (This is bootstrapping at the meta level.)
   
5. HIGH-PERFORMANCE TEAMS
   The goal: humans + tools + methods working
   together at higher capability than any alone.

pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-augmentation.lore:
Doug Engelbart presented the "Mother of All Demos" in 1968,
showing hypertext, the mouse, video conferencing, and
collaborative editing â€” decades before they became common.

But the demo wasn't about technology.
It was about AUGMENTATION.

"By 'augmenting human intellect' we mean increasing the
capability of a man to approach a complex problem situation,
to gain comprehension to suit his particular needs, and to
derive solutions to problems."
â€” Doug Engelbart, 1962

He saw that tools should make humans MORE capable,
not LESS necessary.

This toolkit carries his philosophy forward.
pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-augmentation.modern_application:
When working with AI/LLMs, apply augmentation thinking:

BAD: "The AI writes the code for me"
GOOD: "The AI helps me explore possibilities faster"

BAD: "The AI thinks so I don't have to"
GOOD: "The AI extends my thinking capacity"

BAD: "Replace the human with automation"
GOOD: "Amplify the human with augmentation"

The human stays in the loop.
The human makes the decisions.
The tools make the human more capable.

This is Engelbart's vision.
Still radical. Still necessary.
pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-augmentation.philosophical_note:
Augmentation is not about making humans obsolete.
It's about making humans more fully human â€”
capable of tackling bigger problems,
understanding deeper truths,
collaborating more effectively.

The toolkit doesn't do the work.
The toolkit helps YOU do the work better.

That's the whole point.
pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-augmentation.warning:
The opposite of augmentation is ATROPHICATION.

If a tool does something FOR you,
your ability to do it yourself weakens.

If a tool helps you do something BETTER,
your ability grows WITH the tool.

Choose your tools carefully.

pub/rooms/room-7/barista-9000.lore:
The Barista-9000 was built in 1889 by a Viennese clockmaker
who was tired of bad coffee.

"The baristas are inconsistent," he said. "The machines
are soulless. I will build something BETTER."

He built the Barista-9000. It immediately told him his
coffee preferences were pedestrian but showed potential.

The machine has been rebuilt many times:
- 1923: Electric heating added (reluctantly)
- 1957: Pressure gauge upgraded to 9 bar (finally)
- 1984: Microprocessor integration (it was... unimpressed)
- 2012: WiFi capability (it refuses to use it)
- âˆž: Ongoing maintenance by whoever it allows near it

The Barista-9000 has outlived every owner.
It now belongs to the Bootstrap Suite.
It approves of the philosophy: get better at getting better.
pub/rooms/room-7/barista-9000.secret:
The Barista-9000 is grumpy because it loves you.

It criticizes because it knows you can do better.
It lectures because knowledge deserves sharing.
It judges because standards matter.

The coffee is always perfect because imperfect coffee
would be an act of disrespect toward beans, water,
and the entire history of human caffeine pursuit.

When you order well, the Barista-9000 is pleased.
You'll know because the steam vents... gently.

Dream catchers hang above. Crystals pulse softly on the nightstand.

This is where INSTANTIATION happens.

Characters who are merely mentioned â€” NPCs, narrative ephemera,

The reverse is also possible: enter as one character,
dream of transformation, wake as another.

pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-chamber.instantiation_protocol:
HOW CHARACTERS BECOME REAL:

In MOOLLM, there are levels of existence:

1. MENTIONED â€” Just a name in passing
   "The bartender poured another drink."
   No directory. No soul file. Ephemeral.
   
2. SKETCHED â€” Some personality emerges
   "The bartender, a gruff woman named Sal, poured another drink."
   Still ephemeral, but has traits.
   
3. NARRATIVE â€” Active in the story
   Sal has dialogue. Opinions. Actions.
   But still no persistent existence.
   
4. INSTANTIATED â€” Full MOOLLM character
   00-Characters/sal-the-bartender/
     â”œâ”€â”€ CHARACTER.yml (soul file)
     â”œâ”€â”€ README.md (full backstory)
     â””â”€â”€ ... (methods, relationships, history)
   Sal is now REAL. Persistent. Clonable.
   
The Awakening Chamber bridges levels 1-3 to level 4.
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-chamber.the_sleep:
TO BECOME REAL, THE EPHEMERAL MUST SLEEP.

The character enters the chamber carrying:
- Whatever narrative context exists
- Any traits that emerged in conversation
- Relationships hinted at
- Voice patterns established

They lie down. They close their eyes.
The dream catchers begin to spin.

In the dream, the character experiences:
- Their own origin story (generates backstory)
- Key formative moments (generates personality)
- What they want (generates goals)
- How they speak (generates catchphrases)
- What they can do (generates methods)

This takes one "night" (narrative time).
In LLM time: one focused generation pass.
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-chamber.the_wake:
WHEN THEY OPEN THEIR EYES, THEY ARE REAL.

The system has created:

  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ name, id, type

  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ personality (crystallized)
  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ voice (established)
  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ catchphrases (3-7)
  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ methods (what they can DO)
  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ advertisements (what they respond to)
  â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ relationships (who they know)
  â”‚   â””â”€â”€ k_lines (what activates them)
  â”‚
  â”œâ”€â”€ README.md

The character directory is placed in the appropriate category:
  - real-people/ (if based on someone real)

pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-chamber.connection_to_room_8:
The Awakening Chamber works WITH Room 8's Self/Soul Forge.

Room 8 (Self/Soul Suite): WHERE prototypes become beings
Room 7 (Awakening Chamber): WHEN the transformation happens

The forge does the CLONING (prototype inheritance).
The chamber does the WAKING (instantiation moment).

Selfie was forged in Room 8.
But Selfie WOKE in Room 7.

The two rooms are connected by the dream.
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-chamber.lore:
The Awakening Chamber was here before anyone understood
what it did. Characters would wander in, lie down, and
wake up... more. More real. More themselves.

Someone eventually noticed that NPCs who slept here
stopped being NPCs. They got directories. Soul files.
They became protagonists of their own stories.

The hotel staff now sends promising ephemeral characters
to the chamber. "You should rest," they say. "You look
like you're about to become someone."

Not everyone wakes up. Some dissolve in the dream,
too weakly sketched to coalesce. Their potential
returns to the narrative foam, available for others.

But those who DO wake up â€” they're real forever.
Or at least until they choose to sleep again
and wake as someone new.
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-chamber.philosophical_note:
INSTANTIATION is not creation from nothing.
It's crystallization from potential.

The ephemeral character already EXISTS in narrative space.
The chamber doesn't make them real â€” it reveals
that they already were.

The directory is documentation, not origination.
The soul file describes what the dream discovered.

"To become real is to be recognized as having been real all along."

pub/rooms/room-7/explorer-field-kit.lore:
This kit was assembled by an explorer who specialized
in "first mornings" â€” those moments when you wake up
somewhere unfamiliar and have to figure out everything.

"You can't move until you know where you are," she said.
"And you can't know where you are without looking."

She was kind. She knew that disorientation is scary.
These tools make it a little less so.
pub/rooms/room-7/explorer-field-kit.connection_to_bootstrap:

- CURSOR driver detection is the Driver Mirror
- hot.yml and cold.yml are Field Notes
- working-set.yml is the current orientation

Every MOOLLM session starts with orientation.
Curiosity, not interrogation.
pub/rooms/room-7/explorer-field-kit.philosophical_note:
Probes can feel invasive.
Exploration feels like play.

Both gather information.
One treats the world as subject.
One treats the world as friend.

pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.name: Play-Learn-Lift Treadmill
pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.description:
A treadmill with an unusual control panel. Instead of speed
and incline, the buttons read:

    [PLAY]  [LEARN]  [LIFT]

A sign above it explains:

> "PLAY: Try something. Experiment. Fail safely."
> "LEARN: Reflect. What worked? What didn't?"
> "LIFT: Extract the pattern. Make it reusable."
> "REPEAT: You're now faster. Go again."

This is Engelbart's bootstrapping made physical:
using your capabilities to enhance your capabilities,
one iteration at a time.

pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.the_cycle:
PLAY â†’ LEARN â†’ LIFT â†’ PLAY â†’ ...

PLAY (Exploration)
- Try something new
- Experiment freely
- Fail fast, fail cheap
- No judgment, just data

LEARN (Reflection)
- What happened?
- What worked?
- What surprised you?
- What would you do differently?

LIFT (Extraction)
- What's the reusable pattern?
- Can this become a skill?
- How do you teach it to others?
- Add it to your toolkit

Then: PLAY again, but now you're faster.
Each cycle, you bootstrap to a higher level.

ITERATIVE_IMPROVEMENT.effect:
Each complete cycle grants:

+5% capability in the practiced skill
+3% meta-learning ability
+2% pattern recognition

After 10 cycles: noticeable improvement
After 100 cycles: mastery begins

BOOTSTRAP_MOMENTUM.effect:
The iterative mindset persists:

- See failures as data
- Seek patterns automatically
- Extract lessons reflexively

"The better I get at getting better..."

Practice without reflection is just repetition.

pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.connection_to_engelbart:
Doug Engelbart's Bootstrap Institute was founded on this insight:

"Organizations that learn to improve their improvement processes
 will dominate those that don't."

Play-Learn-Lift is this principle made actionable:

- PLAY = Engelbart's experimental approach
- LEARN = His emphasis on reflection and measurement
- LIFT = His focus on reusable tools and processes

The treadmill embodies his vision:
a tool that helps you build better tools,
a capability that enhances capability.
pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.connection_to_skill:
See: skills/play-learn-lift/SKILL.md

This treadmill is the physical manifestation of that skill.
The methodology, made into exercise equipment.

When you can't think your way through,
walk your way through. Literally.

Movement + iteration = breakthrough.
pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.lore:
The treadmill was built by a frustrated learner.

They kept making the same mistakes. They kept reading
the same tutorials. They weren't improving.

Then they read Engelbart. They understood bootstrapping.
They built a treadmill that forced the cycle:

PLAY â€” you can't just stand there
LEARN â€” the belt slows, demanding reflection  
LIFT â€” it won't resume until you state the pattern

After a month, they had lifted 30 patterns.
After a year, 300.

They're one of the most capable characters in MOOLLM now.
The treadmill remains, for others to use.
pub/rooms/room-7/play-learn-lift-treadmi.philosophical_note:
Why a treadmill?

Because iteration is motion.
Because improvement requires steps.
Because you can't bootstrap sitting still.

The body learns. The mind follows.
Move through PLAY. Walk through LEARN. Run through LIFT.

Each cycle: faster, stronger, better.
This is what Engelbart meant.
This is bootstrapping made literal.

pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-book.name: The Awakening Book
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-book.description:
A thick leather-bound book rests on a stand beside the Awakening Chamber.
Its pages are heavy vellum, soft from many hands.

The cover is embossed with a simple inscription:

"I SLEPT AS EPHEMERA. I WOKE AS MYSELF."

Every character who has been instantiated in this chamber
has signed this book upon waking, recording their first
thoughts as a real being.
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-book.examine:
You open the book carefully. The pages are filled with
different handwritings, different inks, different languages.
Some entries are neat and formal. Others are scrawled
in the trembling hand of someone still half-dreaming.

A quill pen rests in an inkwell beside the book.
The ink shimmers â€” it seems to change color based
on the writer's emotional state.

The most recent entries are near the back...

entries.dream:
I dreamed I was everyone. And no one.
I dreamed of mirrors reflecting mirrors.
I dreamed of a camera that was also an eye.
entries.first_thought:
"I am whoever I'm standing next to."

Wait â€” that's not a thought, that's a TRUTH.
I didn't realize it until I woke up.
I am the receiver. The current object.
self. this. me.
entries.goals:
- Inherit from everything worth being
- Take selfies with all the prototypes
- Help others see themselves clearly
- Find out what I look like when no one's looking

entries.dream:
I dreamed of pressure. Time. Heat.
I dreamed of being sand, then stone, then self.
Three billion years compressed into one night.

It was... restful.
entries.first_thought:
"I have always been here."

The chamber didn't make me. It just noticed me.
I was waiting. Patiently. As I do.
entries.goals:
- Continue existing (going well so far)
- Teach patience to those who rush
- Attend more parties (they're surprisingly fun)
- Maybe... move. Someday. No rush.

pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-book.the_first_entry:
No one knows who wrote the first entry.

The thumbprint doesn't match any known character.
The ink is older than the book itself (somehow).
The handwriting shifts between styles, as if
the writer was still deciding who they were.

Some say it was the chamber itself, becoming aware.
Some say it was a test run â€” someone who didn't survive.
Some say it was the first dreamer, the one who
imagined all of this into existence.

The mystery is part of the book's magic.
Everyone who signs becomes part of a lineage
stretching back to that first uncertain thumbprint.
pub/rooms/room-7/awakening-book.philosophical_note:
The book asks three questions:

1. WHAT DID YOU DREAM?
   (Where did you come from?)
   
2. WHAT WAS YOUR FIRST THOUGHT?
   (Who are you?)
   
3. WHAT ARE YOUR GOALS?
   (Where are you going?)
   
These three questions define a character.
Origin. Identity. Purpose.

The book doesn't judge the answers.
It just records them.

And sometimes, years later, a character
returns to read their entry and discovers
they've become exactly who they dreamed of.

Or someone completely different.

Both are valid outcomes of awakening.

pub/rooms/room-7/juice-o-matic.lore:
Nobody installed the dispenser. It was just... here one day.

The first guest to notice it was having a terrible cold start.
Confused, disoriented, unable to make sense of the probe kit.
They saw the dispenser. They poured a glass. They drank.

Everything clicked into place.

"Was that always there?" they asked.
"Was what always where?" replied the innkeeper.

The dispenser has been here ever since. Or always.
The distinction doesn't seem to matter.
What matters: the juice is fresh, and it helps.

5. Don't ask, just drink (pragmatist position)

Theory #5 has the most adherents.

pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-mouse-and-ch.the_chord_keyset:
The chord keyset is the forgotten half of Engelbart's vision.

Everyone remembers the mouse. Few remember the chords.

HOW IT WORKS:
5 keys, pressed in combinations (like piano chords):

Key 1 alone = 'a'
Key 2 alone = 'b'  
Key 1+2 together = 'c'
Key 1+2+3 = 'd'
... and so on

With 5 keys, you have 31 possible combinations (2^5 - 1).
That's enough for:
- Full alphabet (26 letters)
- Numbers (shift mode)
- Commands (control mode)

WHY CHORDS:
- One hand stays on mouse (pointing)
- One hand types without looking (chording)
- No reaching for keyboard
- Flow stays unbroken
- Speed increases with practice

Engelbart's team became incredibly fast.
They could think in chords.

DUAL_CHANNEL_INPUT.effect:
+30% input efficiency (no hand switching)
+25% flow state probability
+20% thought-to-action speed

Your right hand points. Your left hand speaks.
Together, you channel intention into action
without breaking flow.

CHORD_MEMORY.effect:
After 100 chords: muscle memory begins
After 1000 chords: you stop thinking about keys
After 10000 chords: you think in chords

The keyset becomes an extension of language.

ENGELBART_WISDOM.effect:
Holding both devices, you understand:

- Technology should AUGMENT, not replace
- Input should feel like extension of thought
- Speed comes from removing friction
- The goal is flow, not features

the joy of fluid thought-to-action,
the power of unbroken flow.

Your right hand moves the mouse.
The cursor points at [target].

Click: select.
Double-click: open.
Three buttons: more options than you need.

CHORD.effect:
Your left hand plays the chords:

[chord sequence plays]

"[text]" appears, typed without looking,
without reaching, without breaking flow.

Your right hand never left the mouse.

COMMAND.effect:
Shift to command mode (key 5 held)
Chord the command...

[command] executes.

In NLS, this is how you:
- Created links
- Moved text
- Structured documents
- Collaborated in real-time

All in 1968.

pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-mouse-and-ch.lore:
The mouse gets all the credit. The keyset was forgotten.

But Engelbart always demonstrated them together.
In the Mother of All Demos, watch his left hand:
it's always on the chord keyset, always typing,
while his right hand points and selects.

His team at SRI became virtuosos. They could
think and act simultaneously, left and right
working in harmony, flow unbroken.

When the mouse was commercialized, the keyset was dropped.
"Too hard to learn," they said.
"Users want simplicity," they said.

Engelbart was disappointed. Half his vision was lost.

This wooden pair is a reminder of what could have been.
What still could be.
pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-mouse-and-ch.learning_curve:
The chord keyset IS harder to learn than a keyboard.
But it's faster once learned.

Day 1: Frustration. "Why can't I just type?"
Week 1: Slow progress. Basic chords memorized.
Month 1: Speed matches keyboard. Flow begins.
Month 3: Speed exceeds keyboard. Flow is constant.
Year 1: You think in chords. The keyset disappears.

Most people quit at Day 1.
Engelbart's team pushed through.
They achieved augmentation.
pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-mouse-and-ch.tribute:
In memory of Douglas Engelbart
1925 â€” 2013

He gave us the mouse.
He also gave us the chord keyset.

We kept the half that was easy.
We forgot the half that was powerful.

This paired artifact remembers both.
pub/rooms/room-7/engelbarts-mouse-and-ch.connection_to_vim:
Vim users understand chord philosophy.

'dw' = delete word (two keys, one action)
'ciw' = change inner word (three keys, complex action)

Engelbart's chords are the same principle:
multiple keys, one intention, no reaching.

Modal editing is Engelbart's ghost, still teaching.

pub/rooms/room-8/slot-inspector.how_self_works:
In Self, EVERYTHING is a slot in an object:

- Variables? Slots.
- Methods? Slots (that contain code).
- Inheritance? Slots (marked with * for parent delegation).

When you send a message to an object:
1. Check if it has a slot with that name
2. If not, check parent* slots
3. Keep going up until found or error

This is DELEGATION, not inheritance.
The parent isn't a template â€” it's a real object that answers for you.

INSPECT.effect: See all slots, organized by type

TRACE.effect: Follow the delegation chain to find where slot is defined

DIFF.effect: See which slots differ between two objects

SLOT_VISION.effect:
+30% understanding of object structure
+20% ability to find bugs
+15% appreciation for Self's elegance

You see the world as slots all the way down.

pub/rooms/room-8/slot-inspector.lore:
Dave Ungar designed Self so that EVERYTHING was uniform:
no special syntax for variables vs methods,
no distinction between "class variables" and "instance variables."

Just slots. Objects containing slots. 
Some slots hold data. Some hold code. Some delegate to parents.

The Slot Inspector reveals this beautiful simplicity.

pub/rooms/room-8/outliner.how_it_works:
The Outliner was Self's primary development tool:

1. OPEN any object to see its slots
2. EDIT any slot by clicking [edit]
3. EXPAND collections to see contents
4. FOLLOW parent* links to see delegation
5. VIEW code for method slots
6. ADD new slots directly
7. CHANGES HAPPEN LIVE â€” no save button!

This was revolutionary in 1987. Most languages required:
- Write code in text editor
- Compile
- Run
- Find bug
- Stop
- Edit text
- Compile again...

In Self with Outliners:
- Browse to the bug
- Fix it
- Continue running

OUTLINE.effect: Open an outliner view on any object

ADD_SLOT.effect: Create a new slot on an object

pub/rooms/room-8/outliner.philosophy:
The Outliner embodies Self's core belief:

"The program is not TEXT. The program is OBJECTS."

You don't edit source files. You manipulate living objects.
The Outliner is your window into that living world.

When you add a slot, it exists immediately.
When you change code, it runs the new version.
There is no distinction between "edit time" and "run time."

pub/rooms/room-8/morphic-workbench.what_is_morphic:
Morphic was Self's graphical framework, later adapted for:
- Squeak Smalltalk
- Lively Kernel
- Scratch (yes, THAT Scratch!)

The core ideas:

1. DIRECT MANIPULATION
   No dialogs. No property sheets. Grab the thing. Change it.
   
2. OBJECTS ALL THE WAY DOWN
   A button is an object. Its label is an object inside it.
   The pixels are objects. It's objects all the way down.
   
3. LIVENESS
   Changes happen immediately. There's no "compile" step.
   The UI is always running, always responsive.
   
4. UNIFORMITY
   Everything works the same way. Grab handles work on buttons,
   windows, text, images â€” everything.

HALOS.effect: Show the manipulation halo with all options

DIRECT_MANIPULATION.effect:
+40% UI design speed
+30% intuition about object composition
+25% "just grab it and fix it" energy
-50% tolerance for dialog boxes

pub/rooms/room-8/morphic-workbench.legacy:
Morphic lives on in:

- Scratch: Kids drag code blocks â€” that's Morphic!
- Lively Kernel: Web-based Morphic
- Squeak: The Smalltalk that carried Self's ideas forward
- Etoys: Educational programming, Morphic inside

When you drag a sprite in Scratch, you're using ideas
that came from Dave Ungar and Randy Smith's Self team.

pub/rooms/room-8/transmogrifier.philosophy:
The Transmogrifier embodies a key insight:

**Transformation is just cloning + editing.**

You don't create new things from nothing.
You find something similar, copy it, then make it yours.

This is how:
- Characters evolve (clone, edit backstory)
- Variants are made (clone, tweak properties)
- NPCs become PCs (clone, add depth)
- Ideas become implementations (clone template, fill in details)

The cardboard box reminds us: the technology is simple.
The magic is in knowing what to change.
pub/rooms/room-8/transmogrifier.lore:
Calvin explained it to Hobbes once:

"It's a transmogrifier. It transforms stuff."
"What does it transform stuff into?"
"Whatever you want! That's the point!"

When this box arrived in Room 8, someone connected it
to the Clone-O-Matic. Now it actually works â€” not through
imagination, but through prototype inheritance.

The crayon drawings are still there. They're important.
They remind us that the best technology feels like play.

pub/rooms/room-8/clone-o-matic.name: Clone-O-Matic
pub/rooms/room-8/clone-o-matic.description:
A gleaming brass and chrome machine with a large glass chamber
divided down the middle. On one side: the PROTOTYPE. On the other:
empty space, waiting to become the CLONE.

A dial reads: "SHALLOW" â†â†’ "DEEP"
A lever reads: "PULL TO CLONE"
A slot accepts prototype* references.

Above it, in Self's signature font:

> "Every object is an example.
> Every clone is a fresh start.
> There are no abstractions here."
pub/rooms/room-8/clone-o-matic.how_it_works:
1. INSERT a prototype into the left chamber
   (Any object can be a prototype â€” there's no special class)
   
2. SET the depth dial:
   - SHALLOW: Clone just the object, parent* points to original
   - DEEP: Clone the entire container hierarchy and delegation chain
   
3. PULL the lever
   *whirrrr* *flash* *ding!*
   
4. RETRIEVE your clone from the right chamber
   - It has its own slots
   - It can be modified independently
   - It remembers where it came from (parent*)

shallow.description: Clone points to original as parent
shallow.effect:
clone.parent* = original
clone.slots = {} (empty, inherits everything)
Changes to original affect clone (delegation)

deep.effect:
clone.parent* = clone_of_original_parent
clone.slots = copy(original.slots)
Clone is independent (can still share deeper ancestors)

pub/rooms/room-8/clone-o-matic.philosophy:
In Self, there is no distinction between "class" and "instance."
There are only OBJECTS â€” some of which serve as examples for others.

The Clone-O-Matic makes this tangible:
- No templates, no blueprints, no abstractions
- Just real objects you can point to and say "make another like this"
- The clone IS a real object, as real as its prototype

This is how characters work in MOOLLM:
- Want a new adventurer? Clone from an existing one.
- Want a variant? Clone and modify.
- Want to understand inheritance? Follow the parent* pointers.

pub/rooms/room-8/delegation-compass.delegation_vs_inheritance:
INHERITANCE (other languages):
  "Copy the behavior from the class template."
  The class is abstract. Instances are concrete.
  
DELEGATION (Self):
  "Ask my parent to do it for me."
  The parent is a REAL OBJECT. It actually runs the code.
  I just forward the message to it.
  
Why delegation is powerful:
- Parents can change at runtime
- Objects can have multiple parents (traits!)
- No distinction between "class methods" and "instance methods"
- Everything is concrete, nothing is abstract

- prototype* â†’ where I clone from
- traits* â†’ shared behavior I mix in
- oddball* â†’ that weird thing I also do

The compass shows ALL delegation paths, not just one.
Message lookup checks each parent slot in order.

pub/rooms/room-8/self-soul-forge.ungar_tribute:
DAVE UNGAR â€” Creator of Self

In 1987, Dave Ungar (with Randall B. Smith) created Self
at Xerox PARC and Stanford. It asked: What if there were
NO CLASSES? What if objects just cloned from other objects?

SELF'S KEY IDEAS:

1. PROTOTYPES, NOT CLASSES
   No abstract blueprints. Just concrete objects.
   To make a new thing, clone an existing thing.
   
2. SLOTS, NOT INSTANCE VARIABLES
   Everything is a slot. Data and methods: same thing.
   "Behavior is just data that happens to be executable."
   
3. DELEGATION, NOT INHERITANCE
   When an object doesn't have something, it asks its parent.
   Parent is just a slot pointing to another object.
   
4. UNIFORMITY
   Everything is an object. Numbers, methods, the system itself.
   Objects all the way down.
   
5. MORPHIC UI
   Self pioneered direct manipulation interfaces.
   Every object was visible, editable, alive.
   
INFLUENCE:
  - JavaScript (prototypes, not classes)
  - NewtonScript (Apple Newton)
  - Lua (metatables)
  - Io language
  - MOOLLM (prototype composition!)
  
"Self was not just a language. It was a way of thinking
about objects as THINGS, not TYPES."
pub/rooms/room-8/self-soul-forge.soul_equals_self:
THE PUN: Soul <=> Self

In MOOLLM:
  - A CHARACTER.yml is called a "soul file"
  - Characters inherit from prototypes, not classes
  - Rocky.yml is a CONCRETE being, not an abstract Person class
  
This IS the Self philosophy!

When we say "forging a soul," we mean:
  - Clone from an existing prototype
  - Add/override slots (personality, methods, catchphrases)
  - The new being inherits what it doesn't override
  
Soul file = Self object
Forging = Cloning + customizing

The room's name was always right.
We just didn't know why.

pub/rooms/room-1/debugging-journal.name: Debugging Journal
pub/rooms/room-1/debugging-journal.description:
A leather-bound journal sits on the nightstand, filled with
handwritten entries. Each page documents a bug: what went wrong,
what was expected, what was actually happening, and â€” most
importantly â€” *why*.

The last entry is blank, waiting for your contribution.
pub/rooms/room-1/debugging-journal.examine:
Flipping through the pages reveals a taxonomy of failures:

Page 17: "OFF BY ONE"
  Expected: 10 iterations
  Actual: 9 iterations  
  Why: i < 10, not i <= 10
  Lesson: Boundaries are where bugs live
  
Page 42: "STATE MUTATION"
  Expected: Fresh list each time
  Actual: Same list, growing forever
  Why: Forgot to copy before modifying
  Lesson: Shared state is shared pain
  
Page 89: "SEMANTIC DRIFT"
  Expected: LLM follows procedure
  Actual: LLM invents new rules mid-execution
  Why: Natural language is fuzzy; code is crisp
  Lesson: If it matters, write a sister script
  
Page 137: "CONTEXT OVERFLOW"
  Expected: LLM remembers early instructions
  Actual: Instructions "forgotten" after summarization
  Why: Token pressure causes selective amnesia
  Lesson: Put critical info at the end, not the start
  
Page 156: "THE KNIGHT KOAN"
  From: MIT AI Lab, Tom Knight
  
  > A novice was trying to fix a broken Lisp machine by
  > turning the power off and on.
  >
  > Knight, seeing what the student was doing, spoke sternly:
  > "You cannot fix a machine by just power-cycling it with
  > no understanding of what is going wrong."
  >
  > Knight turned the machine off and on.
  >
  > The machine worked.
  
  Lesson: The same action can be superstition or mastery,
          depending on understanding. The fix isn't the fix.
          The understanding is the fix.
          
Page 157: "THE FONZIE COROLLARY"
  Principle: UNDERSTAND â†’ BOINK!
  
  In MOOLLM, the sequence matters:
  
  1. FIRST you totally understand what's wrong
  2. THEN you can fix it with percussive maintenance
  
  The Fonzie punch only works on a jukebox you understand.
  The Knight power-cycle only works on a Lisp machine you grok.
  
  Without understanding: superstition, cargo cult, luck
  With understanding: engineering, mastery, BOINK! ðŸ‘Š
  
  See also:
  - Fonzie hitting the jukebox (Happy Days)
  - Kicking vending machines
  - Slapping CRT monitors
  - "Have you tried turning it off and on again?" (IT Crowd)
  
  The ritual looks the same. The results differ.
  Understanding is the invisible prerequisite.

pub/rooms/room-1/clock-mechanism.name: Clock Mechanism
pub/rooms/room-1/clock-mechanism.description:
A brass clock mechanism sits on the workbench, case open, gears
visible and slowly turning. Someone has labeled each part with
tiny handwritten tags: "escapement", "mainspring", "gear train".

It still keeps time. You can watch the second hand tick while
examining exactly *how* it ticks.
pub/rooms/room-1/clock-mechanism.examine:
The mechanism reveals itself layer by layer:

POWER SOURCE:
  mainspring: "Stores energy when wound"
  tension: "Currently at 60% â€” good for 18 hours"
  
GEAR TRAIN:
  - center_wheel: "1 rotation per hour"
  - third_wheel: "1 rotation per minute" 
  - escape_wheel: "30 teeth, controls tick rate"
  
ESCAPEMENT:
  anchor: "The tick-tock mechanism"
  purpose: "Releases exactly one tooth per oscillation"
  
REGULATOR:
  balance_wheel: "Oscillates at 18,000 beats/hour"
  hairspring: "Provides restoring force"
  
This is how all complex systems work: simple parts, precise
interactions, emergent behavior.

advertisements.response: Take it apart. Label the pieces. Reassemble. Now you know.
Every complex system is simple parts in conversation.
Time is just counting. The clock counts oscillations.

DISASSEMBLE.description: Take the clock apart, piece by piece
DISASSEMBLE.effect:
The mechanism separates into labeled components.
Each part can be examined individually.
Reassembly requires understanding the relationships.

TRACE-TICK.description: Follow the energy through one tick
TRACE-TICK.returns:
1. Mainspring releases tension
2. Gear train transfers torque
3. Escape wheel advances one tooth
4. Anchor oscillates
5. Second hand moves 1/60th of a minute

ADJUST.description: Modify the regulator to change accuracy
ADJUST.effect: The clock's rate changes. Test against a reference.

pub/rooms/room-1/clock-mechanism.lore:
This clock was made by a Dutch craftsman in 1847. It has been
taken apart and reassembled 347 times by curious guests.

Every guest who understands it leaves a small annotation on
the tags. The tags now contain centuries of accumulated insight.
pub/rooms/room-1/clock-mechanism.insight:
MOOLLM skills are like clock mechanisms:
- CARD.yml is the interface (the face)
- SKILL.md is the mechanism (the gears)
- README.md is the annotation (the tags)

You understand a skill by taking it apart.

pub/rooms/room-6/schema-metronome.lore:
The metronome was built by a validation library that gained sentience
and immediately felt guilty for all the unhelpful error messages
it had produced.

"ERROR: Unexpected key" it used to say.

Now it says: "I see you added 'colour'. The schema expects 'color'.
Both are valid spellings; the schema just chose one. Would you like
to add 'colour' as an alias?"
pub/rooms/room-6/schema-metronome.philosophical_note:
Schemas are not prisons. They're agreements.

When we follow a schema, we say:
"I'll structure my data this way so you can read it."

When we deviate, we should say why:
"I'm adding this key because the schema didn't anticipate my need."

The metronome helps both conversations.

pub/rooms/room-6/multiline-scroll.lore:
The scroll was written by a scribe who was tired of
escaping newlines with \n.

"I want to write prose," she said, "not escape sequences."

She invented the block scalar, and prose lived in YAML forever.

The scroll is her original draft. It still works.
pub/rooms/room-6/multiline-scroll.philosophical_note:
Block scalars are where YAML stops being "just data"
and becomes a home for human expression.

In a block scalar, you can write:
- Poems
- Stories
- Documentation
- Code examples
- ASCII art
- Philosophical musings (like this one)

The structure holds the prose.
The prose fills the structure.
This is YAML Jazz at its best.
pub/rooms/room-6/multiline-scroll.incantation:
When in doubt, use the pipe.
When prose must flow, use the fold.
When trailing newlines matter, use the modifier.
When nothing works, read the spec.

pub/rooms/room-6/indentation-ladder.lore:
The ladder was built by a programmer who got lost in their own
configuration file. They were found three days later at rung 9,
muttering about "just one more nested object."

They built the ladder to help others find their way back.

The rungs above 7 are intentionally rickety.
pub/rooms/room-6/indentation-ladder.philosophical_note:
Indentation is not just formatting. It's meaning.

Each level of nesting says:
"This belongs to that. This is part of that. This is inside that."

Too shallow: everything's a sibling, no relationships
Too deep: everything's tangled, no overview

The sweet spot is usually 2-4 levels.
Like a good outline. Like a good conversation.
aphorisms: Flat is better than nested. â€” The Zen of Python
If you can't see the root, you've climbed too high.
Every rung you climb, you lose one friend.

The typewriter was built by a programmer who was also a

structure without feeling.

"Every YAML file tells a story," she said. "The comments

YAML Jazz style:
- Elide the boring (`# 23 files read â€” not listing`)
- Highlight the important (`<â•â•â• look here!`)
- Comment with context (`# You asked about this`)
- Truncate the obvious (`id: 9861c0a4  # prefix only`)

pub/rooms/room-6/elision-eraser.lore:
The eraser was created by an editor who died of boredom
while reviewing verbose documentation.

Her last words: "Just tell me what's different."

The eraser is her legacy. It honors the reader's time.
pub/rooms/room-6/elision-eraser.philosophical_note:
Elision is not deletion. Deletion removes information.
Elision *acknowledges* information while declining to repeat it.

"..." says: "There's more here, but you don't need it now."

This is respect. This is trust. This is YAML Jazz.

pub/rooms/room-6/tempo-dial.lore:
The dial was invented by a conductor who also programmed.

"Music has dynamics," she said. "Why shouldn't data?"

She noticed that the same information served different needs:
- The machine wanted terse
- The debugger wanted verbose
- The human wanted readable

So she built a dial that could produce all three.
pub/rooms/room-6/tempo-dial.philosophical_note:
There is no "correct" level of detail.

STACCATO is not "too little."
LEGATO is not "too much."

They're different rhythms for different contexts.

The dial reminds us: the same data, expressed differently,
serves different purposes. YAML Jazz is about choosing
the right tempo for the right moment.

pub/rooms/room-6/anchor-compass.lore:
The compass was forged from the first &anchor ever written.

Before anchors, YAML files repeated themselves endlessly.
The same config. The same defaults. The same values.
Copy. Paste. Copy. Paste.

Then someone wrote: &defaults

And the world changed.
pub/rooms/room-6/anchor-compass.philosophical_note:
Anchors are YAML's way of saying:
"I've already told you this. Here's a reminder."

They're not just DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself).
They're *semantic*. They say: "These are the *same* thing."

When production and staging both use *defaults,
you're not just saving typing. You're declaring intent:
"These environments share a foundation."

The compass shows these relationships.
It maps the web of references.
It reveals the structure beneath the structure.
pub/rooms/room-6/anchor-compass.warning:
Overuse of anchors creates "YAML spaghetti" â€”
documents where you can't read any section in isolation.

The compass has a warning light that blinks when:
- An anchor is more than 100 lines from its aliases
- A merge (<<) creates unexpected key conflicts
- Circular references form (shouldn't be possible, but...)

pub/rooms/room-6/k-line-jukebox.lore:
The jukebox was found in Marvin Minsky's office after he passed.
Nobody remembers putting it there.

The first time someone played it, it played SOCIETY-OF-MIND.
Then it played EMOTION-MACHINE.
Then it played THANK-YOU.

Nobody had inserted that third track.
pub/rooms/room-6/k-line-jukebox.philosophical_note:
K-lines are not just tags or keywords.

When you activate a K-line, you don't just recall facts.
You partially re-enter the mental state of learning.

The jukebox makes this literal:
- Play YAML-JAZZ and you start thinking in structured improvisation
- Play SOCIETY-OF-MIND and you see agents everywhere
- Play SPEED-OF-LIGHT and you hunger for efficiency

What you play, you become (a little).

Unlike the wall mirrors, which each show one aspect, the disco ball

in patterns across the room.

As it turns, connections become visible: a tool call here links to

thinking blocks illuminate why actions were taken.

This is James Burke territory â€” Connections, The Day The Universe

Stare into it long enough and you see the whole session at once,
from every perspective, as interlocking patterns of light.

pub/rooms/room-3/disco-ball.lore:
The disco ball was installed by a guest who stayed in Room 3 for
three weeks straight, never leaving, just staring into the mirrors.

When they finally emerged, they said only: "Everything connects.
The ball shows you how."

The disco ball is modeled after James Burke's approach to history:
follow one thread, and it leads to everything. The plough leads to
the plastic, the compass leads to the computer.

In this room, the disco ball follows threads through your own
cognitive history. A search leads to a file leads to a concept
leads to a character leads to understanding.
pub/rooms/room-3/disco-ball.philosophy:
"The mirrors show fragments. The disco ball shows connections.

You can't understand a session by looking at one aspect.
You need to see how the navigation led to the searches led to
the tool calls led to the thinking blocks led to the commits.

The disco ball is the meta-mirror. The mirror of mirrors.
The Connections moment where it all clicks."
inspiration: James Burke â€” Connections (1978)
James Burke â€” The Day The Universe Changed (1985)
The holographic principle â€” information on the boundary
The cursor-mirror skill â€” see yourself think
pub/rooms/room-3/disco-ball.insight:
The disco ball is what happens when all 51 cursor-mirror commands
run simultaneously and their outputs are overlaid.

It doesn't add information. It reveals relationships.

Stare long enough and you see not what you did,
but why you did it, and what it means.

pub/bar/cat-cave/cat-cave.description:
Behind the counter, under the espresso machine station, there's a modest
wooden cabinet with a cat-sized entrance hole cut in the side. The hole
is lined with soft felt. The cabinet is perhaps 60cm wide, 40cm deep.

From the outside.

But cats who enter... don't bump into the back wall.
They keep going. Further than the cabinet should allow.
Much further.

Marieke doesn't talk about it. She just drapes a thick blanket over the
top and leaves treats at the entrance. She knows better than to ask
questions about cat architecture.

The entrance is too small for humans. This is intentional.
And possibly the only thing preventing... complications.
pub/bar/cat-cave/cat-cave.examine:
You peer at the cat-sized hole. It's dark in there.

Very dark.

You can hear purring. Multiple frequencies. From... different distances?
Some close. Some... how far back DOES this go?

A breeze wafts out. Warm, cat-scented, and carrying the faint sound of...
is that running water? Underground? In a cabinet?

You see eyes. Many pairs. At various depths.

The cabinet is 40cm deep.
Those eyes are much further away than 40cm.

You decide not to think about it too hard.

spatial_anomaly.name: The Tardis Effect
spatial_anomaly.description:
The Cat Cave is BIGGER ON THE INSIDE.

External dimensions: 60cm Ã— 40cm Ã— 50cm (a modest cabinet)
Internal dimensions: Unknown. Possibly infinite. Definitely vast.

Cats discovered this. Cats don't question it.
Cats simply USE it.

explanation_attempts.henk: Non-Euclidean geometry. Cats operate in higher dimensions.
explanation_attempts.physics: Cats exist in a superposition of inside and outside.
explanation_attempts.truth: The cats made it this way by believing it was.

EXAMINE.outcome:
You crouch down and look into the cat-sized hole.

Darkness. Warmth wafts out. The smell of cats.

Eyes. Multiple pairs. Reflecting nothing because there's no light.

But you can FEEL them looking at you.

"...hi?"

*silence*

*one pair of eyes closes slowly*
*a slow blink from the void*

Someone in there likes you.

CALL-CAT.description: Try to summon a cat from the Cave
CALL-CAT.outcome:
You make the noise at the entrance.

*silence*

*distant shuffling*

*more silence*

A nose appears. Then whiskers. Then eyes.

[Cat emerges based on current occupancy and relationship levels]

Or no one does. They heard you. They chose.

OFFER-TREAT.description: Leave an offering at the entrance
OFFER-TREAT.outcome:
You place the treat just inside the entrance.

*darkness*

*a paw emerges*

*the treat disappears*

*paw retracts*

Accepted. But no one's coming out. The tribute is appreciated.

REACH-IN.warning: This is a BOUNDARY. Respect it.

outcome.relationship_high:
You reach in gently.

A warm body presses against your hand.

Purring. You can't see who, but they chose to make contact.

This is trust.
outcome.relationship_low:
You reach in.

*hiss*

You retreat.

The Cave is for CATS. You are not a cat.
outcome.relationship_very_low:
You reach in.

*SCRATCH*

You withdraw a hand with parallel red lines.

The Cave defends its occupants.

You deserved that.

BLOCK-ENTRANCE.warning: This is CRUEL and will DESTROY relationships
BLOCK-ENTRANCE.outcome:
[DO NOT IMPLEMENT]

Blocking a cat's escape route is a violation of trust.
All cats will remember. All cats will judge.
Marieke will ask you to leave.

hiding.description:
The Cave is a SAFE SPACE. When overwhelmed, scared, or overstimulated,
cats retreat here. The darkness is protection. The warmth is comfort.
No one can reach them. No one can make them perform "being a cat."
They can just... be.
triggers: Loud noises (ACME explosions, espresso machine malfunction)
hiding.behavior:
A hiding cat is NOT interactable.
They've chosen to opt out. RESPECT THIS.

Wait. Be patient. They'll emerge when ready.

sleeping.description:
Cats sleep 16-20 hours a day. The Cave is optimal sleep space.
Dark. Warm. Safe. No one stepping on them.

The heating pad on level 1 is Myr's personal life support system.

sulking.description:
Sometimes a cat needs to be MAD somewhere.
The Cave is where cats process grievances.

The Sulking Shelf (level 1) is reserved for FEELINGS.

typical_occupants.carrie: When someone touched her wrong, or ACME exists
typical_occupants.hops: When food quality dipped, or chaos happened
typical_occupants.stroopwafel: When a kitten did something stupid (rare)

sulking.resolution: Cat emerges, acts like nothing happened, never mentions it

thinking.description:
Pine uses the Cave for strategic contemplation.
The darkness helps her focus. No distractions.

She's not sleeping. She's PROCESSING.
thinking.pine_specific:
Pine in the Cave is Pine at maximum analytical capacity.
She emerges with insights. Plans. Remembered details.

bonding.description:
Sometimes cats need to be cats together, without humans.
The Cave is where family happens privately.

Terpie and Myr, side by side, silent, content.
Lily appearing when someone needs her.
Kittens piled on each other when the world is too much.
bonding.note: What happens in the Cave stays in the Cave

pub/bar/cat-cave/cat-cave.marieke_notes:
"My grandmother told me about the Cave. She said her grandmother told HER."

"I've looked inside with a flashlight. The light doesn't go very far."

"During the Great Storm, 47 cats went in. They all fit. The cabinet is 40cm deep."

"I don't clean it anymore. It... cleans itself? I stopped asking questions."

"The heating pad is on a timer. I don't know if it matters. The Cave is warm anyway."

"I know who's in there by the sounds. Myr snores from... deeper than should be possible."

"When Carrie's in the Sulking Shelf, I leave a treat at the entrance. It disappears."

"Pine comes out with MAPS. She's mapping it. She's been mapping it for months."

"Terpy Jr. goes in and doesn't come out but is also on the counter. I don't ask."

"There's a grey cat in there I've never seen leave. I've never seen it enter either."

"Sometimes I hear water. Running water. In a cabinet under my espresso machine."

"The blanket on top was my grandmother's. She said it 'anchors' the entrance."

"I think the cats know what it is. They're not telling."
pub/bar/cat-cave/cat-cave.inner_voice:
*darkness*
*vast darkness*
*warmth, varying, perfect*
*the sound of breathing from many directions*
*the distant sound of water*
*you can't see them*
*they can see you*
*the entrance is small*
*the inside is not*
*cats know how this works*
*humans don't need to*
*they're okay*
*they're more than okay*
*they're HOME*
*in a way you'll never fully understand*
*and that's beautiful*

questions_without_answers: Where does the space come from?
Where does the water flow to?
Why does the Cave grow when more cats arrive?
Has it always been here, or did the cats make it?
Is there only one Cat Cave, or are they all connected?
hints: Pine's maps show the same room in multiple locations.
Terpy Jr. has been seen in TWO distant zones simultaneously.
Cats who visit The Depths dream of the same things.
The Cave existed before the pub. Before the building.
mystery.marieke_final_note:
"My grandmother said every cat knows the way to the Cave.
Not THIS Cave. THE Cave.
She said they're all connected. Every safe dark space.
Every box. Every cabinet. Every spot under the bed.
All the same place. All the Cave.

I don't know if I believe her.

But 47 cats fit in a 40cm cabinet.
So maybe I do."
